questions.text: The naked DNA is lysed by the enzyme DNAse. Which of following methods of gene transfer will mostly likely be inhibited when two strains of bacteria are mixed in the presence of DNAse?
questions.solution:
Transformation will most likely be inhibited as it involves the direct uptake of naked DNA by the recipient cell from the environment.

 Transformation is the direct uptake of naked DNA by the bacterial cell from the environment. Several bacteria such as Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae, and Neisseria undergo transformation. 

The transfer of genes for diphtheria toxin on a corynebacteriophage occurs by transduction.

Other options

Option A: Conjugation is the method of gene transfer in bacteria that involves physical contact by a male or donor bacterium with a female or recipient bacterium through an extracellular protein extrusion or appendage called the sex pili. The genetic material that is transferred is usually derived from plasmids. The bacteria that possess the ability to form the sex pili contain the F+ plasmid and are designated as F+. The F+ bacteria can transfer a single strand of the F+ plasmid DNA to F- bacteria via the sex pili. 

Option C: Transduction can be defined as the transfer of a portion of DNA from one bacterium to another by a bacteriophage. This type of horizontal gene transfer may occur by two mechanisms:

  • Lytic cycle - In the lytic cycle, also known as the virulent cycle, a large number of progeny phages build up inside the host bacterium; eventually, the host cell ruptures, releasing the bacteriophages. Some of the bacteriophages will now contain bacterial DNA, which can then be transferred to other bacteria.
  • Lysogenic cycle - In the temperate or non-lytic cycle, the host bacterium is not lysed. Rather, the phage DNA becomes integrated with the bacterial chromosome. This phage DNA multiplies with the host cell and is transferred to daughter cells. 

Option D: Transposition is a process of gene transfer that involves special segments of DNA called transposons (jumping genes).

questions.text: Which of the following cytokines inhibits the production of both interferon gamma and IL-12?
questions.solution:
IL-10 is an anti-inflammatory cytokine and inhibits the production of both interferon gamma and IL–12.

Related Pearl: Cytokines

Interleukins Main sources
IL-1 (α and β) Macrophages and other cell types
IL-2 T cells
IL-3 T cells
IL-4 TH cells
IL-5 TH cells
IL-6 TH, macrophages, fibroblasts
IL-8 Macrophages, others
IL-10 T, B cells, macrophages

Pro-inflammatory cytokines: 

  • IL-1: induces inﬂammation, fever, and sepsis, activates TNF-α; proliferation and differentiation of T, B, and other cells; bone marrow cell proliferation
  • IL-2: promote growth and differentiation of T and B cells; cytotoxicity of T and NK cells; secretion of other lymphokines
  • IL-6: promote B cell stimulation & differentiation; mediator of acute phase reactions; IgG production
  • IL-8: attracts and activates neutrophils in inflammatory regions; neutrophil chemotaxis
  • IFN-α: antiviral, immunoregulatory (enhance MHC class I, NK-cell activity), antiproliferative
  • TNF-α: activate macrophages and cytotoxic cells, induce cachexia, acute phase proteins, cytokines such as IL-1 and IL-6

Anti-inflammatory cytokines: 

  • IL-4: proliferation of B and cytotoxic cells; increases IgG1 and IgE production; enhances MHC-class II receptor
  • IL-10: inhibits IFN-γ and IL-12 production; inhibits IFN production and mononuclear cell functions
  • IL-13

Acute inflammation and sepsis: 

  • TNF-α
  • IL-1

Special Cytokines: 

  1. IFN-γ: 
    • Granuloma formation
    • Antiviral
    • Immunoregulatory (enhances MHC classes I and II and macrophage activation)
    • Antiproliferative
  2. TGF-β: 
    • Fibrosis 
    • Activate macrophages
  3. VEGF:
    • promotes angiogenesis

questions.text: Prior to class switching, all B cells attached to antigen have which of the following antibody on their surface?
questions.solution:
Prior to class switching, all B cells which are attached to antigen have IgM on their surface.

Later, gene rearrangement generates antibodies of the same antigenic specificity but of diﬀerent immunoglobulin classes (IgG, IgA or IgE).

Clinical correlate:

Hyper IgM syndrome is due to deficiency of the CD40 ligand, and its absence in B cells interferes with class switching and the production of memory cells.

The B-cell response to antigens, is unaffected, accounting for the presence of IgM antibodies; hence, the condition is known as Hyper IgM syndrome.

 

The following image explains gene rearrangement for class switching:

questions.text: Which of the following pairs is most likely to be associated with biofilm formation?
questions.solution:
Pseudomonas aeruginosa causing lung infection in the case of cystic fibrosis patients is associated with biofilm formation.

This biofilm provides a hypoxic environment and thereby protects it against antimicrobial agents.

The following image shows pyocyanin of P. aeruginosa, the green pigment in left tube cultured on heart infusion soft agar medium. The aerobic bacteria grow only on the surface of the medium (forming whitish biofilm), and water-soluble green pigment diffuses down.

The following image shows P. aeruginosa with fluorescent pigment under UV-light on cetrimide agar-agar.

Cystic fibrosis:

  • It is an inherited autosomal recessive disorder caused by the presence of mutations in both copies of the gene for the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR).
  • Impaired mucociliary clearance or malfunction of antibacterial peptides, increased the availability of bacterial receptors, and reduced ingestion of pathogens by CF cells are the factors involved in chronic lung infections in cystic fibrosis.

E. coli virulence is mediated by pili that extend from the bacterial cell surface and help mediate adherence to host cell surfaces.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms is seen in the given gram stain image?
questions.solution:
The gram stain shows gram-positive, club-shaped rods, which indicate Corynebacterium diphtheriae.

Clinical correlate:

  • Diphtheria toxin is absorbed into the mucous membrane causing destruction of epithelium leading to pseudomembrane formation, myocarditis and tubular necrosis in kidneys.
  • Inﬂammation begins in the respiratory tract causing a sore throat and low-grade fever. Dyspnea soon follows because of the obstruction caused by the membrane.

 

The following image shows Staphylococcus (gram-positive cocci) in clusters:

The following image shows Streptococci (gram-positive cocci) in chains:

questions.text: A female patient presented to the OPD with dysuria and frequent micturition. Urinalysis showed pus cells. A culture study yields a gram-negative rod, forming non-lactose fermenting colonies on MacConkey's agar, and shows swarming on the blood agar plate. What is the likely causative agent implicated here?
questions.solution:
A gram-negative rod, forming non-lactose fermenting colonies on MacConkey's agar with characteristic swarming motility is suggestive of Proteus.

Swarming effect is produced on blood agar which is characterized by expanding rings (waves) of organisms over the surface of the agar. Organisms exhibiting swarming include:

  • Proteus
  • Vibrio parahaemolyticus
  • Clostridium tetani

Proteus species are Gram-negative, non-capsulated, pleomorphic, motile rods. They are opportunistic pathogens, often causing nosocomial infections, infections in burns, and commonly responsible for urinary tract infections.

Proteus species are urease-positive, non-lactose fermenters. They possess the enzyme phenylalanine deaminase which converts phenylalanine to phenyl pyruvic acid (PPA). This is called the PPA reaction.

Proteus species exhibit swarming on solid media such as blood agar by using their peritrichous flagella. The image below shows the swarming effect.

Related Pearl: Types of motility of microorganisms

Motility Microorganism
Darting/vibratory motility  Vibrio,Campylobacter
Swarming motility Cl. septicum, B.cereus, Proteus, some Vibrio sp
Tumbling motility  Listeria monocytogenes

Cork-screw motility  Treponema pallidum

Twitching motility Eikenella corrodens
Differential motility (Motility varies at different temperatures) Yersinia enterocolitica & Listeria monocytogenes
Jerky motility  Trichomonas vaginalis

Lashing motility  Saprophytic spirochetes

questions.text: Streptococci that show alpha hemolysis on blood agar are again classified on the basis of?
questions.solution:
Streptococci that show alpha hemolysis on blood agar are again classified on the basis of optochin sensitivity and bile solubility.

  • Alpha hemolysis: Streptococcus pneumoniae is sensitive to optochin and is bile soluble. Viridians streptococci are resistant to optochin and are bile insoluble.
  • Beta hemolysis: Group B is resistant to bacitracin and Group A is sensitive to it.
  • Gamma hemolysis: Enterococcus grows in 6.5% NaCl and non-enterococcus does not.

questions.text: Which of the following gram-negative bacilli does not ferment lactose but is oxidase-positive?
questions.solution:
Among the given organisms, only Pseudomonas does not ferment lactose and is oxidase positive.

  • Klebsiella and Escherichia coli: Lactose fermentation positive
  • Salmonella and Proteus: Lactose fermentation negative and oxidase negative (H2S on TSI agar)
  • Shigella and Yersinia: Lactose fermentation negative and oxidase negative (No H2S on TSI agar)

questions.text: Vibrio cholerae causes diarrhea due to the presence of a toxin that results in?
questions.solution:
Cholera toxin causes diarrhea by overactivation of adenylate cyclase by permanently activating Gs causing increased secretion of chloride ion and H2O efflux into the gut.

  • Corynebacterium diphtheriae (Diphtheria toxin) and Pseudomonas (Exotoxin A) act by inactivation of elongation factor (EF-2).
  • Botulinum toxin cleaves SNARE protein and causes flaccid paralysis.
  • Shigella and EHEC cause inactivation of 60S ribosome by removing adenine from rRNA.

Related Pearl: Mechanism of action of various bacterial toxins

The mechanism of action of various bacterial toxins are as given below:

Increase in cAMP

  • Bordetella pertusis
  • Bacillus anthracis
  • Vibrio cholerae - Cholera toxin
  • Enterotoxigenic E.coli (ETEC) - heat labile toxin

Increase in cGMP

  • Enterotoxigenic E.coli (ETEC) - heat stable toxin

Inhibition of protein synthesis

  • Diptheria toxin: inhibit elongation factor-2 (EF-2)
  • Pseudomonas: inhibit elongation factor-2 (EF-2)
  • Clostridium difficile
  • Enterohemorrhagic E.coli (EHEC)-Shiga-like toxin: inhibit 60S
  • Shigella dysenteriae- Shiga toxin: inhibit 60S

questions.text: A patient presented with a swelling and chronic pus discharge from the mandibular region. The swelling developed a few days after undergoing a dental procedure 6 months ago. The discharge was foul-smelling with numerous yellow granules. Which of the following is false regarding the implicated pathogen?

choices.text: The causative organism is a gram-positive anaerobe
Sulfur granules are seen under microscopy
Treatment involves administration of penicillin for 2 weeks
Molar tooth colonies are seen when it is grown on brain-heart infusion agar

questions.solution:
Based on the clinical presentation, this is a case of cervicofacial actinomycosis caused by Actinomyces israeli. Infections caused by actinomyces should be treated by penicillin for about 6-12 months.

Actinomycosis is an indolent, slowly progressive suppurative and granulomatous infection that produces pyogenic lesions with interconnecting sinus tracts that contain sulfur granules. It is an anaerobic or microaerophilic bacteria. 

It presents as one of the following clinical types:

  • Cervicofacial actinomycosis- (most common site) fluctuant mass in the jaw area producing draining fistulas. (lumpy jaw)
  • Thoracic actinomycosis- pulmonary infection with fever, cough, and purulent sputum. It usually occurs following aspiration or trauma leading to inoculation of the infective material.
  • Abdominal actinomycosis- following ruptured appendix or ulcer. It may involve multiple organs.
  • Pelvic actinomycosis- due to the colonization of intrauterine contraceptive devices.
  • Actinomycosis can spread to bones and surrounding tissue and produce multiple discharging sinuses.

Diagnosis is by Gram staining of sulfur granules that shows a dense network of thin gram-positive filaments, surrounded by club-shaped structures. (sunray appearance). Culture shows the "molar tooth" appearance of the colonies. On solid media, A. israeli produces spidery colonies. 

Treatment:

Penicillin G is the drug of choice and requires prolonged administration where the duration of therapy is between 6-12 months. The other drugs that can be used include amoxicillin, erythromycin, tetracycline, doxycycline, clindamycin, and minocycline. Surgical excision and drainage may be required.

Other options:

  • Molar tooth colonies are seen on brain-heart infusion agar.
  • Sulfur granules (unstained gross yellow color) are seen under microscopy.

Histological image showing Splendore-Hoeppli phenomenon by actinomyces (eosinophilic rim at the periphery of the colony consists of immunoglobulin).

"Molar tooth" colonies shown on brain-heart infusion agar

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Quantiferon-Gold In-Tube test (QFT-GIT) is correct?

choices.text: It is an ELISA technique that detects TB by using purified mononuclear cells
It is more sensitive for children below the age of 5
It is used as an alternative to tuberculin skin test
It uses molecular probes to detect DNA of TB

questions.solution:
Quantiferon-Gold In-Tube test (QFT-GIT) is an interferon-gamma release assay which is used as an alternative to the tuberculin skin test.

It is an ELISA technique that detects interferon-gamma in blood.

Other options:

  • T-Spot-TB is another ELISA technique that uses purified peripheral blood mononuclear cells.
  • These techniques should not be used in severely immunocompromised individuals and children less than 5 years of age.
  • GeneXpert MTB/RIF (Nucleic acid amplification tests) test is used for rapid detection of M tuberculosis in specimen through DNA detection.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presented with low-grade fever. On examination, a characteristic slapped cheek appearance is seen on the face. Which of the following describes the genetic makeup of the pathogen?
questions.solution:
Based on the clinical presentation and the classical slapped cheek appearance, the condition is due to Parvovirus infection also known as erythema infectiosum or fifth disease. Parvovirus is made up of single-stranded DNA.

Erythema infectiosum:

  • Also known as Fifth disease
  • Incubation period: 4-14 days
  • Rash appears first on cheeks (slapped cheek appearance), spreads to the trunk

Clinical features:

  • Child will be febrile, non-toxic with a nonspecific prodrome
  • Transient aplastic anemia, myocarditis
  • Petechial/ purpuric skin eruptions: Papular purpuric “gloves and socks” syndrome (PPGSS)
  • Arthritis and arthralgia
  • Primary maternal infection is associated with non-immune fetal hydrops and intrauterine fetal demise.

Related Pearl: Viral infections associated with rash

Viral infection  Rash characteristics 
Chickenpox Appears 1st day of fever, centripetal, pleomorphic, dewdrops on rose petal appearance
Measles Appears on the 4th day over the face and retroauricular origin
Rubella Rash on day 1 over the face

Erythema infectiosum

 Rash on cheeks (slapped cheek appearance), moves to trunk and extremities
Exanthem subitum Macules or maculopapular rash
Infectious mononucleosis Associated with maculopapular rash

questions.text:
In the case of a 50-year-old HIV positive man, select the best option among the following:

A: Plasma HIV RNA levels predict the long-term clinical outcome B: CD4 lymphocyte counts predict the short-term clinical outcome

choices.text: Both A and B are true
A is true and B is false
B is true and A is false
Both A and B are false

questions.solution:
In a case of HIV, plasma HIV RNA levels are the best predictor for a long-term clinical outcome such as progression to AIDS and CD4 lymphocyte count is the best predictor for a short-term clinical outcome such as opportunistic infection.

Clinical correlate:

A single measurement of plasma viral load about 6 months after infection can predict the subsequent risk of developing AIDS in men several years later, in the absence of treatment. Also, it is important in assessing the effectiveness of ARTs.

questions.text: A brain autopsy findings of an HIV-positive woman with dementia is given below. Her medical records show that she had progressive weakness on the right side of the body. Which of the following is the most likely opportunistic co-infection in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with brain autopsy findings showing ballooned oligodendrocytes with nuclear inclusion bodies suggests progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML). It is caused by the JC virus.

PML is a fatal subacute progressive demyelinating disease. It is caused by the neurotrophic JC virus which belongs to the family polyomavirus. The virus preferentially infects oligodendrocytes, demyelination throughout the brain is its principal pathologic effect, but spares the spinal cord and optic nerves.

It is an opportunistic infection in immunocompromised individuals and patients receiving monoclonal antibodies (for multiple sclerosis) and biological agents.

Patients present with insidious onset and steady progression of focal symptoms that include visual deficits (typically homonymous hemianopia), mental impairment (dementia, confusion, personality change), hemiparesis, and ataxia.

Diagnosis is with the help of an MRI brain which shows single or multiple confluent demyelinating lesions in the periventricular white matter. Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) of the CSF is highly specific for the detection of JC virus in patients with PML.

No effective therapy is available for PML, but a 5-HT2a receptor antagonist mirtazapine is found to have beneficial effects.

The image given below shows a brain biopsy of a PML patient showing ballooned oligodendrocytes (blue arrow) with SV40 positive nuclear inclusion bodies (red arrow) and, enlarged astrocytes (yellow arrow) indicative of JC virus infection.

Other options:

Option A: Coxsackievirus B2 causes aseptic meningitis. Patients present with fever, malaise, headache, nausea, and abdominal pain. It may progress to mild muscle weakness.

Option B: Toxoplasma gondii causes toxoplasmosis, especially in immunocompromised patients. It is usually associated with a history of consumption of undercooked meat. Patients present with fever, headache, and focal neurologic deficits. MRI shows ring-enhancing lesions in the brain.

Option C: Herpes simplex virus 2 (HSV 2) can cause neurological disease (meningitis or encephalitis) presenting with fever, focal neurological deficit, and seizures. It shows focal lesions (in the temporal region) on MRI. It is diagnosed by PCR testing of HSV DNA in the CSF sample.

Related Pearl: AIDS-defining opportunistic infections and neoplasm

Infections:

  • Protozoal and helminthic infections-
    • Cryptosporidiosis or Isosporiasis (cystoisosporiasis) - Chronic intestinal
    • Toxoplasmosis (pneumonia or CNS infection)
  • Fungal infections-
    • Candidiasis (esophageal, tracheal, or pulmonary)
    • Cryptococcosis (CNS infection)
    • Coccidioidomycosis (disseminated)
    • Pneumocystosis (pneumonia or disseminated infection)
    • Histoplasmosis (disseminated)
  • Bacterial infections-
    • Mycobacteriosis (“atypical,” e.g., Mycobacterium avium-intracellulare) disseminated or extrapulmonary
    • Mycobacterium tuberculosis (pulmonary or extrapulmonary)
    • Nocardiosis (pneumonia, meningitis, disseminated)
    • Salmonella infections, disseminated
  • Viral infections-
    • Cytomegalovirus (pulmonary, intestinal, retinitis, or CNS infections)
    • Herpes simplex virus (localized or disseminated infection)
    • Varicella-zoster virus (localized or disseminated infection)
    • Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy

Neoplasms:

  • Kaposi sarcoma
  • Primary lymphoma of brain
  • Invasive cancer of uterine cervix

questions.text: A patient presented with the skin lesion shown in the image below. Then, a swab from the lesion was examined under microscopy and is also given below. Which of the following is the most probable causative organism?
questions.solution:
Based on the clinical presentation of the skin lesion with bullous presentation and histology showing thick-walled yeast with broad-based budding, the most probable agent is Blastomyces dermatitis.

Image shows Histoplasma capsulatum - Oval cysts (intracellular in macrophages):

Image shows Coccidioides immitis (Spherules containing endospores):

Image shows Paracoccidioides brasilensis (large budding yeast- Captains wheel appearance):

questions.text: The given image shows the life cycle of which of the following organisms?
questions.solution:
The given life cycle is of Cryptococcus species – Cryptococcus neoformans (common) and Cryptococcus gattii.

Clinical correlate:

  • In immunocompromised patients, both species cause cryptococcosis by inhalation of yeast cells or spores. From the lungs, these yeasts migrate to the CNS and other organs.
  • Cryptococcal meningitis is an AIDS-defining opportunistic fungal CNS infection that generally occurs in untreated patients, with CD4+ T cell counts <100/μL.
  • The CSF profile may show modest elevations in WBC or protein levels and a decrease in glucose. The CSF opening pressure is usually elevated.
  • The diagnosis is made by identification of yeast cells in CSF with India ink stain or by the detection of Cryptococcal antigen using latex agglutination(CrAg).

Treatment:

  • Induction: IV or Liposomal Amphotericin B with Flucytosine for at least 2 weeks, continuing with amphotericin alone ideally until the CSF culture turns negative.
  • Maintenance: Oral Fluconazole until the CD4+ T cell count has increased to >200 cells/μL for 6 months in response to cART.
  • Primary prophylaxis: Oral Fluconazole when CD4+ T cell count is <100/μL.

The following image shows Cryptococcus neoformans stained using India ink. A thick capsule is seen around the yeast cell.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding the organism given in the image below?

choices.text: It is an uncommon pathogenic protozoan in the human intestines
Cysts can survive in water for upto 3 months
It has hooks on the ventral surface to adhere to the intestines
The cysts contain 2 nuclei in mature form

questions.solution:
The image shows the trophozoite form of Giardia lamblia and the cysts can survive in water for up to 3 months.

Other options:

  • It is the only common pathogenic protozoan in the human intestines.
  • The trophozoites are heart-shaped and have a concave sucking disk on the ventral surface to adhere to the intestines.
  • The cysts are ellipsoid, thick-walled and contain 4 nuclei in mature form and 2 nuclei in the immature form.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms is transmitted by black fly?
questions.solution:
Onchocerca volvulus is transmitted by the black fly.

The vector black fly (genus-Simulium) breeds in fast-flowing rivers; and therefore, the disease is most common along the course of rivers. Hence, the name ‘river blindness’.

 

The following image shows life cycle of Onchocerca volvulus:

questions.text: Which of the following is the difference between T solium and T saginata?

choices.text: Adult worms of T saginata are commonly symptomatic
Cysticerci in various tissues happens only in T saginata
Humans are not an intermediate host for T saginata

questions.solution:
Humans are not an intermediate host for T saginata. But can be an intermediate host for Taenia solium.

Adult worms of both T. solium and T. saginata are commonly asymptomatic.

Cysterceri occurring in various tissues happens only in T. solium and causes most of the symtoms related to these infections.

Related Pearl: Difference between T. solium and T. saginata

Properties

Taenia solium

Taenia saginata

Common name

Pork tapeworm

Beef tapeworm

Definitive host

Human

Human

Intermediate

host

Pig/Humans

Cow

 Disease 

Taeniasis and cysticercosis

Taeniasis only

Transmission

Infection is common among those eating raw or insufficiently cooked measly pork containing the cysticerci.

Human beings are infected through the eating of undercooked beef containing the cysticerci (“measly” beef)

Size of adult worm

2-3 m

5-10m

Scolex

The scolex head is globular in outline and has four circular suckers.

The head is provided with the rostellum armed with double row of alternating large and small hooklets. The rostellar hooklets are shaped like daggers or Arabian poniards (armed scolex)

The scolex (“head”) is quadrate in outline and has four circular suckers.

Rostellum and hooklets are absent (i.e. unarmed scolex)

 Proglottid 

Less than 1000 proglottids are present.

The gravid uterus consists of a median longitudinal stem with 5-13 compound lateral branches on each side

The gravid segments are expelled passively, in chains of 5-6 at a time, and not singly.

T. solium may produce 50,000 eggs per proglottid.

The number of proglottids varies from 1000- 2000.

The gravid uterus consists of a central longitudinal stem with 15-30 lateral branches on each side; these in turn sub-branch leaving practically no space in between.

The gravid segments are expelled singly T. saginata may produce up to 100,000 eggs per proglottid.

 Eggs 

The eggs are about 30-35 micrometers in diameter and are bile stained.

The internal oncosphere contains six refractile hooks.

The eggs do not float in the saturated solution of NaCl.

T.solium and T. saginata eggs are morphologically indistinguishable.

Same as T. solium.

Taenia solium and Taenia saginata eggs are morphologically indistinguishable.

 Eggs (Infectious nature)

Infectious to humans (Human who ingested food contaminated with the egg of Taenia solium may develop cysticercosis)

Eggs of Taenia saginata are not infectious. Humans who ingest T. saginata eggs do not develop cysticercosis.

questions.text: Cassoni's test is based on which type of hypersensitivity reaction?
questions.solution:
Casoni’s test is a type I hypersensitivity reaction used in the diagnosis of hydatid disease.

  • It involves the intradermal injection of 0.25 ml of sterilized fluid from hydatid cysts/human cyst and sterilized by Seitz filtration on the forearm and an equal volume of saline injected on the other forearm.
  • Observations are made for next 30 mins and after 1 to 2 days.
  • A wheal response occurring at the injection site within 20 minutes is considered positive.

Delayed hypersensitivity reaction (Type IV):

  • Tuberculin skin test, the indurated skin rash is caused by CD4-positive helper T cells and macrophages that are attracted to the injection site.
  • Frei test is done to identify lymphogranuloma venereum.
  • Montenegro test is a delayed hypersensitivity test for cutaneous leishmaniasis.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presented to the ENT OPD with a history of sore throat and fever for the past 4 days. On examination of the throat, a grey patch was noticed (as shown below) that was found to be adherent and when removed left a bleeding surface. Which of the given statements regarding the condition is true?

choices.text: The membrane is due to the formation of a biofilm
Myocarditis is one of the distant complications of the disease
Antitoxin should be administered after laboratory confirmation
A positive Besredka test confirms the diagnosis

questions.solution:
The given clinical history and image are suggestive of oropharyngeal diphtheria.

The toxin affects distant sites causing myocarditis, neuritis, and acute tubular necrosis.

Other Options:

  • Local inflammation, bacterial proliferation and toxin-mediated tissue necrosis cause formation of the adherent dirty gray pseudo-membrane.
  • The antitoxin should be administered as soon as a clinical diagnosis of respiratory diphtheria is made. Delayed administration of the antitoxin is associated with the risk of myocarditis as it neutralizes only the circulating toxin and is ineffective against the intracellular toxin.
  • Laboratory confirmation is not required when there is a high degree of clinical suspicion.
  • Prior to the administration of the antitoxin, due to a risk of serious allergic reaction to horse serum, Besredka’s sensitization test should be performed in all patients with a probable diagnosis of diphtheria (It is not a diagnostic test).

Related Pearl: Causes of Myocarditis

Causes of myocarditis include:

  • Infections:
    1. Viruses (e.g., coxsackievirus, ECHO, influenza, HIV, cytomegalovirus)
    2. Chlamydiae (e.g.,  Chlamydophila psittaci)
    3. Rickettsiae (e.g., Rickettsia typhi, typhus fever)
    4. Bacteria (e.g., Corynebacterium diphtheriae, Neisseria meningococcus)
    5. Borrelia (Lyme disease)
    6. Fungi (e.g., Candida spp.)
    7. Protozoa (e.g., Trypanosoma cruzi [Chagas disease], toxoplasmosis)
    8. Helminths (e.g., trichinosis)
    9. Poststreptococcal (rheumatic fever)
    10. Immune-Mediated Reactions
    11. Systemic lupus erythematosus
  • Drug hypersensitivity (e.g., methyldopa, sulfonamides)
  • Transplant rejection
  • Sarcoidosis
  • Giant cell myocarditis
  • Unknown

Morphology:

The heart in myocarditis may appear normal or dilated. Some hypertrophy may be present depending on disease duration. Mural thrombi may be present. Active myocarditis is characterized by an interstitial inflammatory infiltrate associated with focal myocyte necrosis. Endomyocardial biopsies are diagnostic in some cases, but not when the inflammation is focal or patchy.

The morphological pattern of myocarditis in certain conditions:

  • Hypersensitivity myocarditis: Interstitial infiltrates with a high proportion of eosinophils
  • Giant-cell myocarditis: Multinucleate giant cells (fused macrophages)
  • Chagas disease: Scattered myofibers by trypanosomes.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the anatomical landmark shown in the image below is true?

choices.text: The base is formed posteriorly by the socket for the second molar
This area drains into level III cervical lymph nodes
Most common malignancy in this region is squamous cell carcinoma
Malignancies occurring in this region are slow growing and have a better prognosis

questions.solution:
The area marked is the retromolar trigone region. 90% of the oral cavity malignancies are histologically squamous cell carcinoma. More than 95% of the malignancies occurring in retromolar trigone are SCC.

Other Options:

  • The boundaries of this trigone include temporal crest medially, anterior border of the ramus of mandible laterally and the base is formed by the socket for the third molar (not second molar).
  • The retromandibular trigone drains into the superior-deep cervical nodes (level II) (and not level III – middle deep cervical nodes which main drain the hypopharynx and larynx).
  • The malignancies occurring in the retromolar trigone are comparatively aggressive and often show local infiltration and have a poorer prognosis compared to the malignancies elsewhere in the oral cavity.

questions.text: Which of the following nerves is most commonly involved in nasopharyngeal carcinoma?
questions.solution:
The most common nerves affected in nasopharyngeal carcinoma in descending order of frequency are CN V > CN VI > CN IX > CN X > CN XII.

Nasopharyngeal carcinoma:

  • Nasopharyngeal carcinoma is also called Guangdong tumor.
  • Commonest site of origin of nasopharyngeal carcinoma is the fossa of Rosenmüller.
  • Epstein–Barr Virus (EBV) is closely associated with nasopharyngeal cancer.
  • Presenting symptoms and signs of nasopharyngeal cancer in order of frequency are
    • Cervical lymphadenopathy (most common) (60–90%)
    • Hearing loss
    • Nasal obstruction
    • Epistaxis
    • Cranial nerve palsies -Cranial nerves V and VI are the most commonly involved among all the cranial nerves. (V more than VI)

 Nasopharyngeal cancer can cause:

  • Conductive deafness (eustachian tube block)
  • Ipsilateral temporoparietal/facial neuralgia (involvement of CN V) and
  • Palatal paralysis (CN X)

This is collectively called Trotter’s triad.

Radiotherapy is the treatment of choice for nasopharyngeal cancer.

  • Stage I and II are treated by radiotherapy alone.
  • Stage III and IV require concomitant radiation and chemotherapy or radiation followed by chemotherapy.

questions.text: Consider the following statements about transoral laser microsurgery (TLM) A. Laryngeal cancer with an exophytic pattern of growth with only minimal invasion to the underlying lamina propria is an ideal candidate for TLM. B. TLM is used to remove the tumor mass “en-bloc”. The true statement(s) is/are:

choices.text: None of the given statements are true

questions.solution:
Only A, laryngeal cancer with an exophytic pattern of growth with only minimal invasion to the underlying lamina propria is an ideal candidate for TLM, is true.

Transoral laser microsurgery (TLM)

  • It is a surgical treatment strategy for primary cancers of the mouth, pharynx, and larynx. The instrument of excision is generally a CO2 Laser beam.
  • Piecemeal removal is a distinguishing feature of TLM.

It can be used in the treatment of the following:

  • Very early laryngeal cancer (exophytic cancers with only minimal invasion into the underlying lamina propria) - They are an ideal application for laser photoablation by means of TLM.
  • Early laryngeal cancer (glottic malignancies that fall within the purview of an open supraglottic laryngectomy; Supraglottic malignancies falling within the boundaries of supraglottic laryngectomy).

Advanced laryngeal malignancies cannot be treated by TLM mainly because reconstruction is required in these cases. TLM also does not have a role in the treatment of very advanced laryngeal cancer (like a massive horseshoe glottic/supraglottic cancer with involvement of bilateral ventricles and bilateral muscular vocal cords).

questions.text: The complication(s) of neck dissection include:
questions.solution:
All of the above mentioned are complications of neck dissection.

Complications of neck dissection include

  • Air Leaks
  • Infections
  • Bleeding
  • Facial, cerebral edema: In synchronous bilateral radical neck dissections, ligation of bilateral Internal Jugular Veins (IJVs) can lead to development of facial and cerebral edema.
  • Chylous Fistula
  • Carotid Artery rupture: most common lethal complication
  • Blindness: possible etiology suggested is intraoperative hypotension and severe venous distension during bilateral neck dissection leading to intraorbital optic nerve infarction.

questions.text: A 45-year-old alcoholic presents with an episode of vomiting bright red blood. His vitals are stable. A UGI endoscopy revealed a tear in the distal esophagus as shown below. Probable diagnosis and the probable origin of the bleed are respectively:

choices.text: Boerhaave Syndrome and left gastric artery
Boerhaave Syndrome and short gastric artery
Mallory Weiss Tear and left gastric artery
Mallory Weiss Tear and short gastric artery

questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis for the above-mentioned clinical presentation and the upper GI endoscopy finding is Mallory Weiss tear (not Boerhaave Syndrome as the patient’s vitals are stable).

The arteries supplying the distal esophagus are ascending branches from the left gastric artery (not short gastric artery), and thus, it is the origin for the bleed in this case.

Mallory Weiss Syndrome:

  • It is a common cause for upper gastrointestinal bleeding due to the presence of longitudinal superficial mucosal lacerations (Mallory-Weiss tears).
  • They occur primarily in the lower esophagus close to the gastroesophageal junction.
  • It mainly occurs in patients with repetitive forceful retching and vomiting and is associated with heavy alcohol intake.
  • Concurrent presence of portal hypertension with esophageal varices and hiatal hernia in patients with Mallory Weiss syndrome is not uncommon.

Boerhaave syndrome:

  • It is a transmural perforation of the esophagus (while Mallory Weiss tear is a mucosal tear).
  • Clinical presentation:
    • Mackler's Triad:
      • Vomiting
      • lower thoracic pain
      • subcutaneous emphysema
    • Other classical findings include deranged vitals tachypnea, tachycardia, fever, and hypotension.
    • Diaphoresis and abdominal rigidity can also be present

questions.text: All of the following are complications of posterior nasal packing except:
questions.solution:
Pharyngeal bursitis (Tornwaldt's disease) is not a complication of posterior nasal packing.

It is the inflammation of the pharyngeal bursa (Tornwaldt's cyst/Luschka's bursa), which is an embryological remnant of the notochord.

Some of the complications of posterior nasal packing include:

  • Toxic Shock Syndrome
  • Sinusitis
  • Periorbital Cellulitis
  • Otitis Media,
  • Nasal Septal Necrosis

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presented with a history of ear discharge in the left ear for the past 4 weeks, deep-seated ear pain for the past 1 week, and diplopia for the past 2 days. What is the most probable diagnosis in this scenario?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Gradenigo’s syndrome, which occurs secondary to petrous apicitis. This is a complication of otitis media. 

The triad of Gradenigo's syndrome consists of:

  • Ipsilateral abducens nerve palsy (6th nerve palsy) - external rectus palsy
  • Deep ear/facial pain  (5th nerve involvement)
  • Persistent ear discharge (otitis media)

The incidence of this syndrome has reduced with the advent of antibiotics.

Option A-  Following acute coalescent mastoiditis the pus breaks through the bony wall between the mastoid antrum and the external meatus and forms Luc's abscess. The swelling can burst into the meatus causing otorrhea.

Options B and C- Nasopharyngeal carcinoma and trigeminal schwannoma can present with cranial nerve palsy, but they do not follow the above clinical course.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presented with a speech disorder and a history of recurrent bouts of secretory otitis media in the past. On examination, he was found to have a bifid uvula and a short soft palate with adenoid hypertrophy. The patient underwent adenoidectomy. The most specific speech disorder expected in this patient postoperatively is:

choices.text: Rhinolalia clausa due to postoperative nasopharyngeal stenosis
Rhinolalia aperta due to postoperative velopharyngeal insufficiency
Rhinolalia clausa due to postoperative velopharyngeal insufficiency
Rhinolalia aperta due to postoperative nasopharyngeal stenosis

questions.solution:
Rhinolalia aperta due to postoperative velopharyngeal insufficiency is the most specific postoperative complication in this case.

Preoperatively, the patient initially presents with a speech disorder, most probably, rhinolalia clausa (hypo-nasality) due to adenoid hypertrophy. Rhinilalia clausa is the lack of nasal resonance for words that are normally resonated in the nasal cavity such as m, n, and ng. It occurs due to blockage of the nose or nasopharynx. 

Postoperatively, the patient with a history of bifid uvula and short soft palate (significant of submucous cleft palate) is likely to develop rhinolalia aperta (hypernasality). In this condition, words that have little resonance, are resonated in the nose. This occurs because the nasopharynx cannot be cut off from the oropharynx or when there is abnormal communication between the oral and nasal cavities. The presence of a submucous cleft palate is a contraindication for adenoidectomy as it can lead to velopharyngeal insufficiency.

Adenoids Cleft of the soft palate

questions.text: Characteristic Pure tone audiometry finding “Acoustic Dip” in noise-induced hearing loss (NIHL) is found at which frequency?
questions.solution: In a patient with NIHL the midfrequency range is involved, primarily 3–6 kHz, with the classical 4000 Hz (4 kHz) dip in the audiogram, with little or no loss below 2 kHz (This audiometry finding is known as 4-kHz notch/acoustic dip/boiler’s notch/Boilermaker’s disease).

questions.text: Postmortem urine sample positive for dimethyl bipyridinium dichloride is indicative of:
questions.solution:
Urine sample positive for dimethyl bipyridinium dichloride is indicative of Paraquat poisoning. Paraquat dichloride is used as a herbicide.

Toxicity can occur via ingestion >> inhalation. The estimated minimum lethal dose is 1 g.

Post-mortem findings include:

  • Superficial erosions in lip, mouth, pharynx, and esophagus
  • Liver: Mottled fatty liver; Histopathology: Centrilobular necrosis
  • Lungs: Proliferative damage to lungs, stiff lung, diffuse pulmonary edema, and hemorrhages.
  • Blood and Urine: can show paraquat concentration for a long period (more than 2-3 weeks) after ingestion.

Other options:

  • Sarin is an inhalational organophosphorus compound used as nerve gas.
  • Picric acid poisoning leads to yellow staining of tissues (skin, lungs, etc.) and port-wine colored urine.
  • Organic acid (eg. oxalic acid) poisoning: It presents with mucosal erosions, but urinary excretion persists only up to 24 hours (unlike paraquat poisoning which lasts for up to 2-3 weeks).

questions.text: Identify the toxic component present in the plant shown in the image below.
questions.solution:
The toxic component of the plant(Cerebra odollam) shown in the image is odollin

Identifying features:

  • Dark-green, fleshy, lanceolate leafs
  • White (Jasmine-like) flowers
  • Globular dark green fruit resembling mango

The active components of Cerbera odollam are cardiac glycosides including cerberin, cerberoside, odollin, odolotoxin, thevetin, cerapain.

Other options:

  • Nerifolin: it is potent toxin found in yellow oleander (Cerbera thevetia).
  • Oleandrin: it is a potent cardiac glycoside found in white oleander (Nerium odorum).
  • Hyoscine: also called Scopolamine, a toxic component present in Datura plants (especially seeds).

Yellow oleander:

White oleander:

questions.text: Which of the following diagnoses have the hematology findings given below?
questions.solution:
The findings present in the above hematology slide are basophilic stippling  (punctate basophilia) with Cabot’s ring . They are features seen in chronic lead poisoning (also called plumbism or saturnism).

Clinical features include:

  • A - Anemia with basophilic stippling
  • B - Burtonian line (blue stippled line on gums)
  • C - Constipation and colic (abdominal pain)
  • D - Drop (wrist and foot drop) due to neuropathy
  • E - Encephalopathy (Mostly seen in infants presenting with severe ataxia, vomiting, lethargy, stupor, convulsion, and coma)
  • F - Facial pallor -earliest sign

Other Options:

  • Minamata disease: Chronic mercury poisoning can show anemia secondary to GI hemorrhage.
  • Chronic iron toxicity: In severe cases, can present with leucocytosis and anemia (due to blood loss).
  • Arsenic poisoning: Can induce microcytic hypochromic anemia or hemolytic anemia.

questions.text: In which of the scenarios mentioned below, a shotgun entry wound is encircled by a Maltese cross pattern abrasion?

choices.text: Close range shot fired between 30 cm and 1 m
Close range shot fired less than 30 cm distance from target
Short range shot fired 1 to 2 m from the target

questions.solution:
Maltese cross/shotcup petal abrasions in shotgun entry wounds produced by a close-range shot fired between 30 to 90 cm.

Other options:

Various entry wounds in shotgun injury:

  • Contact shot over bone: produces a split wound.
  • Contact shot over soft tissue:
  • Close range <30 cm: Circular wound with, singing of tissues surrounding the wound.
  • Close range 30 cm to 1 m: Slightly ragged margin (rat-hole wound); the plastic cup type wad opens up between 30–60 cm leading to the four petals sticking out producing the Maltese cross pattern of abrasion encircling the entrance wound.
  • Short-range 1–2 m: irregular lacerated edges are produced without burning, blackening or tattooing.
  • Intermediate-range 2–4 m: Satellite pellet holes,
  • At 3 m distance: Central aperture is surrounded by separate pellet entry wounds in an area of 8–10 cm diameter.
  • Long-range (> 4m): Individual pellets produce separate entry wounds.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a test for criminal responsibility?
questions.solution:
Ashley's rule also called the “149 rule”, is used to determine the gender using the length of the sternum in European skeleton. Male sternum measures more than 149 mm and female sternum measures less than 149 mm. This rule, however, does not apply for Indian sterna.

The tests to determine criminal responsibility include:

  • McNaughten’s rule (included in the Sec. 84 of IPC)
  • Durham rule
  • Curren’s rule
  • The Irresistible Impulse Test (New Hampshire Doctrine)
  • The American Law Institute (ALI) Test
  • The Federal Rule

Related Pearl: Criminal Responsibilities

BNS section

Previous IPC Section

Deals with

Related Pearl: BNS section 22, M'Naghten's rule

M'Naghten's rule, BNS 22 (Previously - Section 84 IPC):  Criminal responsibility of the insane.

Nothing is an offence which is done by a person who, at the time of doing it, by reason of unsoundness of mind, is incapable of knowing the nature of the act, or that he is doing what is either wrong or contrary to law.

questions.text: In 1970, the World Medical Association adopted a resolution on therapeutic abortion known as:
questions.solution:
The Declaration of Oslo (1970) is related to therapeutic abortion.

Other options:

  • Declaration of Alma-Ata: Identified primary health care as the key to the attainment of the goal of Health for All
  • Declaration of Tokyo: related to torture and other degradation
  • Declaration of Helsinki: concerned with Human experimentation.

Related Pearl: Health-related International Declarations:

  1. Declaration of Alma-Ata (1978): Identified primary health care as the key to the attainment of the goal of Health for All.
  2. Ottawa Charter for Health Promotion (1986): The aim of the conference was to continue to  achieve the objectives of the World Health Organization (WHO) Health for all by the year 2000.

3. Declaration of Oslo (1970): Related to therapeutic abortion.

4. Declaration of Tokyo (1975): Guidelines for medical doctors concerning torture and other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment in relation to detention and imprisonment. (T – Tokyo – Torture)

5. Declaration of Helsinki (1975): Related to human experimentation. (H – Helsinki – Human experimentation)

6. Declaration of Geneva (1948): Most recent amendment was done on October 14, 2017 in Chicago. It gives the modern version of the 2500-year-old Hippocratic Oath which laid down the fundamental principles of medical ethics that any physician should follow.

7. Declaration of Malta (1991, revised in 1992): Related to hunger strikes.

8. Declaration of Lisbon: Related to rights of the patients like right to information, confidentiality, dignity, freedom of choice etc.

9. Declaration of Sydney on human death: It stated that the determination of death “will be based on clinical judgment, supplemented if necessary by a number of diagnostic aids”, emphasising the EEG. Nonetheless, it asserted that “the overall judgment of the physician” could not be replaced by any ancillary test.

The statement also recommended that two or more physicians should make the diagnosis of death when organs were removed for transplantation.

10. Declaration of Istanbul: To address the urgent and growing problems of organ sales, transplant tourism and trafficking in organ donors in the context of the global shortage of organs.

11. Declaration of Taipei: Related to ethical considerations regarding health databases and biobanks.

questions.text: As a part of questioning a criminal, the police beat him on the soles of his feet using a rod. What is this form of torture known as?
questions.solution:
Falanga (also known as Falaka or Bastinado), is a method of torture that involves repeatedly striking the soles of the feet with an object such as a truncheon, iron rod, cable, bamboo cane, wooden pole, or rifle butt.

Other options:

Telefono: This form of torture involves repeated slapping of the sides of the head (over the ears). It may result in rupture of the tympanic membranes or damage to the inner ear.

Chepuwa: This form of torture involves tying the thighs and legs very tightly with bamboo sticks to induce severe pain.

Ghotna: This form of torture involves rolling a wooden log or an iron rod up and down the thigh while the log is being weighted by one or two individuals standing on it.

questions.text: Based on the pattern of postmortem staining shown in the image below, which of the following positions was the body in at the time of death?
questions.solution:
The postmortem staining/lividity in the image provided is characteristic of hanging as it is more marked in the legs, hands, and external genitalia.

Postmortem staining is usually seen in the dependent parts of the body wherein there is gravitational pooling of blood. 

Medicolegal importance - Postmortem staining and its fixation can be helpful to ascertain the time since death. It can also be used to estimate the body's position at the time of death and if the body has been relocated since. 

Other options:

Option A- In supine position (shown below), postmortem staining is limited to the neck and entire back except for the points of contact between the body and the ground (occipital areas, scapulae, buttocks, calves, and heels). The absence of lividity in these areas, due to external compression of blood vessels, is termed contact pallor.

 

Option B- In the prone position, postmortem staining is marked on the anterior surface of the body associated with the presence of Tardieu spots. 

Option C- In a body lying on the side, postmortem staining will is marked on that particular side due to the pooling of blood in the dependent parts.

questions.text: Which of the following component of a typical embalming fluid controls its pH?
questions.solution:
Sodium chloride is the component of embalming fluid that controls pH.

questions.text: Klismaphilia represents sexual gratification obtained by:
questions.solution:
Klismaphilia is the sexual gratification obtained by the use of enemas.

Other options:

  • Frotteurism: Sexual gratification obtained via contact with another person.
  • Undinism: Sexual gratification obtained via urinating on the sexual partner.
  • Coprolagnia: Sexual excitement associated with the sight or smell of excrement.

Related Pearl: Paraphilic disorders

DSM-5 includes eight specific paraphilic disorders:

Disorder Description
Exhibitionistic disorder Sexual arousal from exposing their genitals to a stranger
Pedophilic disorder Sexual arousal to a prepubescent individual, generally 13 years of age or younger
Voyeuristic disorder Sexual arousal from observing other's sexual activities
Sexual sadism disorder Sexual arousal upon inflicting suffering or humiliation  
Frotteuristic disorder Sexual arousal by touching or rubbing against a non-consenting person
Fetishistic disorder Sexual arousal from the use of inert objects, such as female
undergarments
Transvestic disorder Sexual arousal from cross-dressing
Sexual masochism Sexual arousal from being humiliated, beaten, bound, or made to suffer

As per ICD-11, the first five are included under paraphilic disorders. Two other subclasses in addition to this are:

  • Other paraphilic disorders involving non-consenting individuals (e.g., arousal patterns involving corpses or animals)
  • Paraphilic disorders involving solitary behaviour or consenting individuals (e.g., asphyxophilia, fetishism, fetishistic transvestism).

questions.text: The convergence projection theory of referred pain states:

choices.text: The somatic and visceral pain fibres converge on the same second-order neurons
The second order neurons project into the anterior thalamus and somatosensory cortex
The somatic and visceral pain fibres are carried by their respective first order neurons which converge in the somatosensory cortex

questions.solution:
The convergence projection theory of referred pain states:

The somatic and visceral pain fibers converge on the same second-order neurons in the ipsilateral dorsal horn, which in-turn projects into the ventral posterior (not anterior) thalamus and then to the somatosensory cortex.

When the visceral stimulus is prolonged, the somatic fiber activity is facilitated. The somatic nerve endings stimulate the second-order neurons and thus, the brain is unable to distinguish whether the stimulus is from the viscera or from the area of referral.

questions.text: Which of the following is used for directly measuring plasma volume?
questions.solution:
T–1824, also called Evan’s Blue Dye is used in the direct measurement of plasma volume among the given options.

questions.text: A carpenter was hammering a nail into a door. Accidentally, he struck his left thumb with the hammer. He developed a lasting, throbbing pain. What is the type of nerve fibre carrying this pain and its rate of conduction, respectively?
questions.solution:
The throbbing pain experienced after a strike with a hammer on the nail of the left thumb is a deep throbbing pain (slow, dull aching, and second pain) and it is carried by C – fibres (conducting at a rate of 0.5–2 m/s). (Neurotransmitters – Glutamate and Substance P).

Other Options:

Aδ fibre conducts “fast, first pain” at a rate of 12–35 m/s. (Neurotransmitter – Glutamate)

questions.text: Nifedipine is given for the following conditions: Trismus (A), colicky pain due to distal ureteric calculus (B) and pain due to Prinzmetal Angina (C) respectively. In which patient(s) can we expect symptomatic relief?
questions.solution:
Patients B and C present with ureteric colic and vasospastic angina, which are due to spasms of smooth muscles that can be relieved by nifedipine (calcium channel blocker).

Patient A presents with Trismus, which is due to the spasm of the muscles of mastication (skeletal muscle); calcium channel blocker like nifedipine has little/no effect on skeletal muscles.

Principle: The mechanism of skeletal muscle contraction is mainly the release of calcium from the sarcoplasmic reticulum, while in the mechanism of smooth muscle contraction, the source of the calcium is from the extracellular fluid. Ca2+ ions are transported via calcium channels into the smooth muscle cell during the action potential along the concentration gradient. Thus, calcium channel blockers inhibit the contraction of only smooth muscles and not skeletal muscles.

questions.text: Maximum urine-to-blood pH gradient is seen in which part of the nephron?
questions.solution:
Maximum urine-to-blood pH gradient is seen in the DCT.

The H+ ions are secreted in the PCT (Proximal Convoluted Tubule) via Na-H exchanger by primary active transport. The secreted H+ combines with HCO3- to form H2CO3 which dissociates to form H2O and CO2 in the presence of carbonic anhydrase. Thus, the secreted H+ has little effect on luminal pH.

The distal nephron (distal convoluted tubule and collecting duct) reabsorbs that portion of the filtered HCO3- escaping proximal reabsorption, titrates luminal buffers, and lowers urine pH. Thus, even though, DCT has little capacity to secrete H+ ions, it is the segment where the urinary-to-blood pH gradient is significant.

questions.text: A histology slide of the adrenal gland is provided below. Which is the hormone(s) secreted from A?
questions.solution:
Aldosterone and Corticosterone are secreted from Zona Glomerulosa.

While the active enzymatic mechanism for aldosterone biosynthesis is limited to zona glomerulosa, corticosterone is secreted from all the three (A, B, C (marked in the image)) cortical zones of the adrenal gland.

Labels:

A – Zona Glomerulosa (Just underneath the eosinophilic connective tissue) – Aldosterone synthesis is limited to this layer

B – Zona Fasciculata (Inbetween Zona glomerulosa and reticularis) – enzymatic mechanisms for both cortisol and sex hormones present

C – Zona Reticularis (Cells arranged in the form of irregular cords giving rise to the reticular pattern) – enzymatic mechanisms for both cortisol and sex hormones present

D – Adrenal Medulla – Produces Catecholamines: Norepinephrine, Epinephrine, and Dopamine

questions.text: Circus movement in cardiac conduction is seen in
questions.solution:
Paroxysmal arrhythmias such as reentrant tachyarrhythmia can be caused due to a defect in conduction that permits a wave of excitation to propagate continuously within a closed circuit (termed circus movement also called echo/reciprocal beats).

Initiation of such a phenomenon can be due to

  1. Accessory pathways (e.g., the bundle of Kent in WPW syndrome).
  2. Transient unidirectional block (prolonged refractory period/prolonged repolarization time).

Wenckebach Phenomenon: It is the Mobitz Type 1 Second degree heart block; there is a progressive prolongation of the PR interval followed by loss of a QRS complex.

questions.text: Consider the following ECG finding: absent P wave; broad QRS complex with Tall and slender T waves. Assuming that the serum calcium levels are normal, what would be the estimated serum K+ level in this patient?

choices.text: The estimation is not possible without information regarding heart rate

questions.solution:
The ECG features are suggestive of hyperkalemia with the levels of potassium between 7-8.5 mEq/L.

The ECG shows no evidence of atrial activity; the QRS complex is broad and slurred and the QRS complex is widened to 0.2 s. The T waves are tall and slender. Further elevation of the plasma levels of potassium may cause ventricular tachycardia progressing towards ventricular fibrillation and cardiac arrest.

Other options:

  • Plasma potassium levels of 5.5 to 6.5 mEq/L can cause tall and slender T waves. But, PR interval and QRS complex are within normal limits.
  • Plasma potassium levels between 6.5 - 7.5 mEq/L can cause loss of P wave

questions.text: The principal neurotransmitter in type I (Glomus) cells of the carotid body is:
questions.solution:
The principal neurotransmitter in type I (Glomus) cells of the carotid body is dopamine. 

Carotid and aortic bodies contain type I cells/Glomus cells and type II cells. Like adrenal chromaffin cells, they contain dense-core granules containing catecholamines. They are excited in a hypoxic state and their principal transmitter is dopamine which stimulates the nerve endings via D2 receptors.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman diagnosed with tubercular meningitis has a peculiar breathing pattern as shown in the image below. What is the pattern of breathing?
questions.solution:
The pattern of breathing in the case presented is Biot's breathing.

Biot's breathing is a variant of Cheyne-Stokes breathing. It is characterized by periods of apnea that alternate irregularly with a series of breaths of equal depth that terminate abruptly. It is seen in meningitis.

Other Options:

Option B: Cheyne-Stokes Breathing: It is the period of apnea alternating with hyperapnea.It is seen in patients with cardiac failure, raised intracranial pressure, and brainstem lesions.

Option C: Kussmaul’s Breathing: It is a type of rapid, deep breathing. It is seen in cases of metabolic acidosis.

Option D: Pursed lip breathing is seen in COPD patients. The purpose of this breathing is to slow down the airflow during the exhalation to build up back pressure in the airway to avoid a sudden drop in intrapulmonary pressure resulting in alveolar and airway collapse.

questions.text: Persistent flexor spasm, profuse sweating, spontaneous defecation and urination, and hypertension following spinal trauma are components of:
questions.solution:
The phenomenon described is Mass reflex.

Mass reflex (also called autonomic dysreflexia/hyperreflexia), can occur following any Spinal Cord Injury (especially below T6 level), and an episode can be triggered essentially by any painful or irritating stimulus below the level of spinal cord injury. The most common stimulus being bladder distension (in 75-85% of cases). The effects of the reflex are as follows:

  • Major portion of the body’s skeletal muscles goes into flexor spasm.
  • Colon and bladder evacuate
  • Arterial pressures rise to maximum values (SBP sometimes well over 200 mmHg
  • Large areas of the body break out into profuse sweating.

Other Options:

  • Spinal shock: when the spinal cord is transected (commonly, above the level of T6 ), initially all cord functions including cord reflexes immediately become depressed to a point of total silence, often it is associated with arterial hypotension and bradycardia. After a few hours to weeks, the spinal neurons gradually regain their excitability. Since the above case has flexor spasm with hypertension and the level of lesion is below T6, it is not a spinal shock.
  • Cord righting reflex: When a spinal animal is laid on its side, it will make uncoordinated movements to try to raise itself to the standing position. This reflex is unrelated to the above case scenario.
  • Magnet reaction: The locus of the pressure on one side of the pad of foot causes extension in that direction, this effect is called the magnet reaction. This reaction helps keep an animal from falling to that side.

questions.text: What is the Broadmann Area of the region highlighted in the image below?
questions.solution:
The area highlighted in the image is the Premotor Cortex (Broadmann Area 6). Unlike the function of the Primary Motor Cortex (Broadmann Area 4) which directly initiates motor activity, the premotor cortex governs the pattern of movements made by an individual. It assists in the integration of sensory and motor information for the performance of an action.

Damage to this region can cause:

  • Apraxia (especially Limb-Kinetic Apraxia)
  • Deficits in contralateral fine motor control (not paralysis)
  • Difficulty in using sensory feedback for the control and performance of movements

Other Options:

  • Area 4 – Primary Motor cortex, just anterior to the central sulcus of Rolando
  • Area 3 – Primary Sensory Cortex, just posterior to the central sulcus of Rolando
  • Area 8 – Frontal Eye Field

questions.text: Which among the following acts via tyrosine kinase signalling?
questions.solution:
Somatomedin C (Insulin-like growth factor - 1) acts via tyrosine kinase signalling

All of the hormones below use tyrosine kinase signalling:

  • Fibroblast growth factor
  • Growth hormone
  • Insulin
  • Insulin-like growth factor – 1 (also called Somatomedin C)
  • Leptin
  • Prolactin
  • Vascular endothelial growth factor
  • Hepatocyte growth factor

Other Options:

  • Somatostatin acts via the cAMP second messenger system
  • Oxytocin and GHRH (Growth Hormone Releasing Hormone) act via Phospholipase C second messenger system.

questions.text: Which of the following isoforms of thyroid hormone receptor is found only in the brain?
questions.solution:
TRβ2 is found only in the brain.

There are 2 human TR genes: α receptor gene on Chr. 17; β receptor gene on Chr. 3; giving rise to 4 isoforms of thyroid hormone receptors: TRα1, TRα2, TRβ1, TRβ2.

TRα2 does not bind thyroid hormone due to its unique C terminus. It can antagonize the activity of the other subtypes by competitively binding to the T3 response elements.

questions.text: Gastrin is produced maximally from which part of the GIT?
questions.solution:
Gastrin is produced maximally from the G-cells in the antral portion of the gastric mucosa.

Gastrin exists in 3 forms containing 34, 17, and 14 amino acid residues called G34, G17, and G14 gastrins respectively. The G17 gastrin is the principal, most abundant form.

questions.text: The ferrous form is converted to ferric form in the basolateral aspect of the intestinal mucosal cell by which of the following?
questions.solution:
Hephaestin (Hp) present in the basolateral aspect of the intestinal mucosal cell converts Fe2+(ferrous) to Fe3+(ferric). Associated with ferroportin 1, Hephaestin facilitates the basolateral transport of iron but is not a transporter itself. Fe3+ is then transported in the plasma bound to transferrin.

Other Options:

  • Ferric Reductase (DCYTB): Converts dietary Fe3+ to absorbable Fe2+ in the apical/luminal aspect of the intestinal mucosal cell.
  • Divalent Metal Transporter 1 (DMT1): Transports Fe2+ from the intestinal lumen into the intestinal mucosal cell.
  • Ferroportin 1 (FPN1): Transports Fe2+ from the mucosal cell into the interstitial fluid and then into the plasma.

The below image depicts the process of iron absorption.

questions.text: Phase III of migratory motor complex is best described as:

choices.text: Period of irregular electrical and Mechanical Activity which does not propagate
Period of regular electrical activity lasting for about 5 minutes which does not propagate
Period of regular electrical activity which sweeps along the length of the intestine

questions.solution:
Phase III of the Migrating Motor Complex is best described as a period of regular electrical activity, lasting for about 5 minutes which sweeps along the length of the intestine.

Migrating motor complex:

It is a type of motility in intestine that occurs during fasting between periods of digestion.

  • They are initiated by motilin.
  • These cycles (MMC) migrate from stomach to the distal ileum at a rate of about 5 cm/min and occur at intervals of approximately 90-100 minutes.
  • They likely serve to clear the stomach and small intestine of luminal contents in preparation for the next meal.
  • Upon ingestion of a meal, secretion of motilin is suppressed and the MMC is abolished. The MMC resumes 90-120 minutes after a meal.
  • Each cycle of MMC has 3 phases
    • Phase I - quiescent period
    • Phase II - period of irregular electrical and mechanical activity, which doesn't propagate.
    • Phase III - ends with bursts of regular activity, propagated along the length of the intestine.

questions.text: Which of the following about clinical trials is incorrect?

choices.text: Phase I – Access efficacy and dosage
Phase II – In most cases drugs are first time introduced in patients
Phase III – Multisite trial involving thousands of patients
Phase IV – Look for adverse events and drug-drug interactions

questions.solution:
Phase I trial is done to access safety and tolerability. It is conducted mostly on healthy volunteers and rarely on patients with advanced or rare diseases.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is/are true in the given graph?

1 – Drug A has more potency and efficacy when compared to drug B
2 – Drug C has the same efficacy as Drug A
3 – Drug B and D have the same potency
4 – Drug D has more efficacy but less potency than drug C
questions.solution:
Statements 2 and 4 are true about the given dose-response curve. Drug C has the same efficacy as drug A. Drug D has more efficacy but has less potency than Drug C.

Potency is the dose or concentration of a drug required to produce 50% of the drug’s maximal effect. The more the curve is on the left in a dose-response curve (DRC), the greater is its potency. 

Efficacy is defined as the maximum effect produced by the drug and is determined by the peak of the curve. It reflects the capacity of the drug to bind a receptor and produce a cellular response.

In the above graph order of potency is A>B>C>D. Drugs A and C have same efficacy, and drug B and D have the same efficacy.

The slope of the DRC also has significance. A steep slope implies that a moderate increase in dose markedly increases the response. Thus, for such drugs, the dose needs individualization. A flat slope implies that over a wide dose range, only a little increase in response will occur. Thus, these drugs can be given in standard doses.

β1 causes stimulation of SA node and β2 causes relaxation of the detrusor muscle of bladder.

questions.text: A 70-year old man diagnosed with Alzheimer's disease was prescribed an anticholinesterase agent. Which of the following is avoided due to its hepatotoxic side-effect?
questions.solution:
Tacrine has the highest incidence of hepatotoxicity among the anticholinesterase agents.

Anticholinesterase drugs:

Noncovalent reversible inhibitors:

  • Edrophonium: Diagnose myasthenia gravis
  • Tacrine, donepezil, and galantamine: Treat Alzheimer disease

Carbamate inhibitors:

  • Pyridostigmine, neostigmine, and ambenonium: Treat myasthenia gravis
  • Neostigmine: Paralytic ileus and Atony of the urinary bladder
  • Rivastigmine: Alzheimer disease

questions.text: Which of the following is the action of the drug metaproterenol?

choices.text: Acts on the SA node to decrease heart rate
Acts on the AV node to cause conduction delay
Acts on bronchial smooth muscle to cause bronchodilation
Acts on ventricular musculature to reduce oxygen requirement

questions.solution:
Metaproterenol is a short-acting beta-2 selective agonist, which cause bronchodilation.

Beta –2 selective agonist:

Short-acting:

  • Albuterol
  • Levalbuterol
  • Pirbuterol
  • Terbutaline

Long-acting:

  • Salmeterol
  • Formoterol
  • Arformoterol

Very long-acting:

  • Indacaterol
  • Olodaterol
  • Vilanterol

questions.text: Which of the following drugs promote weight loss by increasing satiety?
questions.solution:
Lorcaserin acts as an agonist on 5HT2C receptor and causes weight loss by increasing satiety and decreasing food consumption.

Other options:

  • Option 1 : Orlistat acts in the gastrointestinal system inhibiting intestinal lipase and hence reducing fat absorption.
  • Option 3 : Alosetron acts on 5HT3 receptor and act as an antiemetic.
  • Option 4 : Zolmitriptan acts on 5HT1B/1D and is used in the treatment of migraine.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is FDA approved for the treatment of Tourette syndrome?
questions.solution:
Aripiprazole is the only antipsychotic approved by FDA for the treatment of Tourette syndrome.

Treatment modalities of Tourette syndrome (in order of preference):

  • Detection and treatment of co-morbidities like OCD, ADHD, depression, and anxiety.
  • Education and behavioral treatments:  Habit reversal and exposure and response prevention are the behavioral treatments of choice.
  • Adrenergic alpha-2 agonists (Always to be tried first before starting antipsychotics): Clonidine and Guanfacine.
  • Antipsychotics: Aripiprazole is the first line drug. Because of side-effects haloperidol and pimozide are no longer used.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man with a history of schizophrenia was brought to the hospital with an acute-onset neck spasm. On examination, his upper body and neck are rigid. On review of his medications, it is seen that he had been started on haloperidol 5 days back. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Based on the clinical presentation and the history of recent haloperidol usage, the most probable diagnosis is acute dystonia. 

Acute dystonia usually presents within hours or days of starting treatment with antipsychotic drugs. There is a higher risk among patients between the ages of 10–19. It occurs due to acute dopamine receptor antagonism.  It presents with spasms of the head and neck muscles and the tongue. The severest form includes an oculogyric crisis with extraocular muscle involvement.

Treatment is with anticholinergics, such as benztropine, diphenhydramine, or trihexyphenidyl.

Other options:

Option A: Akathisia is an extrapyramidal syndrome characterized by a feeling of restlessness, frequent repetitive stereotyped movements, and an inability to sit still for more than a short period of time. It usually occurs during the first few months of drug use.

Option C: Neuroleptic malignant syndrome: It usually occurs weeks to months after starting neuroleptic therapy. Clinical manifestations include fever, extreme muscle rigidity, stupor, dystonia, tachycardia, and unstable blood pressure. Treatment is with dantrolene or with dopamine agonists such as bromocriptine. The antipsychotic drug responsible should be immediately stopped.

Option D: Tardive dyskinesia is characterized by choreiform movements which are quick, repetitive, involuntary movements, along with slower twisting athetotic movements. It occurs months or years after initiation of the treatment and is more frequent in the elderly.

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient experiences transient flashing in the vision even in the dark. Which of the following drugs could be the cause?
questions.solution:
One of the known side effects of Ivabradine is phosphenes, which is transient enhanced lightness in few areas of the visual field.

It is a selective blocker of hyperpolarization-activated HCN ion channels involved in the generation of automaticity in the SA node.

It is used for the treatment of stable angina and heart failure.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs acts through the receptor marked in the given image?
questions.solution:
Ticlopidine acts through the ADP receptor of the platelet and prevents its recruitment and activation.

Other drugs that act through the ADP receptor are:

  • Clopidogrel
  • Prasugrel
  • Cangrelor
  • Ticagrelor

Drugs that act through GPIIb/IIIa are:

  • Abciximab
  • Tirofiban
  • Eptifibatide

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is most commonly associated with statin-induced myopathy?
questions.solution:
Gemfibrozil is the most commonly associated with statin-induced myopathy, followed by digoxin, cyclosporin, and azole antifungals.

Coadministration of gemfibrozil nearly doubles the plasma concentration of the statin hydroxy acids.

Other factors associated with statin-induced myopathy are

  • Age more than 80 years
  • Hepatic and renal dysfunction
  • Perioperative period
  • Untreated hypothyroidism

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with multiple sclerosis was prescribed alemtuzumab. The mechanism by which the drug acts, that helps in the treatment of this condition is_______

choices.text: Binds with T-cell receptor complex and block antigen recognition
Binds to CD52 and causes lysis of the cell
Inhibiting antigen presenting cells by attaching to CD80 and CD86

questions.solution:
Alemtuzumab is a monoclonal antibody that attaches to CD52 and causes the lysis of B cells, T cells, macrophages, and natural killer cells.

It is used mainly for induction of immunosuppressive therapy and allows the avoidance of the early high dose of steroids. Also used for the treatment of multiple sclerosis and chronic lymphocytic leukemia

Other options:

Option A: Muromonab is a monoclonal antibody that attaches to CD3. It binds with the T-cell receptor complex and blocks antigen recognition.

Option C: Daclizumab and Basiliximab prevent IL-2 receptor-mediated T-cell activation.

Option D: Belatacept acts by inhibiting antigen-presenting cells by attaching to CD80 and CD86.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is also used in the treatment of erectile dysfunction?
questions.solution:
Alprostadil (Prostaglandin E1) is used as a second-line drug for the treatment of erectile dysfunction, either by intracavernous injection or urethral suppository.

Other options:

  • Epoprostenol (PGI2) used to treat pulmonary hypertension.
  • Dinoprostone (PGE2) is used for cervical ripening and induction of labor.
  • Tafluprost (PGF2alpha) is used to treat glaucoma.

questions.text: Which of the following is not one of the uses of thyrotropin alpha?

choices.text: Prepare the patient for radioiodine ablation of thyroid remnant
Test the capacity of thyroid tissue to take up radioactive iodine
Prepare patients for radioactive ablation of metastatic disease
Prevents the use of thyroid hormone withdrawal

questions.solution:
Thyrotropin alpha (Recombinant human TSH) is currently not approved to prepare the patient for radioactive ablation of thyroid metastatic disease.

It is used instead of thyroid hormone withdrawal to prepare a patient for radioiodine ablation of thyroid remnant tissue or to test the capacity of thyroid tissue, both normal and malignant, to take up radioactive iodine and to secrete thyroglobulin.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs have similar potency for both anti-inflammatory action and sodium retention?
questions.solution:
Hydrocortisone has similar potency for both anti-inflammatory action and sodium retention.

Other options:

  • Fludrocortisone is primarily mineralocorticoid and has the most sodium retaining capacity.
  • Triamcinolone and betamethasone are predominately glucocorticoid action and negligible sodium retention properties.

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen with the usage of liraglutide in diabetic patients?

choices.text: Causes weight gain when used over a year
Reduces the risk of cardiovascular death
It is better than exenatide in reducing HbA1C
Used with both oral hypoglycemics and basal insulin

questions.solution:
Liraglutide causes weight loss and improves glycemic control.

Also, it reduces the risk of cardiovascular death. It is better than exenatide in reducing HbA1C.

It is a soluble fatty acid-acylated GLP-1 analog. The half-life is approximately 12 hours, permitting once-daily dosing. It is approved in patients with type 2 diabetes who achieve inadequate control with diet and exercise and are receiving concurrent treatment with metformin, sulfonylureas, or thiazolidinediones.

It reduces post-meal hyperglycemia by

  • Increasing glucose-mediated insulin release
  • Lowering glucagon levels
  • Slowing gastric emptying
  • Decreasing appetite

It is used in type 2 DM and is the only GLP-1 receptor agonist used in obesity.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs prolong the slow inactivation of voltage-gated Na+ channels?
questions.solution:
Lacosamide prolongs the slow inactivation of voltage-gated Na+ channels.

It is approved for both monotherapy and add-on therapy for focal-onset seizures in patients 17 years and older.
