questions.text: Which of the following drug is used for oral treatment of hypervolemic and euvolemic hyponatremia?
questions.solution:
Tolvaptan is a selective oral V2 receptor antagonist FDA approved for the treatment of hypervolemic and euvolemic hyponatremia.

Conivaptan is nonselective V1a/V2 receptor antagonist used for the treatment of hypervolemic and euvolemic hyponatremia but is available only for intravenous usage.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs induces paralysis by activating ligand-gated Cl- channels and is used in the treatment of onchocerciasis?
questions.solution:
Ivermectin induces paralysis by activating ligand-gated Cl- channels and is used in the treatment of onchocerciasis.

Other options:

  • Praziquantel acts by promoting an influx of Ca2+ and is the drug of choice for treating schistosomiasis.
  • Pyrantel pamoate induces persistent activation of nicotinic acetylcholine receptors and spastic paralysis of the worm.
  • Tribendimidine is an agonist of nicotinic acetylcholine receptors of nematodes.

questions.text: Which of the following is wrong about ziconotide?

choices.text: It is a synthetic copy of neuroactive cone snail toxin
Binds to and blocks N-type Ca2+ channels on nociceptive neurons
It is administered through intravenous patient-controlled pump
Contraindicated in a patient with history of psychosis

questions.solution:
Ziconotide is administered intrathecally as a continuous infusion by a controlled microinfusion pump.

It is a synthetic copy of neuroactive cone snail toxin and binds to and blocks N-type Ca2+ channels on nociceptive neurons and is used to treat severe chronic pain in adults.

Side effects include hallucinations and paranoia and hence contraindicated in patients with preexisting history of psychosis.

questions.text: The caspase first activated by the intrinsic pathway of apoptosis is:
questions.solution:
The intrinsic/mitochondrial pathway leads to activation of the initiator caspase-9.

Caspases are cysteine proteases that cleave proteins after aspartic residues. They exist as inactive proenzymes.

There are two types of caspases:

  • Initiator caspases - They are activated first. They, in turn, activate executioner caspases. Caspases 8, 9, and 10 are initiator caspases.
  • Executioner caspases- They act on the cellular components. Caspases 3 and 6 are executioner caspases.

Apoptotic pathways lead to the activation of caspases:

  • The mitochondrial pathway leads to activation of the initiator caspase-9,
  • The death receptor pathway leads to the activation of the initiator caspases-8 and -10.

The activated initiator caspase leads to the activation of the executioner caspases such as caspase-3 and -6.

These caspases activate enzymes that degrade the cells, proteins, and nucleus. The end result is the characteristic cellular fragmentation of apoptosis.

The following image shows the apoptotic pathways:

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in MEN 2B?
questions.solution:
Primary hyperparathyroidism is not seen in MEN 2B.

MEN syndrome:

  • MEN-1 syndrome is caused by germline mutations in the MEN1 tumor suppressor gene, which encodes a protein called Menin.
  • MEN-2 syndrome comprises two distinct groups of disorders that are caused by gain-of-function mutations of the RET proto-oncogene at chromosomal locus 10q11.2.

MEN 2B is also called MEN 3 and is characterized by:

  • Medullary thyroid cancer
  • Pheochromocytoma
  • Mucosal neuromas
  • Marfanoid habitus
  • Medullated corneal nerve fibers
  • Megacolon

Related Pearl: MEN 2 Syndrome Features

MEN 2A

  • Known as Sipple’s syndrome
  • Chromosome 10 / RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Parathyroid adenoma (10–25%)

MEN 2B

  • Known commonly as MEN 3
  • Chromosome 10/ RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (>90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Other associated abnormalities include: (40–50%)
      • Mucosal neuromas
      • Marfanoid habitus
      • Medullated corneal nerve fibers
      • Megacolon

questions.text: Which of the following conditions does not favor the formation of red infarct?
questions.solution:
Red (hemorrhagic) infarct does not occur in organs with high tissue density because this limits the seepage of blood from adjoining capillary beds into the necrotic area.

Infarcts can be classified according to:

  • Color- they are either red (hemorrhagic) or white (anemic)
  • Presence or absence of infection- they may be septic or bland.

Red infarcts occur in the following conditions:

  • Venous occlusion (e.g., testicular torsion)
  • Loose, spongy tissues (e.g., lung) where blood can collect in the infarcted zone
  • Tissues with dual circulations (e.g., lung and small intestine) that allow blood from a parallel supply into the necrotic zone
  • Tissues previously congested by the sluggish venous outflow
  • Blood flow is reestablished to a site of previous arterial occlusion and necrosis (e.g., following angioplasty of an arterial  obstruction)

White infarcts occur in the following conditions:

  • Arterial occlusions
  • Organs with end-arterial circulation
  • High tissue density e.g., heart, spleen, and kidney

 

The following image shows red infarction of the lung:

White splenic infarct:

questions.text: Which of the following is the major source of plasma von-Willebrand factor?
questions.solution:
The major source of plasma von-Willebrand factor is endothelial cells.

vWF is also found in:

  • Platelet granules - lesser compared to endothelial cells
  • Endothelial cells within cytoplasmic vesicles called Weibel-Palade bodies
  • Subendothelium - binds to collagen

questions.text: Red cell distribution width (RDW) is an indicator of:
questions.solution:
Red cell distribution width (RDW) is the coefficient of variation of red cell volume. Increase in RDW indicates increased variation in cell sizes of the RBCs which is known as anisocytosis.

Normal value: 

  • RDW-SD: 39-46 fL
  • RDW-CV: 11.5-14.8%

Causes of increased RDW:

  • Iron-deficiency anemia
  • Folate/vitamin B12 deficiency anemia

Poikilocytosis - Variation in the shape of RBCs.

Anisochromia - Non uniform colour of the RBCs caused by non uniform distribution of haemoglobin in them.

Microcytosis - Decrease in the size of RBCs.

 

The following image shows anisocytosis:

questions.text:
A young adult male presented with chronic fatigue and gallstones. His father had a similar illness for which splenectomy was done. Investigations were done and shown below. Which of the following protein defects is not seen in this condition?

Hemoglobin- decreased
Mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration- increased
Mean corpuscular volume - decreased
Red cell distribution width - increased
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario, lab investigations and peripheral smear showing numerous spherocytes are suggestive of Hereditary spherocytosis (HS). Laminin is not involved in the pathogenesis of hereditary spherocytosis. 

Laminins form part of the basement membrane which binds to both hemidesmosomes and anchoring filaments. Mutations in laminin and laminin alpha 2 (merosin) result in the blistering phenotype of junctional epidermolysis bullosa (JEB) and congenital muscular dystrophy (CMD) respectively.  

Hereditary spherocytosis is a type of hemolytic anaemia that is most commonly inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern. Mutations in α-spectrin, β-spectrin, ankyrin, band 4.2, and band 3 weaken the association of the membrane skeleton with the overlying plasma membrane, making them spheroid and less deformable. This causes red cells to shed membrane vesicles and transform into spherocytes. The non-deformable spherocytes get trapped in the splenic cords and phagocytosed by macrophages.

The ankyrin gene mutation is the most likely genetic mutation seen in autosomal-dominant hereditary spherocytosis. Mutations in the spectrin gene result in the most severe form of HS.

 

Patients usually present with anemia, fatigue, splenomegaly, and jaundice and the age of presentation varies with the severity of the disease. The unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia predisposes the patient to develop gallstones.

An aplastic crisis might occur when red cell production is halted due to parvovirus infection. This lasts 1 to 2 weeks, usually the time required for the immune system to clear the virus. Blood transfusions may be needed during this period.

Based on family history, peripheral smear findings, and laboratory investigations an adequate diagnosis is made. Increased osmotic fragility is seen in the majority of the cases. They show normocytic normochromic anemia, an increased MCHC (mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration) due to cellular dehydration, raised RDW(red cell distribution width) and normal or reduced MCV (mean corpuscular volume).

The most common peripheral smear finding is spherocytosis, which presents as small, dark-staining (hyperchromic) red cells without the central zone of pallor. This is, however, a non-specific finding. Other features seen are reticulocytosis, Howell-Jolly bodies (dense basophilic nuclear remnants in the RBCs), marrow erythroid hyperplasia and hemosiderosis.

Splenectomy is the current treatment of choice in HS.

questions.text: Which subtype of thyroid carcinoma has the worst prognosis?
questions.solution:
Anaplastic carcinomas have the worst prognosis among the thyroid carcinomas. These are aggressive tumors, with a mortality rate approaching 100%.

Anaplastic carcinomas:

  • Undifferentiated tumors of the thyroid follicular epithelium
  • Accounting for less than 5% of thyroid tumors
  • Arise de novo or  by the progression of  papillary or follicular carcinoma
  • Mean age of affected patients is 65 years
  • Composed of highly anaplastic cells, with variable morphology
  • The neoplastic cells express epithelial markers like cytokeratin

Papillary thyroid cancers have an excellent prognosis, with a 10-year survival rate more than 95%.

Related Pearl: Thyroid Malignancy - Most Commons

  • Most common primary thyroid malignancy – Papillary carcinoma
  • Most common thyroid malignancy associated with radiation - Papillary carcinoma
  • Most common malignancy of thyroid associated with lymphatic spread – Papillary carcinoma
  • Most common thyroid malignancy associated with blood and bone metastasis – Follicular carcinoma
  • Most common thyroid malignancy in iodine sufficient areas – Papillary carcinoma
  • Most common thyroid malignancy in iodine deficient areas – Follicular carcinoma
  • Most common thyroid malignancy associated with Multi Nodular Goiter - Follicular carcinoma
  • Thyroid malignancy associated with amyloid - Medullary carcinoma
  • Thyroid malignancy associated with MEN 2 syndrome - Medullary carcinoma
  • Most aggressive thyroid malignancy with worst prognosis - Anaplastic carcinoma
  • Thyroid malignancy with best prognosis - Papillary carcinoma

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about gastrointestinal stromal tumor?

choices.text: Most common mesenchymal tumor of the abdomen
Most common genetic change is activation of PDGFRA
Arise from the interstitial cells of Cajal
Peak incidence of gastric GIST is around 60 years of age

questions.solution:
The most common genetic change in GISTs is gain-of-function mutation of the tyrosine kinase KIT gene. These are present in 75% to 85% of all GISTs.

The second most common mutation results in activation of platelet-derived growth factor receptor A (PDGFRA).

Related Pearl: Gastrointestinal Stromal Tumor (GIST)

M/C mesenchymal tumor of GIT arising from interstitial cells of Cajal (pacemaker cells of GIT). Stomach is the m/c site.

GISTs express:

  • c-KIT (CD117)
  • PDGF receptor A
  • CD34
  • SDH

Clinical Features:

  • Peaks at 60 years of age.
  • M/C symptom: Upper GI bleeding
  • Other symptoms: Pain, lump, perforation, incidental finding
  • Carney's Triad: Sporadic GIST, Paraganglioma, Pulmonary chondroma

Management:

  • IOC for primary GIST: CECT abdomen
  • IOC for recurrent GIST: PET-CT
  • IHC markers: CD117/C-KIT (M/C), DOG 1 (most specific), CD 34
  • Route of metastasis: Hematogenous

The following image shows microscopy of GIST composed of spindle-shaped tumor cells:

  • Fletcher's classification (Tumor size & No. of mitotic figures) is used to classify the tumors according to their malignancy risk.
  • Prognosis is determined by: Mitotic index, tumor size & location of tumor (Stomach GISTs are less aggressive).
  • Complete surgical resection is the mainstay treatment. For unresectable, recurrent, or metastatic GISTs, imatinib, a tyrosine kinase inhibitor, can be used.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman, previously diagnosed with breast cancer, is now found to have endometrial cancer. Genetic testing revealed a mutation in the PTEN gene. What other condition is she at increased risk of developing?
questions.solution:
A patient with a PTEN germline mutation with history of breast carcinoma, now diagnosed with endometrial carcinoma is at high risk of developing thyroid carcinoma concerning cowden syndrome.

Cowden syndrome is an autosomal dominant disorder associated with pTEN germline mutations and marked by:

  • Hamartomatous growths of the skin and mucus membranes- buccal, intestinal, and colonic
  • Increased incidence of epithelial cancers particularly of the breast, endometrium, and thyroid

questions.text:
A patient with a family history of Alport syndrome comes for genetic counseling. Which of the following inheritance patterns can be seen in Alport syndrome?
  1. X-linked dominant
  2. Mitochondrial
  3. Autosomal dominant
  4. Autosomal recessive
questions.solution:
The inheritance patterns seen in Alport syndrome are X-linked dominant, autosomal dominant, and autosomal recessive.

Alport syndrome is a form of hereditary nephritis caused by a mutation in the gene encoding type IV collagen. The most common inheritance pattern is X-linked dominant, wherein all males develop the full syndrome but women present with only hematuria. Other rare patterns include autosomal dominant and autosomal recessive, wherein both males and females develop the full spectrum.

Type IV collagen is essential for the functioning of the glomerular basement membrane (GBM), the lens of the eye, and the cochlea. Thus, patients most commonly present with hematuria, which progresses to chronic renal failure. Various eye disorders, including lens dislocation, posterior cataracts, corneal dystrophy, and nerve deafness may also be present. 

Electron microscopy shows irregular thickening and thinning of the GBM, with marked splitting and lamination of the lamina densa, giving it a typical basket-weave appearance.

questions.text: Fibrinoid necrosis is an example of:
questions.solution:
Fibrinoid necrosis is an example of Type III (immune-complex mediated) hypersensitivity.

It usually occurs in immune reactions in which complexes of antigens and antibodies are deposited in the walls of blood vessels.

Pathogenesis of Type III hypersensitivity:

  • Deposition of antigen-antibody complexes leading to complement activation
  • Recruitment of leukocytes by complement products and Fc receptors
  • Release of enzymes and other toxic molecules leading to inflammation

questions.text: The trinucleotide repeat mutation associated with Fragile X syndrome is:
questions.solution:
Fragile X syndrome is associated with CGG trinucleotide repeat mutation on Xq chromosome.

The normal FMR1 gene contains CGG repeats. When the number of trinucleotide repeats is excessive, abnormal methylation of the region results in transcriptional suppression of FMR1 and the absence of familial mental retardation protein (FMRP).

Clinical features: X linked disease which predominantly affects males.

  • Moderate to severe mental retardation
  • Long face with a large mandible
  • Large everted ears
  • Large testicles (macroorchidism)

Other common trinucleotide repeat mutations and their associated conditions:

  • GAA- Friedreich ataxia
  • CAG- Huntington disease
  • CTG- Myotonic dystrophy

questions.text: The cyclin essential for transition from G2 to M phase of the cell cycle is:
questions.solution:
Cyclin B is essential for the transition from G2 to M phase of the  cell cycle.

Role of cyclins in regulating the cell cycle:

  • Cyclin D and cyclin E regulate the G1-to-S transition.
  • Cyclin A is active in the S phase.
  • Cyclin B is essential for the G2-to-M transition.

 

The normal cell cycle:

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about hepcidin?

choices.text: Suppressed by high plasma iron concentration
Plays a role in anaemia of chronic disease

questions.solution:
High iron levels in the plasma enhance hepcidin production, whereas low iron levels suppress it.

The fraction of iron that is absorbed from the GIT  is regulated by hepcidin, a small peptide that is synthesized and secreted from the liver.

Other options:

  • Hepcidin levels rise during systemic inflammation (Acute phase reactant).
  • Hepcidin reaches the duodenum, where it binds ferroportin and induces its degradation and hence, prevents iron absorption.
  • Anemia of chronic inflammation stems from high levels of plasma hepcidin, which blocks the transfer of iron to erythroid precursors by downregulating ferroportin.

questions.text: The Hand-Schuller-Christian triad includes all except:
questions.solution:
The combination of calvarial bone defects, diabetes insipidus, and exophthalmos is referred to as the Hand-Schüller-Christian triad.

Multifocal cutaneous lesions are seen in multisystem Langerhans cell histiocytosis (Letterer-Siwe disease). They grossly resemble seborrheic skin eruptions and are composed of Langerhans cells.

Langerhans cell histiocytoses are proliferations of a special type of immature dendritic cell called the Langerhans cell. It can present as the following clinical entities:

  • Multifocal multisystem Langerhans cell histiocytosis (Letterer-Siwe disease)
  • Unifocal and multifocal unisystem Langerhans cell histiocytosis (eosinophilic granuloma)
  • Pulmonary Langerhans cell histiocytosis

questions.text: Identify the subtype of Hodgkin’s lymphoma based on the cell marked as A in the image:
questions.solution:
The given image shows popcorn cell which is characteristic of lymphocyte-predominant Hodgkin lymphoma.

Popcorn cell is lymphohistiocytic (L&H) variant of RS cells that has a delicate multilobed, puffy nucleus resembling popped corn.

L&H variants usually are found within large nodules containing mainly small B cells along with variable numbers of macrophages. The immunophenotype is CD20+ve, CD15−ve and C30−ve 

Related Pearl: Important Features of the Different Types of Hodgkin's Lymphoma (HL)

Classic subtypes

  • Nodular sclerosis 
  • Mixed cellularity 
  • Lymphocyte-rich
  • Lymphocyte depletion

Non-Classical subtype

  • Lymphocyte predominant

Note: Mixed cellularity is most commonly associated with HIV due to its high incidence.

questions.text: A 75-year-old man came with complaints of bilateral pedal edema and decreased urine output for the past one month. He has a past history of diabetes mellitus and has not been under regular treatment. The following histopathological image was obtained after a biopsy. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given histopathological image shows PAS-positive nodules suggestive of nodular glomerulosclerosis which is seen in diabetic nephropathy.

Nodular glomerulosclerosis, also known as Kimmelstiel-Wilson lesion is a glomerular lesion characterized by spherical-ovoid deposits of a laminated matrix in the periphery of the glomerulus surrounded by patent or dilated capillary loops. These nodules are PAS-positive and usually contain trapped mesangial cells. The nodules often show features of mesangiolysis, defined as disruption of anchoring interactions between the capillaries and the mesangial stalks, which leads to the formation of capillary aneurysms.

Nodular glomerulosclerosis is encountered in approximately 15% to 30% of individuals with long-term diabetes and is a major contributor to renal dysfunction.

The lesions encountered in diabetic nephropathy are:

  • Glomerular lesions: Capillary basement membrane thickening, diffuse mesangial sclerosis, and nodular glomerulosclerosis.
  • Renal vascular lesions, principally arteriolosclerosis
  • Pyelonephritis, including necrotizing papillitis.

Other options:

Option B: Crescentic glomerulonephritis is also known as rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN). Histopathology will show compressed glomerular tufts by a crescent-shaped mass of epithelial cells and leukocytes.

Option C:  glomerulonephritis (MPGN) is a pattern of immune-mediated injury. MPGN is characterized histologically by changes in the glomerular basement membrane, multiplication of glomerular cells, and the presence of deposits in the mesangial area and glomerular capillaries. The basement membrane shows a 'double-contour' or 'tram-track' appearance on silver or PAS stains. 

Option D: Segmental glomerulosclerosis is characterized by presence of focal and segmental sclerotic lesions of glomeruli which show obliteration of capillary lumens and deposition of plasma proteins along the capillary wall (hyalinosis). On electron microscopy, there is diffuse effacement of foot processes.

Related Pearl: Tram Track Appearance in Various Conditions

Tram tracks or tram track signs are medical signs that bear some resemblance to tramway tracks (Railway Track).

1. Pulmonology

  • When found in the lungs, tram tracks are radiologic signs that are usually accompanied by pulmonary edema in cases of congestive heart failure and bronchiectasis.
  • Tram tracks are caused by bronchial wall thickening, and can be detected on a lateral chest X-ray.

2. Nephrology

  • The term "tram tracks" is also used to describe the basement membrane duplication found on light microscopy that is characteristic of membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN) type I.
  • It is less commonly associated with types II and III.

3. Neurology

  • The term has also been used to describe findings associated with optic nerve sheath meningioma.
  • Tram track-shaped calcifications in the cerebral cortex indicate Sturge-Weber syndrome.

4. Mammary glands:

  • Tram track appearance in mammography/USG indicates Duct Ectasia.

questions.text: Which of the following tumors is not commonly seen in patients of neurofibromatosis 2?
questions.solution:
Neurofibromas are rarely found in neurofibromatosis 2 patients.

Neurofibromatosis 2 patients are at risk of developing multiple schwannomas, meningiomas, and ependymomas. The presence of bilateral vestibular schwannomas is a hallmark of NF2.

Neurofibromatosis 1 is associated with neurofibromas, malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumors, gliomas of the optic nerve, other glial tumors, hamartomatous lesions, and pheochromocytomas.

questions.text:
Which of the following tumors is correctly matched with its histological features?

A. Neuroblastoma- Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes
B. Nephroblastoma- Triphasic pattern
C. Retinoblastoma-  Homer Wright rosettes  
D. Teratoma- Multiple germ cell lines
questions.solution:
The correct match is as follows:

Neuroblastoma  Homer Wright pseudorosettes
Nephroblastoma  Triphasic pattern
Retinoblastoma  Homer Wright rosettes and Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes
Teratoma    Cells of multiple germ layers

Neuroblastoma - Homer-Wright pseudorosettes consist of tumor cells that are concentrically arranged about a central space filled with neuropil (eosinophilic fibrillary material).

Nephroblastoma- The classic triphasic combination of blastemal, stromal, and epithelial cell types is observed in most lesions.

Retinoblastoma- Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes consist of clusters of cuboidal or short columnar cells arranged around a central lumen. Homer Wright rosettes are also seen in retinoblastoma.

Teratoma- Contains recognizable mature or immature cells or tissues derived from more than one germ cell layer.

questions.text: Which of the following stains is commonly used to detect ring sideroblasts in bone marrow aspirate?
questions.solution:
Perl’s Prussian blue is used to detect ring sideroblasts in bone marrow aspirates or biopsies.

Ring sideroblasts are erythroblasts with iron-laden mitochondria which are visible as perinuclear granules when stained with Prussian blue stain.

 The given image shows ringed sideroblast:

Other options:

  • Toluidine blue is used to highlight mast cells granules.
  • Brilliant cresyl blue is used to stain reticulocytes.
  • Alcian blue is used to stain acidic mucin, especially in GI specimens.

questions.text: Which of the following originates from the B cells of marginal zone?
questions.solution:
Small lymphocytic lymphoma originates from the B cells of the marginal zone.

Lymphoid neoplasms that originate from the germinal center are:

  • Follicular lymphoma
  • Burkitt lymphoma
  • Diffuse large B cell lymphoma
  • Hodgkin’s lymphoma

Lymphoid neoplasms that originate from the marginal zone B cells are:

  • Marginal zone lymphoma
  • Small lymphocytic lymphoma
  • Chronic lymphocytic leukemia

Small lymphocytic lymphoma/ chronic lymphocytic leukemia can also arise from the naive B cell (pre germinal B cells).

questions.text: The granulomas in sarcoidosis consist of:

choices.text: Epithelioid cells rimmed by CD4+ T cells
CD4+ T cells rimmed by  epithelioid cells
Eosinophilic cells rimmed by multinucleated giant cells
Central necrosis rimmed by epithelioid cells and multinucleated giant cells

questions.solution:
The cardinal histopathologic feature of sarcoidosis is the non-necrotizing epithelioid granuloma - epithelioid cells rimmed by an outer zone rich in CD4+ T cells.

Other option:

  • Eosinophilic granuloma is a variant of Langerhans cell histiocytosis. The Langerhans cells are admixed with variable numbers of lymphocytes, plasma cells, neutrophils, and eosinophils, which are usually prominent.
  • Caseating granuloma (tubercle) is a focus of activated macrophages(epithelioid cells), rimmed by fibroblasts, lymphocytes, histiocytes, occasional Langhans giant cells; central necrosis with amorphous granular debris and acid-fast bacilli.

questions.text: Which of the following features differentiates leukodystrophies from demyelinating diseases of the CNS?
questions.solution:
Abnormal myelin synthesis differentiates leukodystrophies from demyelinating diseases of the CNS.

Leukodystrophies are inherited demyelinating diseases caused by mutations of genes whose products are involved in the generation, turnover, or maintenance of myelin. 

Demyelinating diseases of the CNS do not affect myelin synthesis. They are characterized by preferential damage to previously normal myelin.

  Demyelinating diseases Leukodystrophies
Inheritance Acquired Inherited
Onset Rapid onset Insidious onset
White matter involvement Patchy Diffuse
Course Episodic Progressive
Pathophysiology Damage to previously normal myelin Abnormal myelin synthesis or turnover
Examples Multiple sclerosis, Progressive multifocal leukoencapholpathy Adrenoleukodystrophy, Metachromatic leukodystrophy

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of cold antibody immunohemolytic anemia?
questions.solution:
IgA antibodies cause warm antibody immunohemolytic anemia.

Cold antibody immunohemolytic anemia is caused by low-affinity IgM antibodies that bind to red cell membranes only at temperatures below 30°C, such as in distal parts of the body (e.g., ears, hands, and toes) in cold weather.

Although bound IgM fixes complement, the latter steps of the complement cascade do not occur efficiently at temperatures lower than 37°C. When these RBCs reach warmer areas, C3b on these RBCs acts as an opsonin causing the cells to be phagocytosed by macrophages, mainly in the spleen and liver. Hence, in most cases, the hemolysis is mainly extravascular.

Binding of pentavalent IgM also crosslinks red cells and causes them to clump (agglutinate).

Sludging of blood in capillaries because of agglutination often produces Raynaud phenomenon in the extremities of affected individuals.

questions.text: You are writing a review on various government schemes that help provide non-formal education and aim at reducing malnutrition, morbidity, and mortality. The logo of one such scheme is given below. Which of the following schemes does it represent?

choices.text: Ministry of Woman and Child Development
National Commission for Protection of Child Rights

questions.solution:
The given logo is of ICDS - Integrated child development services.

Integrated child development services:

It was launched on the 2nd of October, 1975, and focuses on early childhood care and development. The scheme helps in providing pre-school non-formal education and breaking the vicious cycle of malnutrition, morbidity, reduced learning capacity, and mortality. Beneficiaries under the Scheme include children in the age group of 0-6 years, pregnant women, and lactating mothers.

Objectives:

  • to improve the nutritional and health status of children in the age group 0-6 years
  • to lay the foundation for proper psychological, physical and social development of the child
  • to reduce the incidence of mortality, morbidity, malnutrition, and school dropout
  • to achieve effective co-ordination of policy and implementation amongst the various departments to promote child development
  • to enhance the capability of the mother to look after the normal health and nutritional needs of the child through proper nutrition and health education.

Other options:

Option B- Ministry of Woman and Child Development:

 

Option C- National Commission for Protection of Child Rights:

 

Option D- Janani Shishu Suraksha Karyakram is a part of the National Health Mission:

questions.text: Which of the following is the vector for Zika virus?
questions.solution:
Aedes aegypti and Aedes albopictus are the two vectors for Zika virus transmission.

Zika virus (RNA virus) is a flavivirus and the infection is characterized by influenza-like clinical signs including fever, headache, and malaise.

A maculopapular rash, conjunctivitis, myalgia, and arthralgia usually accompany or follow those manifestations. Petechial rashes are not seen.

Complications: Guillian-Barre syndrome and microcephaly and intracranial calcification in infants born to mothers infected with Zika virus. Pregnant women should consider postponing travel to areas where Zika virus transmission is ongoing.

Diagnosis:  

  • Trioplex Real-Time RT-PCR (rRT-PCR) assay
  •  Zika MAC-ELISA.

questions.text: What do all of the following together represent? “The ability to lead a long and healthy life; the ability to acquire knowledge; and the ability to achieve a decent standard of living”.
questions.solution:
Human Development Index (HDI) is defined as “a composite index focusing on three basic dimensions of human development: To lead a long and healthy life, measured by life expectancy at birth; the ability to acquire knowledge, measured by mean years of schooling; and the ability to achieve a decent standard of living, measured by gross national income per capita”.

Other options:

  • Physical Quality of Life Index (PQLI): It consolidates three indicators which include “infant mortality, life expectancy at age one, and literacy”.
  • Human Poverty Index (HPI): Measures deprivation in basic dimensions of human development.
  • GNI Index: Gross National Income Index, is a component of HDI.

Related Pearl: HDI vs. PQLI

 

Human Development Index (HDI)

 Physical Quality of Life Index (PQLI)
Components

Longevity (Life expectancy at birth)

A decent standard of living (Real GNI per capita in PPP US$)

Knowledge (mean years of schooling and expected years of schooling)

Life expectancy at 1 year of age 

Infant Mortality rate

Literacy rate
Range 0 to +1 0 to 100

questions.text: A study was conducted on 200 individuals. 100 of them had a history of occupational exposure to asbestos and 100 of them did not. From the data in their past investigations, the incidence of asbestosis was derived. In addition to this, the study population was followed up for a period of 20 years to find out the incidence of malignant mesothelioma in the study population. The study is a typical example of:
questions.solution:
It is a combination of both retrospective and prospective cohort studies (i.e., ambispective cohort study).

In the above study, the incidence of asbestosis is arrived at using the retrospective component of the cohort study and the incidence of malignant mesothelioma is arrived at from the prospective component of the cohort study.

In case-control studies often called “retrospective studies”, the progression is from effect to cause. In such cases the outcome has already occurred. It is a common first approach to test the causal hypothesis (this is not the case in the study in question).

Related Pearl: Cohort Study

  • A cohort study progresses from cause (exposure) to effect (disease).
  • It is also known as forward-looking study, incidence study, prospective study, and longitudinal study.
  • Design of a cohort study:
    • Types of cohort study:
      • Prospective (concurrent) cohort studies
      • Retrospective (historical) cohort studies
      • Combination cohort studies
    • Steps of cohort study:
      • Selection of study subjects
      • Obtaining data on exposure
      • Selection of comparison groups
      • Follow-up
      • Analysis in terms of incidence rates and estimation of risk
    • Advantages of cohort study:
      • Incidence can be calculated
      • Several possible outcomes related to exposure can be studied at the same time
      • Provides direct estimate of relative risk
      • Calculation of dose-response ratio
      • Minimization of certain biases
    • Disadvantages of cohort study:
      • Cannot use for uncommon diseases
      • Expensive, requires a large population and longer time
      • Many common administrative and ethical problems
      • High attrition and selection of subjects is difficult
      • Dynamism of diagnostics is difficult to incorporate
      • Tends to alter the behaviour of subjects known as Hawthorne effect.

Related Pearl: Case Control Study

In a case-control study, progression is from effect (disease) to cause (exposure) as the outcome or disease has already occurred. It is also called a retrospective study.

Design of case-control study:

 

  • Steps of case control study:
    • Selection of cases and controls
    • Matching
    • Measurement of exposure
    • Analysis in the form of exposure rates, risk ratio, and odds ratio
  • Advantages of case control study:
    • Easy to carry out, rapid and inexpensive
    • Requires few subjects, no risk to subjects
    • Used to investigate rare diseases
    • Different etiological factors can be studied and risk factors can be identified
    • No attrition problems, minimal ethical problems
  • Disadvantages of case control study:
    • Relies on memory or past records giving rise to bias
    • Selection of appropriate control groups is difficult
    • Incidence cannot be measured
    • Does not distinguish between causes and associated factors
    • Not suited for evaluation of therapy or prophylaxis
    • Representativeness of the cases and controls is often inadequate

questions.text: The curve given below is used to determine and compare the threshold(s) of screening test(s). Label the X and Y axes.
questions.solution:
The curve given below is a Receiver Operating Characteristic (ROC) Curve. It is used for comparison between 2 or more screening tests of a disease with each other.

In a ROC Curve: True positive rate (or Sensitivity) of a screening/diagnostic is plotted as a function of the False positive rate (or 1 – Specificity) for different cut-off points of a parameter.

The area under the ROC Curve is a measure of how well a parameter can distinguish (I.e., threshold) between two diagnostic/screening groups.

questions.text: All of the following are components of the GOBI FFF strategy except:
questions.solution:
The GOBI FFF strategy was proposed by the United Nations Children’s Fund (UNICEF, originally known as United Nations Internation Children’s Emergency Fund).

Components of GOBI FFF are given in the pearl mentioned below.

Related Pearl: GOBI–FFF Strategy

This strategy was proposed by the United Nations Children’s Fund (UNICEF)

  • G – Growth monitoring with growth charts
  • O – Oral rehydration therapy for diarrhoea and dehydration
  • B – Breastfeeding
  • I – Immunization of children
  • F – Family planning and birth spacing
  • F – Food supplementation
  • F ­– Female literacy promotion

questions.text: Which of the following tuberculins is/are commonly used in India?
questions.solution:
The PPD-RT (Research Tuberculin) 23 with Tween 80 (a detergent to prevent adsorption of tuberculin on a glass or plastic surface) is used in India.

The standardized tuberculins (PPD-RT 23 with Tween 80 of strengths 1 TU and 2 TU) are supplied by BCG Vaccine Laboratory, Guindy, Chennai.

Only 2 tuberculins have been accepted as standard tuberculin by WHO: PPD – S (Siebert, derived from M. tuberculosis) and PPD-RT 23 (derived from seven strains of M. tuberculosis.

The few other types of Tuberculins are:

  • PPD-A: derived from M. avium
  • PPD-B: derived from M. intracellulare (Battey Bacillus)
  • PPD-Y: derived from M. kansasii (Yellow photochromogen)
  • PPD-F: derived from M. fortuitum

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy was brought with complaints of diarrhea and blood loss to the outpatient department. A stool examination showed  Ancylostoma dudoenale.  All of the given statements regarding Ancylostoma dudoenale are true except:

choices.text: Eggs are shed in faeces of an infected individual
Man and soil are known reservoirs
It can enter the human body through penetration of skin
Immediate source of infection is soil

questions.solution:
The given scenario of diarrhea, blood loss, and stool examination showing the presence of Ancylostoma dudoenale is suggestive of hookworm infection. Man is the only known reservoir of this condition. 

A reservoir is any person, animal, arthropod, plant, soil, or substance in which an infectious agent can live, multiply, and is transmissible to the susceptible host. 

The two main nematodes causing hookworm infection in humans are  Ancylostoma dudoenale and Necator americanus. The affected individuals can present with blood loss, diarrhea, and iron deficiency anemia. The adult hookworms reside in the small intestine (mainly jejunum) and are attached to the villi. The female worm can lay thousands of eggs which are passed in feces.

Larvae rapidly develop when these eggs land on warm, moist soil, and the egg hatches after 1 to 2 days. This soil contaminated with the infective larvae of this organism is the immediate source of infection. The feces containing the ova of the organisms are considered the infective material. The filariform larvae can enter the human body through penetration of skin or ingestion by mouth.

questions.text: An outbreak of viral hepatitis A was reported in a village between the months of July and October, with maximum cases in August. Which of the following statements is correct?

choices.text: Point source, multiple exposure with an infectivity period of 1 week
Point source, multiple exposure with an infectivity period of 4 weeks
Point source, single exposure with an infectivity period of 1 weeks
Point source, single exposure with an infectivity period of 4 weeks

questions.solution:
Hepatitis A virus is detected in the stool of a patient, typically from 2 weeks before the onset of jaundice up to 2 weeks after (i.e., the period of infectivity is about 4 weeks).

There are no cases of chronic disease due to hepatitis A. 

All of the above statements point to the presence of a point source of infection with multiple exposures. The outbreak lasted for more than the duration of a single period of infectivity (approximately, 4 weeks); thus, the above outbreak of hepatitis A is not from a single exposure.

questions.text: Which of the following is included in the WHO Global Action Plan for the Prevention and Control of non communicable diseases (NCDs) (2013 – 2020)?

choices.text: At least 50% relative reduction in harmful use of alcohol as appropriate with the national context
A 50% availability of the affordable basic technology and essential medicines
A 30% relative reduction in prevalence of current tobacco use in persons aged
30% relative reduction in the prevalence of insufficient physical activity

questions.solution:
The WHO Global Action Plan for the Prevention and Control of NCDs (2013 – 2020) has the following 9 Targets:

  • A 25% relative reduction in the overall mortality from cardiovascular diseases, cancer, diabetes, or chronic respiratory diseases.
  • At least 10% relative reduction in the harmful use of alcohol, as appropriate, within the national context.
  • A 10% relative reduction in the prevalence of insufficient physical activity.
  • A 30% relative reduction in mean population intake of salt/sodium.
  • A 30% relative reduction in the prevalence of current tobacco use in persons aged 15+ years.
  • A 25% relative reduction in the prevalence of raised blood pressure or contain the prevalence of raised blood pressure, according to national circumstances.
  • Halt the rise in diabetes and obesity.
  • At least 50% of eligible people receive drug therapy and counseling (including glycemic control) to prevent heart attacks and strokes.
  • An 80% availability of the affordable basic technologies and essential medicines, including generics, required to treat major NCDs in both public and private facilities.

questions.text: Tracking of dropouts and left outs by card tracing and vaccinating them per complete coverage is done by?
questions.solution:
It is the duty of the female health worker to track dropouts and left outs under the Universal Immunization Program (UIP) and vaccinate them per complete coverage.

While the Male health worker has a role under the expanded programme on immunization, it does not involve tracking of dropouts.

questions.text: The ability of a test to avoid false negative error is:

choices.text: Directly proportional to the width of confidence interval and inversely proportional to sample size
Directly proportional to β and directly proportional to sampling error
Directly proportional to sample size and inversely proportional to sampling error
Inversely proportional to the width of confidence interval and directly proportional to sampling error

questions.solution:
The ability of a test to avoid false negative error (type II or β error) is called the Power of the Test (“the ability of a test to reject a null hypothesis when it is false”).

It is expressed as 1 - β.

Thus,

A test’s power will increase if

  • β error decreases
  • Width of the Confidence interval (I.e., the margin of error) decreases
  • Sampling error decreases
  • Sample size increases

Related Pearl: Concepts in Hypothesis Testing

Probability value (p value)

  • A probability value is the probability of an outcome given the hypothesis.
  • It is not the probability of the hypothesis given the outcome, although the probability of the given hypothesis is not ignored.
  • If the probability of an outcome is sufficiently low, we have evidence that the hypothesis is false.
  • It is also called the p value.

The Null Hypothesis and Alternative Hypothesis

  • The hypothesis that an apparent effect or outcome is only due to chance is a null hypothesis.
  • In other words, a null hypothesis is one where there is no difference between the specified sample and population and any observed difference is due to chance or some other error.
  • A null hypothesis is represented by H0.
  • If the null hypothesis is rejected as false, then there is an alternative or experimental hypothesis (HA), which is logically accepted.

Criterion or Significance Level (α)

  • If the probability value of an outcome is sufficiently low, then the null hypothesis is rejected.
  • This point below which we would define the probability value as being low enough to reject the null hypothesis is called the criterion or significance level or α (alpha) level.
  • When the null hypothesis is rejected, the effect or outcome is said to be statistically significant.
  • By convention (but not always), the level of α is 0.05, i.e., if the probability value of an outcome is less than or equal to 0.05 (p value ≤ 0.05), then the null hypothesis is rejected.
  • If it is greater than 0.05, then the null hypothesis is accepted.
  • Although by convention the level of α is 0.05, it can be lower but cannot be any higher.

Type I Error

  • The interpretation of p value ≤ 0.05 is that an investigator can be 95% sure that the result was not obtained by chance.
  • It also means that there is a 5% probability that the result was obtained by chance.
  • From this, we can deduce that the null hypothesis might indeed be true even though we rejected it.
  • This is a type I error. In other words, when an alternative hypothesis is accepted even when it is false and the null hypothesis is true, it is a type I error or false positive error.
  • It is also called an alpha (α) error as it is related to the criterion α.
  • The lower the α level, the lower the rate of a type I error being made.
  • Thus, it can be said that α is the maximum tolerable probability that a type I error is being made and that the p value is the probability that a significant difference is declared when there is none.

Type II Error

  • The error that is made by rejecting an alternative hypothesis when it is true or failing to reject a null hypothesis when it is false is called a type II error.
  • It is also called a false negative error and more commonly, as a beta (β) error.
  • If the null hypothesis is false, then the probability of a type II error is β.
  • The power of a statistical test is indicated by 1–β.

Power of a Test

  • The power of a test is the ability of a statistical test to avoid a type II error, which depends on its ability to detect a false null hypothesis.
  • It is equal to 1–β, which is the probability that a false null hypothesis will be rejected.
  • By convention, a test is required to have a power of 0.8 (or a β of 0.2) to be acceptable. This is to say that a study that has less than 80% chance of detecting a false null hypothesis is unacceptable.
  • Type I errors are easily reduced by reducing the criterion α.
  • A test's power will increase in the following conditions:
    • If α increases, but this will increase the chance of a type I error.
    • If the difference between the sample mean and hypothesized mean increases. This is also called effect size.
    • If sampling error decreases.
    • If the sample size (n) increases.

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman working in a chemical industry is not given protective masks and goggles. The employer is liable under
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the employer is liable under the Factories (Amendment) Act, 1987.

The Factories Act, 1948 has prescribed in detail the precautions to be taken for ensuring the safety of the workers. Including protective devices (like goggles) and precautions against dangerous fumes.

The Factories Act was amended in the year 1987. It stipulates pre-employment examination as a pre-placement procedure, and statutory periodic medical examination for a job in hazardous areas.

Other options:

Option A- The Maternity Act, 2017: it enhances the duration of paid maternity leave.

Option B- The Employees State Insurance Act, 1948: It provides for certain cash and medical benefits to industrial employees in case of sickness, maternity, and employment injury.

Option C- Rajiv Gandhi Shramik Kalyan Yojna, 2005: It provides an unemployment allowance for the employees covered under the ESI Scheme.

Related Pearl: The Factories act, 1948 and The Maternity Act, 2017

The Factories act,1948

The act defines a factory as an establishment employing 10 or more workers where power is used, and 20 or more workers where power is not used. 

Provisions in the age of employment are:

  • Children <14 years are prohibited from working.
  • Adolescents between 15-18 years:
    • Can be employed only in certain industries.
    • They can work only between 6 AM – 7 PM.
    • They should not be made to work for more than four and a half hours.
    • They are allowed to take leave once every 15 days and have an accumulated leave of up to 40 days.

For adults, the maximum hours of work for an industrial worker should be not more than 48 hours per week, not exceeding 9 hours a day. If working overtime, then it should be no more than 60 hours per week including overtime.

Per capita space availability: For factories established after 1948 – min 500cuft / person

Safety and welfare measures include the provision of the following:

  • > 1000 Workers – Safety officer
  • > 500 Workers – Welfare officer
  • > 250 Workers – Canteen
  • > 50 employees - Crèche

The Maternity Act, 2017 is a landmark law that has enhanced the duration of paid maternity leave:

  • Working mothers - 12-26 weeks
  • Working mothers, with 2 surviving children - 12 weeks
  • Adopting mother and commissioning mothers- 12 weeks from the date on which the child is being handed over to the mother.

According to Indian Maternity Benefit (Amendment) Act, 2017: Effective as of the 1st of July 2017, mandatory crèche (daycare) facilities for every establishment employing 50 or more employees (inclusive of men and women).

questions.text: Aerodynamically respirable quartz dust in which of the following size ranges is most dangerous?
questions.solution:
Quartz dust mainly consists of silicon. A particulate size of 0.5 to 5 µm is considered most dangerous as they are maintained in the airstream over long distances and reach the interior of the lungs with ease.

Other options:

  • Larger Particles (> 5 µm) deposit higher up in the airway.
  • Maximum deposition in the alveolar region occurs for particles of approximately 2 µm and deposition is minimum at about 0.5 µm.
  • For still smaller particles diffusion becomes an effective mechanism thus, though there is an increased probability of deposition that is not the case as they diffuse through the alveolo-capillary membrane into the blood stream.

questions.text: A nuclear disaster occurs in your state. Which of the following drugs is given prophylactically?
questions.solution:
After a nuclear disaster, Potassium Iodide (KI) is given prophylactically to all people exposed/at risk of exposure to radiation. If taken in time and at the appropriate dosage, KI blocks the thyroid gland uptake of radioactive iodine and thus, reduces the risk of thyroid cancers.

Table salt (while it contains KI), does not contain enough iodine to block uptake of radioactive iodine by the thyroid gland.

questions.text: All of the following regarding total fertility rate are true except:

choices.text: It is a measure of completed family size
It is the sum of the age specific fertility rates for all ages
It is the total number of children born to a woman in a given year
The total fertility rate in India in the year 2016 was 2.3

questions.solution:
It is the total number of children a woman would have if she were to pass through her reproductive years bearing children at the same rates as the women now in each age group (and not in a given year).

Related Pearl: Fertility Indicators

Crude birth rate

  • It is the simplest measure of fertility although its usage is unsatisfactory
  • India, as per SRS bulletin 2018, had a birth rate of 20.0 per 1000 population

General Fertility Rate

  • It is a better indicator of fertility than crude birth rate
  • The demerit of this indicator is that not all women in the denominator are exposed to childbirth

Age-specific fertility rates is a more precise measure of fertility and is also a sensitive indicator of family planning achievement.

Total Fertility Rate

  • It is the sum of all age-specific fertility rates multiplied by 5
  • This measure gives the approximate magnitude of completed family size

Gross Reproductive Rate is the average number of girls that would be born to a woman if she experiences the current fertility pattern throughout her reproductive span, assuming no mortality.

Net Reproduction Rate

  • It is a demographic indicator
  • NRR of 1 is equivalent to approximately the 2 child norm
  • If the NRR is less than 1, then the reproductive performance of the population is said to be inadequate

questions.text: The steps of Nalgonda technique in sequence are:

choices.text: Flocculation –> Sedimentation –> Filtration –> Addition of lime and alum
Addition of lime and Alum –> Flocculation –> Sedimentation –> Filtration
Addition of lime and Alum –> Sedimentation –> Filtration –> Flocculation
Addition of lime and Alum –> Disinfection –> Sedimentation –> Filtration

questions.solution:
The steps of Nalgonda Technique of defluoridation of water are as follows:

Addition of Alum (aluminum sulphate), lime (calcium oxide), and bleaching powder followed by rapid mixing, flocculation, sedimentation, filtration and disinfection (chlorination).

questions.text: The estimated average requirement for iron for an Indian Reference man is calculated to be 13 mg/day. Calculate the RDA assuming standard deviation as 2 mg/day.
questions.solution:
The RDA is calculated as the estimated average requirement (EAR) plus twice the standard deviation (SD).

RDA = EAR + (2 × SD)

RDA = 13 + (2 × 2) = 17 mg/day

The Indian Reference man is aged between 18-29 years and weighs 60 kg.

questions.text: Which of the following tests can be used to identify the contamination of mustard oil with argemone oil?
questions.solution:
Detection of contamination of mustard oil with argemone oil can be done by Nitric acid test.

Epidemic dropsy is caused by the toxic compound sanguinarine, which is present in argemone oil extracted from argemone seeds. It is commonly used as an adulterant in mustard oil. Epidemic dropsy results in sudden onset of swelling of lower limbs, diarrhea, and breathlessness. Some patients may develop hypersecretory glaucoma. It can lead to death due to cardiac failure. Adulteration with argemone oil can be detected by the following tests:

  • Paper chromatography (most sensitive test)
  • Nitric acid test 

Phosphatase test (Option A), standard plate count (Option B), and coliform count are used to check whether milk has been pasteurized. A positive test after pasteurization of milk shows contamination after pasteurization.

Methylene blue reduction test (Option D) is an indirect method for the detection of microorganisms in milk. The test is carried out on the milk accepted for pasteurization to check for gross contamination. It is used for grading raw milk quality prior to pasteurization.
