questions.text: With respect to the loss of head in a slow sand filter, which of the following is true?

choices.text: It denotes the humidity of the sand bed
It is measured using a venturi meter and denotes the loss of resistance of the sand bed
It denotes the loss of organic material in the sand bed
An increase in loss of head makes the filter uneconomical

questions.solution:
When the loss of head exceeds 1.3 m, it becomes uneconomical to run the slow sand filter.

Loss of head or bed resistance is measured in a slow sand filter by venturi meter (it denotes the bed resistance not the loss of resistance).

Related Pearl: Slow Sand Filters

  • These are also called biological filters.
  • They are accepted as the standard method of large scale water purification.
  • Essentially, elements of a slow sand filter include
    • Supernatant (raw) water
    • Bed of graded sand
    • Under-drainage system
    • System of filter control valves
  • Supernatant water:
    • It lies above the sand bed and its depth varies from 1 – 1.5 metres.
    • The level of supernatant or raw water is always kept constant and this helps in overcoming the resistance of filter bed, promoting the downward flow of water through the sand bed.
    • It also provides for a waiting period during which the water undergoes partial purification by sedimentation, oxidation and particle agglomeration.
  • Sand bed:
    • This is the most important part of a slow sand filter.
    • Its thickness is generally around 1 metre.
    • The sand grains must be rounded and have an effective diameter of 0.2 – 0.3 mm. They must be clean and free from organic matter.
    • A layer of supporting, graded gravel, 30 – 40 cm deep, prevents the grains from being carried into drainage pipes.
    • The sand bed filters the water as it percolates slowly through it through processes like mechanical straining, oxidation, sedimentation and adsorption.
    • Vital layer: In a new filter, the bed merely acts as a mechanical strainer. But over time the sand bed get covered with a Schmutzdecke/vital layer/zoogleal layer/biological layer. This is a slimy and gelatinous layer that contains algae, diatoms and plankton. The formation of such a layer is the ripening of the filter and this layer is the heart of a slow sand filter. It removes organic matter, prevents bacteria from flowing through and oxidizes ammoniacal nitrogen into nitrates, thus rendering the water bacteria-free.
  • Under-drainage system:
    • A system of porous and perforated pipes, at the bottom of the filter bed, is part of the under-drainage system.
    • They provide an outlet for the filtered water and a support to the filter medium above.
    • The under-drainage system along with the supernatant water and sand bed is kept in a filter box, which is usually 2.5 to 4 metres.
  • Filter control:
    • The outlet-pipe system is provided with valves and other devices which maintain a constant rate of filtration.
    • The Venturi meter measures the bed resistance or the loss of head.
    • When the resistance builds up, the operator opens the regulatory valve to maintain a steady-state of filtration.
    • When the loss of head exceeds 1.5 metres (4 feet), it is uneconomical to run the filter.
    • If the regulatory valve has to be kept fully open as the bed resistance is very high, the filter needs to be cleaned.
    • This is done by scraping the sand bed, which doesn’t need to be done by skilled labor. After several years of operation (say 20 to 30 scrappings) the sand bed can be changed as it would have diminished in size.
  • Advantages of slow sand filters:
    • Simple to construct and operate.
    • Cost of construction is cheap compared to rapid sand filters.
    • Physical, chemical and bacteriological quality of the water is very high which is partially owed to the long duration taken for filtration.
    • Bacteria are cleared more effectively than rapid filters.

questions.text: Blue baby syndrome can be prevented when the levels of nitrates and nitrites in drinking water are respectively less than:
questions.solution:
Methemoglobinemia caused by the decreased ability of blood to carry vital oxygen around the body manifests as blueness around mouth, hands, and feet and is thus known as “blue baby syndrome”.

The most common cause of methemoglobinemia is the high levels of nitrates in drinking water.

High levels of nitrate may be due to intensive farming practices with excess use of fertilizers. The group at the highest risk are bottle-fed infants.

Control of nitrate and nitrites respectively below 50 mg /litre and 3mg/litre is an effective preventive measure.

Related Pearl: WHO Guidelines for Drinking Water Quality, 2017

WHO Guidelines for Drinking Water Quality, 2017

I) Physical parameters:

  Guideline values Comments
Turbidity Ideally, no visible turbidity but permissible standard is < 1.0 NTU (nephelometric turbidity units) for household drinking water. 

It describes the cloudiness of water.

  • >4 NTU – cloudiness visible to naked eye.
  • <4 NTU – measured only by instruments. 
Color Ideally, no visible color but permissible standard is <15 TCU (true color units).  >15 TCU is detectable by the naked eye. 

Taste, odor and temperature

 No health based guideline values It may be indicative of contamination and pollution. High water temperature may enhance growth of microorganisms and influence taste, odor and color.

 

II) Chemical parameters:

  Guideline values
Ammonia

No health based guideline value.

Natural levels in surface and ground water is 0.2 mg/l. Anaerobic groundwater may have up to 3 mg/l.
Aluminium up to 0.9 mg/l
Arsenic

up to 0.01 mg/l

Levels in natural water range from 1 to 2 µg/l.
Chloride

250 mg/l, as above this a detectable taste appears.

Maximum permissible level is 600 mg/l. Sodium thiosulphate can be used to dechlorinate drinking water or tap water.
Copper

up to 2 mg/l.

Excess copper in water can have gastrointestinal effects.
Fluoride

up to 1.5 mg/l. Above this, there is risk of dental and skeletal fluorosis.

Artificial fluoridation range is 0.5 to 1.0 mg/l.
Hydrogen sulphide

Taste and odor threshold is between 0.05 and 0.1 mg/litre.

A rotten egg smell of water indicates hydrogen sulphide.
Nitrates 50 mg/l as nitrate ion, to prevent methaemoglobinaemia and thyroid effects
Nitrites 3 mg/l as nitrite ion, to prevent methemoglobinemia in bottle-fed infants and general population.
pH Acceptable pH is in the range of 6.5 – 8.5.
Lead

up to 0.01 mg/l

The concentration of lead must be kept as low as possible. It is the most undesirable metal in drinking water.
Mercury

0.006 mg/l for inorganic mercury

It is nephrotoxic
Polyaromatic hydrocarbons (PAH)

Benzo(a)pyrene up to 0.0007 mg/l

They are to be kept in traces as they are carcinogenic/mutagenic
Sodium Above 200 mg/l may give an unacceptable taste.
Total Dissolved Solids (TDS)

Less than 600 mg/l is generally considered palatable.

TDS consists of inorganic salts and small amounts of organic matter dissolved in water. Water is completely unpalatable above 1200mg/l.

 

III) Biological indicators:

  • Total coliform bacteria:
    • They are the primary bacterial indicators for drinking water.
    • Total coliforms are good indicators of water disinfection because they are abundant in the human intestine and are foreign to potable water.
    • E. coli is considered the best indicator of fecal contamination of water when resources for supplementary microbiological examination are limited.
    • Guidelines state that coliforms must not be detectable in 100ml of sample water. 
    • Multiple tubes method:
      • This is a test of bacteriological surveillance of drinking water for coliforms and thereby fecal contamination.
      • This test is based on the most probable number (MPN) of coliform organisms.
      • Acid and gas production from fermentation due to coliforms are observed for in multiple tubes and a presumptive coliform count is arrived at.
      • Confirmation of E. coli can be done by testing for indole formation at 44-45 degrees Celsius or by another test called Eijkman test.
    • Faecal streptococci: Their presence in water indicates recent contamination with feces and are regarded as specific indicators of human faecal pollution.
    • Clostridium perfringens: They are spore-forming organisms that are resistant to many disinfection methods. They are used as an indicator of protozoa in water and also of remote/intermittent fecal contamination. Their spores are also indicators of the effectiveness of filtration processes.
    • Viruses like enteric viruses can also be used as indicators of the disinfection process.
    • Heterotrophic plate counts measure a wide range of heterotrophic organisms including bacteria and fungi.
    • Coliphages and Bacteroides fragilis phages are evidence of fecal contamination of water. 

IV) Radiological aspects:

  • The proposed guidelines for gross alpha activity is 0.5 Bq/litre and for gross beta activity, it is 1.0 Bq/litre of drinking water.

questions.text: What is the function of the instrument shown below?

choices.text: To protect an air thermometer against radiant heat
To measure the humidity content of the air
To measure precipitation levels in the surrounding area

questions.solution:
The image shows a “Stevenson Screen”. It protects an air thermometer against radiant heat, while maintain free access of air at the bulbs of the thermometers which are mounted inside it.

Other options:

  • Humidity content of air is measured using: Dry and wet hygrometer, sling psychrometer or Assmann psychrometer.
  • Precipitation levels are measured using: Symon’s Rain gauge.

questions.text: The co-factor of isocitrate dehydrogenase in the TCA cycle is:
questions.solution:
The isocitrate dehydrogenase (IDH) isoform that participates in the TCA cycle is IDH3 and uses NAD+ as co-factor. It is exclusively present in the mitochondria.

There are two other isoforms – IDH1 and IDH2, that use NADP+ as co-factor. They are found in both the mitochondria and the cytosol.

questions.text: The oxygen debt seen after exercise is due to?
questions.solution: Oxygen debt seen after exercise is due to increased gluconeogenesis. In exercise, anaerobic glycolysis takes place and the lactate formed enters the gluconeogenic pathway in the liver. Regeneration of a glucose molecule from lactate requires 6 ATPs whereas the ATP provided by anaerobic glycolysis is only 2 per molecule of glucose. This energy gap is met through oxidative phosphorylation and the oxygen consumed in the process makes up the oxygen debt.

questions.text: Lipoprotein lipase is not active in?
questions.solution:
Lipoprotein lipase is not active in the adult liver. This prevents the degradation of chylomicrons and VLDL in the liver. Instead, the liver has hepatic lipase that is involved in the degradation of chylomicron remnants and HDL.

Lipoprotein lipase is found in the heart, lung, adipose tissue, renal medulla, aorta, diaphragm, lactating mammary gland and spleen.

questions.text: The fraction of the conjugated bilirubin that binds to albumin is called?
questions.solution: The fraction of conjugated bilirubin that binds to albumin is called delta bilirubin (δ-bilirubin). This fraction remains bound to albumin even after serum conjugated bilirubin level falls in mixed/obstructive jaundice. As a result, patients appear jaundiced though conjugated bilirubin level are normal.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a core histone?
questions.solution:
H1 histone is not a core histone.

H1 histones are the least tightly bound to chromatin so they can easily be removed with a salt solution. They interact with DNA as it enters and exits the nucleosome. It is not a part of the nucleosome. 

H2A, H2B, H3, and H4 are called core histones. They form octamers made up of two units of each core histone. DNA is wrapped around this octamer to form a nucleosome. Nucleosomes are the organizational unit of the soluble chromatin.

The following image represents a nucleosome. 

Related Pearl: Role of Histones

Types

Function

H1 histones

Stabilize the 30-nm chromatin fiber

H2 histones

H2A–H2B dimers stabilize the primary particle and firmly bind two additional half-turns of DNA

H3 histones

(H3–H4)2 tetramer has a central role in the formation

of the nucleosome

H4 histones

questions.text: Identify the product formed by 12-lipoxygenase acting alone:
questions.solution:
Of the three types of lipoxygenase, 12-lipoxygenase and 15-lipoxygenase form hydroperoxides (HPETE) when they act alone. Only 5-lipoxygenase forms leukotrienes.

Lipoxins are formed by the combined action of 5-lipoxygenase and 12 or 15-lipoxygenase.

questions.text: Identify the enzyme that synthesizes galactose from glucose:
questions.solution:
Galactose can be synthesiszed from glucose by the enzyme UDPGal 4-epimerase. Hence, galactose is not an essential dietary carbohydrate. Galactose is required for the formation of lactose in lactation and is also a constituent of cerebrosides, proteoglycans, and glycoproteins.

Other options:

  • Lactose synthase forms lactose from glucose and galactose.
  • Phosphoglucomutase interconverts between glucose-6-phosphate and glucose-1-phosphate
  • Aldolase A & C preferentially cleave fructose–1,6 bisphosphate into dihydroxyacetone phosphate and glyceraldehyde 3-phosphate. Aldolase B cleaves fructose-1 phosphate into dihydroxyacetone phosphate and glyceraldehyde.

questions.text: Which of the following has the lowest glycemic index?
questions.solution:
Artificial sweeteners such as saccharin, acesulfame K, aspartame and sucralose have an effective glycemic index of zero because they do not affect glucose metabolism.

Other options:

  • Inverted sugar is an equimolar mixture of glucose and fructose and has a glycemic index around 60.
  • Brown rice has a glycemic index around 68 which is relatively lower compared to white rice.
  • Sugar alcohols such as glycerol, sorbitol, mannitol, and lactitol have single-digit glycemic indices.

questions.text: What causes the spinal cord degeneration seen in pernicious anaemia?
questions.solution:
The spinal cord degeneration seen in pernicious anaemia is due to methionine deficiency.

Vitamin B12 deficiency reduces regeneration of methionine from homocysteine which in turn affects methylation of amino acid residues in the CNS. This causes the following changes

  • Posterolateral cord degeneration: Also known as subacute combined degeneration, it presents with loss of proprioception, vibration, positive Romberg sign, ataxia, hyperreflexia, spasticity
  • Dementia leading to cognitive impairment
  • Peripheral neuropathy: presenting as muscle weakness, paraesthesia
  • Optic atrophy

There is also an increase in homocysteine level which increases the risk of cardiovascular disease.

questions.text: A genetic scientist was studying the mechanisms occurring after transcriptional events in eukaryotic cells mRNA. One such process is the polyadenylation of mRNA, which protects against the degradation of mRNA by which enzyme?
questions.solution:
Polyadenylation of mRNA protects against degradation by 3’ exonucleases.

5’ capping protects the mRNA against attacks by 5’ exonucleases. Sequences in the 5’ and 3’ ends as well as in the coding region of the mRNA are thought to either protect against or facilitate endonuclease action.

After synthesis, eukaryotic RNA undergoes extensive post-transcriptional modifications including 7-methylguanosine capping, polyadenylation forming poly-A tail, and splicing.

  • 5' Capping: This is the first of the processing reactions for pre-mRNA. The cap is a 7-methylguanosine attached backward to the 5'-terminal end of the mRNA, forming an unusual 5'→5' triphosphate linkage.
  • Poly-A tail is added after transcription by the nuclear enzyme, polyadenylate polymerase, using ATP as the substrate. These tails help stabilize the mRNA, facilitate its exit from the nucleus, and aid in translation.
  • Splicing: The maturation of eukaryotic mRNA usually involves the removal of introns and joining of exons together to form the mature mRNA. The process of removing introns and joining exons is called splicing. snRNA facilitates the removal of introns by forming base pairs with the consensus sequences at each end of the intron.

Image depicting the steps of transcription:

questions.text: How many molecules of ATP are needed to synthesis one molecule of urea?
questions.solution:
3 molecules of ATP are required for the synthesis of one molecule of urea.

Related Pearl: Urea Cycle and its disorders

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy complains of right-sided flank pain radiating to the groin and passage of blood in urine. A KUB X-ray ordered by the physician is normal while urinalysis reveals hexagonal translucent crystals in urine. Which of the following is found in the urine in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical findings are suggestive of cystinuria and lysine is excreted in the urine along with arginine, ornithine, and dimers of cysteine called cystine.

The condition becomes symptomatic with the formation of cystine calculi in the renal tract. The calculi are radiolucent on X-ray and the excretion of hexagonal/benzene shaped translucent crystals in the urine is pathognomic. The urine may also have a rotten odor due to the sulfur present in cystine.

Treatment:

Initial treatment is with adequate hydration, alkalization of the urine with citrate supplementation or acetazolamide, and dietary modification to reduce salt and protein intake.

If this fails, patients are usually started on chelation therapy with penicillamine.

 

Note: In cystinuria, cysteine is not found in the urine and only dimers of cysteine called cystine is present. Hence, between lysine and cysteine, lysine is the better choice.

questions.text: Flavin mononucleotide is a part of which electron transport chain complex?
questions.solution:
FMN is a component of electron transport chain complex I.

It participates in the transfer of electrons from NADH to Q (Quinone) via Fe-S proteins and four protons are driven out of the mitochondrial matrix into the intermembrane space in the process.

Complex II is coupled with succinate dehydrogenase and uses FAD for the transfer of electrons.

Complex III uses cytochromes c1, bL, bH and a Rieske Fe-S (unusual non-heme protein where Fe is linked to two histidine residues instead of cysteine) while complex IV uses two heme groups a and a3 and copper (Cu) containing proteins CuA and CuB.

questions.text: Ammonia production in the renal tubules is increased in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Renal glutaminase increases in metabolic acidosis and more ammonia is released from glutamine. The ammonia binds to protons (H+) in the tubular lumen and is excreted as ammonium in the urine.

Hepatic glutaminase increases in high protein intake and generates ammonia for urea synthesis.

questions.text: Pan-acinar emphysema associated with liver cirrhosis is seen in the deficiency of which of the following?
questions.solution:
α1 anti-proteinase deficiency is associated with pan-acinar emphysema and liver cirrhosis.

α1 anti-proteinase is a protease inhibitor that inhibits the activity of trypsin, elastase, and other serine proteases.

Its deficiency is caused by mutations that alter its structure and prevent release from hepatocytes. Accumulation of polymeric aggregates of α1 anti-proteinase in the hepatocytes leads to liver cirrhosis.

The emphysema is due to the unopposed action of neutrophil elastases which destroy the alveolar walls.

questions.text: What happens to the metabolic rate after a meal?
questions.solution: The metabolic rate increases after a meal and this increase is called diet induced thermogenesis. It is mostly due to the synthesis of glycogen, triacylglycerol and proteins. Secretion of digestive enzymes and active transport of the products of digestion also contribute to the rise.

questions.text: Micro-dehiscence of the Bruch membrane is seen in?
questions.solution:
Micro-dehiscences of the Bruch membrane called Lacquer cracks are seen in pathological myopia. The cracks are formed when a posterior staphyloma stretches the Bruch membrane beyond its elastic limit.

Pathological/degenerative myopia: It is characterized by progressive anteroposterior elongation of the scleral envelope associated
with secondary ocular changes due to the mechanical stretching of the involved tissues. Following changes are seen:

  • A Pale tessellated (tigroid) appearance of the fundus is seen as the choroid becomes visible due to diffuse attenuation of the RPE
  • Temporal myopic crescent
  • Focal chorioretinal atrophy
  • Anomalous optic nerve head with tilted conformation
  • Acquired optic disc pit formation
  • Lattice degeneration
  • Cystoid degeneration
  • Lacquer cracks are fine irregular yellow lines crisscrossing at the posterior pole, due to ruptures in Bruch membrane.
  • Subretinal coin hemorrhages developing from lacquer cracks.
  • Fuchs spot: It is a raised, circular, pigmented scar at the macula which develops after absorption of subretinal hemorrhage.
  • Posterior staphyloma

questions.text: A 0.5D myope undergoes streak retinoscopy. The patient is seated one meter from the light source and is asked to fixate on a distant object as the retinoscopy is performed. The red reflex in the eye exhibits?
questions.solution:
In patients with myopia less than 1D, the red reflex exhibits with movement when retinoscopy is done without cycloplegia from a one-meter distance. With movement is also seen in emmetropes and hypermetropes.

Against movement is seen in those with myopia greater than 1D.

No movement is seen in 1D myopes.

Oblique movement is seen in astigmatism.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman complains of aching pain over her right eyebrow. The pain occurs mostly in the evenings and is relieved by sleep. On inquiry, the patient reports seeing rainbow-colored rings around lights and blurring of vision during these episodes. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The history is suggestive of subacute angle closure. In subacute angle-closure, the anterior chamber angle is occluded intermittently, causing rise in IOP and headache or brow ache.

The pain typically occurs in the evening due to mydriasis in dim light and accommodation in close work. These changes cause crowding of the iris at the anterior chamber angle and also bring the lens close to the iris, thereby blocking aqueous outflow. Colored halos and blurred vision are seen during the episode if corneal edema is present. The episodes usually resolve with sleep.

Gonioscopy reveals a narrow-angle and sometimes, peripheral anterior synechiae. Repeated attacks cause extensive anterior angle synechiae and may lead on to acute or chronic angle-closure glaucoma.

Peripheral laser iridotomy is done in the affected eye to prevent further attacks and complications.

questions.text: Epidemic keratoconjunctivitis is not treated with _______________
questions.solution:
Epidemic keratoconjunctivitis is caused by adenovirus serotypes 3, 7, 8, and 19 and antiviral therapy is not indicated.

The condition is characterised by follicular conjunctivitis associated with preauricular lymphadenopathy. A conjunctival membrane may form in 7-10 days and the cornea could also be involved with punctate epithelial infiltrates and discrete subepithelial opacities.

Treatment is non-specific with lubricants and decongestive drops for relief of discomfort. Antibiotic drops prevent secondary bacterial infection.

questions.text: The abnormality shown in the image below is caused by over-action of _______________
questions.solution:
Over-action of the inferior oblique muscles causes V pattern strabismus. Exotropia appears on upward gaze due to exaggerated abduction caused by overacting inferior oblique muscles. It may be associated with paresis of superior oblique muscles and convergence on downgaze.

Over-action of the superior oblique and paresis of the inferior oblique are associated with A pattern strabismus.

questions.text: Identify the cataract shown in the image below:
questions.solution:
The image shows sutural cataract with Y shaped anterior suture and inverted Y shaped posterior suture opacifications. The sutural opacities are located in the nucleus of the lens and cause little visual disturbance. Surgery is not usually required.

Other options:

Zonular cataract is an opaque ring usually seen in the foetal nucleus of the lens. The ring is formed by defective lens fibres produced during a particular period of development. Other lens fibres are normal. It accounts for about half of all visually significant congenital cataracts.

Coronary cataracts are club-shaped peripheral opacities present in the deep cortex and the superficial nucleus of the lens. They are not progressive and don’t usually affect vision.

Fusiform cataracts are spindle-shaped anteroposterior cataracts that have a genetic association and run in families. They are also called spindle-shaped, axial or coralliform cataracts. They may be associated with polar cataracts.

questions.text: What is the definitive treatment for tarsal cysts?
questions.solution:
Chalazion is also known as tarsal or meibomian cyst and the definitive treatment is incision and curettage.

A chalazion is a chronic inflammatory granuloma formed due to the retention of meibomian secretions. The swelling is painless and non-tender. On everting the eyelid, a nodule is seen and the overlying conjunctiva is red or purple in color. Long-standing lesions form a jelly-like mass and the overlying conjunctiva appears grey.

Definitive treatment involves incising the swelling, draining the contents and curetting the walls. A vertical incision is made to avoid damage to adjacent meibomian ducts. Intralesional injection of triamcinolone acetate can be tried in small lesions before performing incision and curettage.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a defining feature of medial longitudinal fasciculus lesions?
questions.solution:
Convergence insufficiency may or may not be associated with medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF) lesions. Impaired convergence implies that the lesion involves the input/output of the oculomotor nerve nucleus in the midbrain.

Damage to the medial longitudinal fasciculus causes internuclear ophthalmoplegia. The medial longitudinal fasciculus connects the oculomotor nerve nucleus on one side with the abducens nucleus and paramedian pontine reticular formation (PPRF) on the other. A lesion on one side affects lateral gaze towards the opposite side Thus, if the right medial longitudinal fasciculus is damaged, right eye adduction paresis and left eye nystagmus are seen on gazing to the left.

questions.text: The device shown in the image below is used to assess:
questions.solution: The image shows a Placido’s keratoscope used to assess corneal topography. It consists of multiple concentric circles from which light is projected onto the corneal surface. The reflection is viewed through a small hole in the centre or captured using a video camera for analysis. The reflection is distorted in corneal curvature abnormalities such as keratoconus. Software analysis can reveal additional information such as corneal power and render surface maps of the cornea.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with a right-sided blurring of vision for 3 months. The blurring is more for near vision and is not progressive. The right pupil is larger than the left and doesn’t react to light. On applying 0.1% pilocarpine, the right pupil becomes smaller than the left. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features suggest a diagnosis of Adie’s tonic pupil. This condition is usually unilateral and is caused by damage to the postganglionic parasympathetic neurons supplying the pupillary sphincter. The following findings are seen in the affected eye.

  • The affected pupil is larger and doesn’t react to light.
  • On applying a weak solution of pilocarpine (0.1%), the affected pupil becomes smaller than the other pupil due to denervation supersensitivity.
  • The affected pupil constricts very slowly on testing the near reflex due to aberrant innervation of the pupillary sphincter by ciliary muscle nerve fibers.

It is more common in young women and its etiology is uncertain. It may follow a viral illness. Absent knee jerk on the same side may be associated with this condition in which case it is known as Holmes - Adie Syndrome.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman complains of a creepy crawling sensation in her legs associated with an irresistible urge to move the legs. It is more at night and prevents her from sleeping. Which of the following drugs is considered as the drug of choice in treating her condition?
questions.solution:
The history is suggestive of restless leg syndrome and gabapentinoids are now considered as the drug of choice in treating this condition. 

Restless leg syndrome is a typical sensory-motor disorder that generally affects the legs during rest periods, especially during sleep. There is an irresistible urge to shake the legs associated with a burning sensation, itching, and cramps of the legs. In idiopathic cases, dopaminergic hypofunction is postulated.

In patients with restless legs syndrome, iron stores are initially repleted, and the aggravating factors are eliminated. If RLS still persists, initial therapy with a gabapentinoid (pregabalin, gabapentin, gabapentin enacarbil) is preferred, rather than a dopamine agonist (pramipexole, ropinirole, rotigotine). This is due to the high frequency of intermediate and long-term augmentation with dopamine agonists, as well as their risk of impulse control disorders.

FDA-approved drugs for the treatment of restless leg syndrome: 

  • Gabapentin
  • Ropinirole
  • Pramipexole
  • Rotigotine 

A dopamine agonist is used as an alternative in patients with increased risk for side effects from gabapentinoids, such as those with obesity and its complications, a past or present history of moderate to severe depression, a disorder causing gait instability or respiratory failure, and a history of substance use disorder.

Non-pharmacological treatments that can be used in restless leg syndrome are:

  • Avoiding alcohol at bedtime
  • Massaging affected legs
  • Hot baths
  • Applying hot or cold to the affected area
  • Engaging in moderate exercises

Other options:

Option A- Fluoxetine is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor that binds to serotonin transporter and inhibits its transport. They are mainly indicated in depression, obsessive-compulsive disorder, panic disorder, social phobia, and posttraumatic stress disorder. 

Option B- Clozapine is a second-generation antipsychotic that is an antagonist to 5HT2A and D2 receptors. They are mainly used in refractory schizophrenia and refractory mania. 

Option D- Imipramine is a tricyclic antidepressant that inhibits serotonin receptor transporter, norepinephrine transporter. They also block H1 histamine, 5HT2, alpha 1 adrenergic, muscarinic 1 receptors. They are indicated in major depression.

questions.text: Tourette’s disorder is diagnosed in the presence of ________________
questions.solution:
Tourette's disorder is diagnosed only if both motor and vocal tics are present. The following are the DSM-5 criteria for a diagnosis of Tourette’s disorder.

  • Multiple motor tics and at least one vocal tic during the course of the disease
  • Disease onset before 18 years of age
  • Persistence of the disorder for more than one year since the first tic
  • Disturbance must not be due to substance abuse or a medical condition (such as encephalitis)

questions.text: A 23-year-old man comes to the psychiatric outpatient department complaining of depression and loneliness. History taking reveals that he does not engage in any social activity because he’s afraid of being rejected. Identify the likely personality disorder in this patient:
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of avoidant personality disorder, as the patient does not engage in social activities due to fear of being rejected.

Avoidant personality disorder is characterized by extreme sensitivity to rejection leading to socially withdrawn lives, low levels of energy, easy fatigability, lack of enthusiasm, and inability to enjoy life.

Other options:

Option B: Paranoid personality disorder is characterized by unwarranted suspicion, hypersensi­tivity, jealousy, envy, rigidity, excessive self-importance, and a tendency to blame and ascribe evil motives to others.

 Option C: Schizoid personality disorder is characterized by shyness, oversensitivity, seclusive­ ness, avoidance of close or competitive relationships, eccentric­ity, no loss of capacity to recognize reality, daydreaming, and an ability to express hostility and aggression.

 Option D: Antisocial personal­ity disorder covers persons in conflict with society. They are incapable of loyalty, selfish, callous, irresponsible, impulsive, and unable to feel guilt or learn from experience; they have low levels of frustration tolerance and a tendency to blame others.

Related Pearl: Personality Disorders

Key features of Personality disorders

Cluster A (Odd, Weird, Eccentric)
Paranoid
Suspicious, distrustful, hypervigilant
Schizoid
Prefers to be loner, detached, unemotional
Schizotypal
Eccentric & odd thoughts, perceptions & behavior, magical thinking and beliefs

Cluster B (Dramatic, Emotional and Erratic)
Antisocial
Disregard for and violation of rights of others, illegal activities
Borderline
Chaotic relationships, sensitivity to abandonment, labile mood, impulsivity, inner emptiness, self-harm
Histrionic
Dramatic, superficial, attention-seeking
Narcissistic
Grandiosity, lack of empathy

Cluster C (Anxious, Fearful, Introvert)
Avoidant
Avoidance due to fears of criticism and rejection
Dependent
Submissive, clingy, needs to be taken care of
Obsessive-compulsive/
Anankastic
 
Rigid, controlling, perfectionist

questions.text: What is the treatment of choice for postpartum blues?
questions.solution:
Postpartum blues is common in mothers in the puerperal period and requires nothing more than education and support. It is characterised by a labile mood, sadness and subjective confusion. It is thought to be due to changes in hormone levels, the stress of childbirth and anxiety about the responsibilities of motherhood.

If symptoms last longer than 2 weeks, an evaluation for postpartum depression is needed.

Related Pearl: Postpartum mood disorders

Disorders and features Incidence and timeline Harmful thoughts Treatment

Postpartum blues:

Depressed affect, tearfulness and fatigue

30-75%

Starts 2-3 days after delivery. Resolves within 10 days.

 No thoughts of harming the baby Support and follow up

Postpartum depression:

Depressed affect, anxiety, and poor concentration

10-15%

Starts within 4 weeks from delivery (DSM 5) or 6 weeks (ICD 11) and persists for ≥ 2 weeks. 

 Thoughts of harming the baby often present CBT and SSRIs 

Postpartum psychosis:

Mood-congruent delusions, hallucinations

0.1-0.2%

Onset within 4 weeks postpartum (DSM 5) or 6 weeks (ICD 11)

 Thoughts of harming the baby or self Hospitalization, atypical antipsychotics and ECT for refractory cases

Note: Zuranolone is the first-ever oral drug to be FDA-approved specifically for the treatment of postpartum depression. It is a neuroactive steroid that enhances the action of GABA in the brain and regulates mood.

questions.text: Which of the following brain regions is primarily affected in delirium?
questions.solution:
The brain region primarily affected in delirium is the reticular formation which regulates attention and arousal.

The pathway that is primarily involved is the dorsal tegmental pathway which connects the mesencephalic reticular formation with the tectum and the thalamus.

The major neurotransmitter involved is acetylcholine.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the WHO analgesic ladder for chronic pain in adults?

choices.text: Non-opioids are preferred over opioids initially
Opioids are considered only in step 3

questions.solution:
The true statement is Non-opioids are preferred over opioids initially.

WHO has developed 3 step ladder for chronic/cancer pain relief in adults.

The 3 main principles are as follows:

  • By the clock: Drugs should be given “by the clock” or “around the clock” rather than “on demand”.
  • By the mouth: Oral route is preferred. If not feasible, the least invasive route should be considered.
  • By the ladder: Drugs are given in the following order, Non-opioids → Mild opioids → Strong opioids. Adjuvants are added at any stage of WHO ladder to relieve anxiety.

This 3-step ladder approach is inexpensive and 80-90% effective when utilized optimally.

questions.text: The pre-anesthetic evaluation of a 33-year-old male who has been posted for surgery is conducted, and the oral cavity examined is as depicted in the image given below. This would be______________ according to Mallampati classification.
questions.solution:
Since the soft palate, fauces, and part of the uvula are seen, this is graded as Mallampati class II.

Mallampati classification: Here the size of the tongue in relation to the oral cavity is assessed. The greater the tongue obstructs the view of the pharyngeal structures, the more difficult the intubation.

Mallampati class III and class IV are considered risk factors for difficult ventilation.

Related Pearl: Predictors of Difficult Airway

Risk factors:

  1. Obstructive sleep apnea
  2. History of snoring
  3. Obesity
  4. Facial and neck deformities from previous surgery
  5. Previous head and neck radiation
  6. Head and neck trauma
  7. Congenital abnormalities of the head and neck
  8. Rheumatoid arthritis
  9. Down syndrome
  10. Scleroderma
  11. Cervical spine disease or previous cervical spine surgery

Specific tests for assessment:

  1. Mallampati scores (III and IV)
  2. Thyromental distance less than 6 cm
  3. Sterno-mental distance <12.5 cm with head in maximum extension
  4. Increased neck circumference >17 inches in men or >16 inches in women
  5. Upper lip bite test: Inability to protrude the mandible or lower teeth in front of the upper teeth
  6. Cormack and Lehane (laryngoscopic view) - Grade III and IV

Although the presence of these risk factors may not be sensitive in detecting difficult intubation, the absence of these findings indicates ease with intubation.

Related Pearl: Samsoon & Young's Modified Mallampati Classification

Samsoon & Young's Modified Mallampati Classification is used to predict the ease of endotracheal intubation.

• Class I: The entire palatal arch, including the bilateral faucial pillars, is visible down to the bases of the pillars.
• Class II: The upper part of the faucial pillars and most of the uvula are visible.
• Class III: Only the soft and hard palates are visible.
• Class IV: Only the hard palate is visible.

Initially, the Mallampatti scoring system (1985) had only 3 classes. This was modified by Samsoon and Young to include class 4. Later class 0 was also added.

questions.text: Pin index given for the mixture of CO2 and O2 gas with less than 7% CO2 is  ?
questions.solution:
Pin index system for mixture of CO2 and O2 gas with less than 7% CO2 is 2, 6.

Pin index system for mixture of CO2 and O2 gas with more than 7% CO2 is 1, 6.

Pin index safety system (PISS) is a safety measure to prevent incorrect cylinder attachment.

Related Pearl: Pin index safety system (PISS):

Note:

  • Mixtures of CO2 and O2 with more than 7% CO2: 1,6
  • Mixtures of CO2 and O2 with less than 7% CO2: 2,6

questions.text: Which of the following opioids follow the marked graphical representation (A) in the given image?
questions.solution:
The graph is of the ceiling effect of opioids i.e. with some opioids when the ceiling is reached further increment in dose does not increase the effect. Morphine does not show the ceiling effect. 

The ceiling effect is particularly seen with respiratory depression i.e. higher doses do not produce further respiratory depression. Respiratory depression increases proportionally with dose.

The following opioids show a ceiling effect:

  • Buprenorphine
  • Butorphanol
  • Nalbuphine
  • Pentazocine

Related Pearl: Ceiling effect of opioids

Drug Correlation of Respiratory Depression With Dose
Morphine

Increases proportionally with dose (i.e. no ceiling effect)
Buprenorphine

Ceiling effect at 0.15-1.2 mg in adults
Butorphanol

Ceiling effect at 30-60 μg/kg
Nalbuphine

Ceiling effect at 30 mg in adults
Pentazocine 

Ceiling effect suggested

questions.text: What is the recommended range of bispectral index for general anesthesia?
questions.solution:
Recommended range of Bispectral index (BIS) for anesthesia is 40-60.

 Bispectral index

  • It is the monitoring technique used to check the depth of anesthesia.
  • First quantitative electroencephalographic index used in clinical practice to assess the depth of anesthesia.
  • Individual intraoperative awareness is evaluated.
  • It utilizes parameters like EEG signals, eye blinking, etc
  • It has numerical values from 0 to 100 with 0 representing isoelectric EEG and 100 being awake
  • Recommended range of Bispectral index (BIS) for anesthesia- 40-60.
BIS value    Interpretation
   80 - 100 Awake
    60-80 Moderate sedation
    40-60 General anesthesia
    <40 Deep anesthesia

questions.text: The lateral compartment of the leg contains all of the following muscles except ______
questions.solution:
Peroneus tertius is a part of anterior compartment of leg.

Muscles of anterior compartment: These produce dorsiflexion (extension) of the ankle. It consists of two of the muscles, extensor digitorum longus and extensor hallucis longus, which also extend the toes, and two muscles, tibialis anterior and peroneus tertius, have the additional actions of inversion and eversion of the foot.

Muscles of posterior compartment: They include superficial and deep groups, separated by the transverse intermuscular septum.

  • Superficial flexor group: Gastrocnemius, plantaris and soleus
  • Posterior flexor group: Popliteus, flexor digitorum longus, flexor hallucis longus and tibialis posterior.

Muscles of lateral compartment: Fibularis (peroneus) longus and fibularis (peroneus) brevis.

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the anatomy of epiglottis?

choices.text: The laryngeal surface is lined by stratified squamous non- keratinized epithelium

questions.solution:
Epiglottis has bilateral lymphatic supply.

Rest all statements are false.

Epiglottis:

The epiglottis is a thin, leaf-like plate of elastic cartilage that projects obliquely upwards behind the tongue and hyoid body, and in front of the laryngeal inlet. The cartilage is posteriorly pitted by small mucous glands.

It has two surfaces namely:

  • Upper anterior or lingual surface covered by nonkeratinized stratified squamous epithelium.
  • Smooth posterior or laryngeal surface covered by ciliated respiratory mucosa.

questions.text: All of the following statements are true regarding perineal membrane except:

choices.text: The posterior border is attached medially to perineal body
Apex is attached to arcuate ligament of pubis

questions.solution:
The perineal membrane is perforated by the urethra in both male and female.

The perineum is an approximately diamond-shaped region that lies below levator ani, between the inner aspects of the thighs and anterior to the sacrum and coccyx. It supports the pelvic floor.

The perineum is bounded:

  • Anteriorly by pubic symphysis and apex is attached to arcuate ligament of pubis.
  • Posteriorly by coccyx and the posterior border is attached medially to perineal body.
  • Anterolaterally by the ischiopubic rami and ischial tuberosities.
  • Postero-laterally by the sacro-tuberous ligaments.

An arbitrary line joining the ischial tuberosities (the inter-ischial line) divides the perineum into an anterior urogenital triangle and a posterior anal triangle.

questions.text: All are tributaries of coronary sinus except:
questions.solution:
Anterior cardiac vein opens directly in the anterior wall of right atrium. Hence, it is not a tributary of coronary sinus.

Thebesian vein/venae cordis minimae, anterior cardiac veins of RV and right marginal vein drain directly into the right atrium.

Most of the veins of the heart drain into the coronary sinus.

Tributaries of coronary sinus include the following:

  • Great cardiac vein
  • Middle cardiac vein
  • Small cardiac vein
  • Posterior cardiac vein
  • Oblique vein of left atrium

questions.text: Secondary oocyte is formed after:
questions.solution:
Secondary oocyte is formed after the first meiosis (Meiosis 1).

Primary oocyte completes Meiosis I to form 2 daughter cells:

  • The Secondary Oocyte
  • First polar body

questions.text: Which of the following is not an anatomical ureteric constriction?
questions.solution:
The regions of the ureter which prevent renal calculi from passing freely are nothing but the ureteric constrictions.

The ureter is constricted at 5 places:

  1. At the pelvic ureteric junction
  2. At the brim of the lesser pelvis (as it crosses the common Iliac artery)
  3. At the site of crossing of the ureter by ductus deferens or broad ligament of the uterus.
  4. Vesico-ureteric junction
  5. At its opening in the lateral angle of the trigone

These are regarded as surgical constrictions of the ureter.

However, the anatomical constrictions are only three of them (1, 2, and 4).

Clinical note: The constrictions are what prevent renal calculi from passing freely, of these the vesico-ureteric junction is the narrowest and can be responsible for arresting the passage of stones of as little as 2–3 mm.

Note: Above image shows the Xray identification of Vesico-ureteric junction as ischial spine, Ischial spine is an X-ray landmark but with no anatomical relation.

questions.text: The type of joint involved in side to side movements of the neck is?
questions.solution:
Joint for side to side movements in neck is atlanto-axial joint which is a type of pivot joint.

Movement in the atlanto-axial joints are simultaneous and consists almost exclusively of rotation around the axis, which helps a person look to the right and left. 

  • The normal range of atlanto-axial rotation is about 40°.
  • The orientation and shape of the atlanto-occipital joints allow mainly for flexion–extension, which has a total range of about 15°.

Pivot joint:

In pivot joint, one bone rotates in relation to another bone.

This is a uniaxial joint, and thus rotation is the only motion allowed at a pivot joint.

Eg:

  • Atlantoaxial joint: the first cervical (C1) vertebra (atlas) rotates around the dens, the upward projection from the second cervical (C2) vertebra (axis). This allows the head to rotate from side to side as when shaking the head “no.”
  • The proximal radioulnar joint is a pivot joint formed by the head of the radius and its articulation with the ulna. This joint allows for the radius to rotate along its length during pronation and supination movements of the forearm.

questions.text: Which of the following muscle of tongue is not supplied by hypoglossal nerve?
questions.solution:
Palatoglossus is not supplied by hypoglossal nerve.

All intrinsic and extrinsic muscles of tongue are derived from occipital myotomes, hence innervated by hypoglossal nerve, except palatoglossus which is derived from the pharyngeal arch and is supplied by vago-accessory nerve.

Note:

  • All the muscles of the tongue except palatoglossus (cranial accessory nerve through pharyngeal plexus) are supplied by hypoglossal nerve
  • All the muscles of pharynx except stylopharyngeus (glossopharyngeal nerve) are supplied by pharyngeal plexus.
  • All muscles of soft palate except tensor veli palatini (nerve to medial pterygoid from mandibular nerve) are supplied by pharyngeal plexus.
  • All muscles of larynx except cricothyroid (external laryngeal nerve) are supplied by recurrent laryngeal nerve

questions.text: Which of the following nerves carries the preganglionic sympathetic fibers to the duodenum?
questions.solution:
The preganglionic sympathetic fibers to the duodenum travel via the greater and lesser splanchnic nerves to the coeliac plexus and synapse in the coeliac and superior mesenteric ganglia.

Autonomic innervation of Duodenum:

Sympathetic Innervation:

Origin: Cell bodies in the intermediolateral columns of the grey matter in the fifth to the twelfth thoracic spinal segments.

Preganglionic sympathetic neurones fibres travel via the greater and lesser splanchnic nerves to the coeliac plexus and synapse in the coeliac and superior mesenteric ganglia.

Postganglionic axons are distributed to the duodenal wall via peri-arterial plexuses on the branches of the coeliac trunk and superior mesenteric artery.

The sympathetic nerves are vasoconstrictor to the duodenal vasculature and inhibitory to duodenal musculature.

Parasympathetic Innervation:

The preganglionic parasympathetic supply is carried by vagal fibres that travel from the coeliac plexus and synapse on neurones in the duodenal wall.

The parasympathetic supply is secretomotor to the duodenal mucosa and motor to the duodenal musculature.

questions.text: Which of the following is the pre-trematic nerve of first pharyngeal arch?
questions.solution:
Chorda tympani is the pre-trematic nerve of the first pharyngeal arch.

Nerve supply of Pharyngeal arches:

The nerve of the arch itself runs along the cranial side of the arch and is called post-trematic nerve of the arch.

Each arch also receives a branch from the nerve of the succeeding arch called the pre-trematic nerve which runs along the caudal border of the arch.

The mandibular nerve is the post-trematic nerve of the first arch and chorda tympani (branch of the facial nerve) is the pre-trematic nerve.

This double innervation is reflected in the nerve supply of anterior two-thirds of tongue which is derived from the first arch.

questions.text: Which of the following is at the transpyloric plane?

choices.text: Lower limit of spinal cord in neonates

questions.solution:
Origin of portal vein occurs at the transpyloric plane (L1).

Other options:

Uncinate process of pancreas is at L2 level.

Celiac trunk is at T12 vertebral level.

Lower limit of spinal cord in neonates is at upper border of L3.

Related Pearl: Abdominal planes and their landmarks

Planes that divide the abdomen into 9 regions are:

  • Horizontal planes 
    • At the level of L3 - Subcostal plane (between 10th costal cartilages). It corresponds to the 3rd part of the duodenum
    • At the level of L5 - Transtubercular plane (between tubercles of iliac crests). It corresponds to the origin of inferior vena cava. 
  • Vertical planes (paramedian or lateral planes)
    • From mid-clavicular point to mid-inguinal point on both sides 

The nine regions of the abdomen include:

  • Right hypochondriac, epigastric, left hypochondriac
  • Right lumbar, umbilical (central), left lumbar
  • Right iliac, hypogastric (suprapubic), left iliac

Other planes and angles in the abdomen are:

  • Transpyloric (Addison's) plane - passes midway between the suprasternal notch and the upper border of the pubic symphysis.
  • Supracristal plane - passes through the highest point of the iliac crest on both sides. It corresponds to the level of the L4 body or L4/5 disc and its spinous process. It is an important landmark when performing a lumbar puncture or spinal injection. The bifurcation of the abdominal aorta lies approximately in this plane.
  • The plane of the pubic crest - passes through the upper border of the pubic symphysis. In supine, this plane intersects the tip of the coccyx and the femoral head.
  • Renal angle - between the 12th rib and the outer border of erector spinae muscle. The lower border of normal kidneys may occasionally be felt here. 
  • Lumbar triangle of Petit - formed below by the iliac crest, anteriorly by external oblique, and posteriorly by latissimus dorsi. Lumbar hernia can occur here.

questions.text: Two patients who underwent neck surgery present to you with winging of scapula. On examination, the scapula in patient A is displaced downwards and away from spine while in patient B, it is pulled upwards and towards the spine. Which of the following statements correctly describe the nerves injured in both of them?

choices.text: Patient A -Thoracodorsal nerve and Patient B- long thoracic nerve
Patient A - Accessory nerve and Patient B- long thoracic nerve
Both patient A and B - Long thoracic nerve
Both patient A and B - Thoracodorsal nerve

questions.solution:
Winging of scapula in Patient A is caused by paralysis of trapezius muscle that results from damage to the spinal accessory nerve (CN XI).

Winging of scapula in Patient B is caused by paralysis of serratus anterior muscle that results from damage to the long thoracic nerve, which arises from the roots of the brachial plexus (C5-C7).

Note:

Scapular winging is almost always caused by damage to one of three nerves that control muscles in your arms, back, and neck:

  • The long thoracic nerve, which controls the serratus anterior muscle
  • The dorsal scapular nerve, which controls the rhomboid muscles
  • The spinal accessory nerve, which controls the trapezius muscle

questions.text: Nerve supply of the tip of nose is:
questions.solution:
Tip of nose is supplied by external nasal branch of ophthalmic division of trigeminal nerve.

Nasal skin is innervated by the infratrochlear and external nasal branches of the nasociliary nerve (ophthalmic division, trigeminal nerve), and the nasal branch of the infraorbital nerve (maxillary division, trigeminal nerve).

Hutchinson's Eye Sign:

It is the presence of vesicles on the tip of the nose or nasal mucosa on the ipsilateral side of herpes zoster ophthalmicus (HZO) infection, which is indicative of involvement of the nasociliary branch of the ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve.

questions.text: Example of traction epiphysis is:
questions.solution:
Tibial tuberosity is type of traction epiphysis.

Traction epiphysis is the region of the long bone that is non-articular, i.e., not involved in joint formation.

Unlike pressure epiphyses, these regions do not assist in weight transmission.

Related Pearl: Types of Epiphysis

There are four types of epiphysis.

Pressure epiphysis

  • Articular and assist in the transmission of weight
  • Found in regions of the bone that are under pressure during movement or locomotion
  • Examples: Head of the humerus, Head of the femur, Condyles of femur and tibia

Traction epiphysis

  • Non-articular and do not transmit weight
  • Provide attachment to one or more tendons that exert traction on the epiphysis
  • Traction epiphyses ossify later than pressure epiphyses
  • Examples: Greater and lesser tubercles of the humerus, and greater and lesser trochanters of the femur

Atavistic epiphysis

  • An independent bone in lower animals but in humans has fused to another bone
  • Examples: Coracoid process is fused to the scapula in humans but is a separate bone in four-legged animals

Aberrant epiphysis

  • Deviations from the normal and are not always present
  • Example: Epiphysis at the head of the first metacarpal and at the base of the other metacarpal bones

questions.text: Which of the following is not related to the sternocostal triangle?
questions.solution:
Sternocostal triangle is related to all except external thoracic artery.

Sternocostal triangle, also known as foramen of Morgagni is a small defect in the posterior aspect of anterior thoracic wall between the sternal and costal attachments of diaphragm.

The superior epigastric artery which is a terminal branch of internal thoracic (not external thoracic artery) enters the abdomen through this gap.

questions.text: Which of the following structure is marked in the given image?
questions.solution:
The image given is of floor of the fourth ventricle, and the area marked is the vagal triangle.

Structures on the floor of the 4th ventricle (Rhomboid Fossa)

Ridges:

  • Transverse fibers: Striae medullares
  • Striae medullares divides rhomboid fossa into 2parts: Rostral pontine and Caudal medullary 

Medial to lateral in rostral pontine part:

  • Midline longitudinal sulcus: Median sulcus
  • Bilateral eminences: Medial eminence
  • Bilateral longitudinal sulcus: Sulcus limitans
  • Bilateral areas: Vestibular area (deeper to it is the vestibular nucleus)

Upper and lower ends of sulcus:

  • Bluish-colored, uppermost area where sulcus limitans ends: Locus coeruleus
  • Depression, the upper area of sulcus limitans: Superior fovea
  • Depression, the lower area of sulcus limitans: Inferior fovea

Cranial nerve nucleus elevations:

  • Elevation on the medial eminence: Facial colliculus
  • Elevations in the lowermost area in the shape of 2 triangles: Hypoglossal and vagal triangles

Circumventricular organ:

  • Between the vagal triangle and gracile tubercle below: Area postrema

questions.text: Stereocilia are found in?
questions.solution:
Stereocilia are found in epididymis.

The epithelial lining of the epididymal tubule contains principal, basal, apical and clear cells. Principal cells are tall columnar cells with basally located, oval nuclei. They bear long stereocilia and function to resorb testicular fluid.

Other options:

Fallopian tubes are lined by ciliated columnar epithelium.

Testis & ovary are lined by simple cuboidal epithelium – germinal epithelium.

Note:

Human spermatozoa acquire motility as they migrate through epididymis.

Human spermatozoa undergo capacitation in female reproductive tract.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding the image given below ?

choices.text: Most common manifestation of nail psoriasis
Most specific sign of nail psoriasis
Most common manifestation of Lichen Planus of the nail
Most specific sign of Lichen Planus of the nail

questions.solution:
The above clinical image depicting Dorsal Nail Pterygium is the most specific nail change in Lichen planus.

The fusion of dorsal nail fold and nail bed leads to pterygium.

 

Related Pearl: Nail changes in lichen planus

Nail involvement in lichen planus occurs in up to 10% of the cases but is usually a minor feature of the disease.

Dorsal Nail Pterygium is the most specific nail change in Lichen planus. The fusion of dorsal nail fold and nail bed leads to pterygium.

The most frequent nail change is the exaggeration of longitudinal lines and linear depressions due to a slight thinning of the nail plate.

Pup-tent sign - elevation of nail in shape of tent

Trachyonychia - 20 nail dystrophy

Subungual Hyperkeratosis and Onycholysis

Longitudinal Melanonychia in Lichen Planus of the nail bed

Permanent destruction of several toenails with ulceration of soles (rare variant)

Image shows  Nails in Lichen planus presented with irregular longitudinal grooves and ridges .

Image : Dorsal Nail Pterygium

Image : Pup-tent sign 

Image: Trachyonychia

questions.text: Which of the following organisms is unlikely to cause onychomycosis in a patient?
questions.solution:
Microsporum gypseum does not cause onychomycosis.

Dermatophytes includes 3 genera: Trichophyton, Microsporum and Epidermophyton.

  • Trichophyton includes species T. rubrum, T. mentagrophytes, T. tonsurans, T. schoenleinii, T. violaceum, etc. These infect infects skin, hair, and nails.
  • Microsporum includes species M. gypseum, M. canis, and M. nanum. These infect only hair and skin and not nails.
  • Epidermophyton includes species E.floccosum. It infects only skin and nails and not hair.

Note: Microsporum gypseum is now known as Nannizzia gypsea.

Related Pearl: Characteristic features of macroconidia and microconidia of dermatophytes

Small unicellular

Multicellular, spindle-shaped

Scanty

Absent

questions.text: What is the location of the target antigen in the condition represented in the immunofluorescence of skin sample shown below?
questions.solution:
Immunofluorescence pattern shown above is of fish-net appearance, which is characteristic of pemphigus vulgaris.

The location of target antigens in the given condition is intraepithelial.  This fish-net appearance of pemphigus vulgaris is due to anti-desmoglein IgG antibodies deposited on the desmosomes (Dsg3 > Dsg1), which are present inter-cellularly.

Direct immunofluorescence of skin sample with anti-IgG shows intercellular IgG deposits in the epidermis. The bullae (blisters) of pemphigus vulgaris occur from destruction within the epidermis; therefore, they are

  • Thin and fragile- rupture frequently
  • Painful (not pruritic)
  • Involves oral mucosa
  • Nikolsky’s sign positive: Slight rubbing of the skin results in peeling off of the epidermis. It is also seen in staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome and toxic epidermal necrolysis.

Other patterns seen on Direct Immunofluorescence in Vesiculobullous disorders are

  1. Linear Pattern (shore-line fluorescence pattern)
  • Due to linear IgG and C3 deposits along the DermoEpidermal Junctions (DEJ): Bullous Pemphigoid, Cicatricial Pemphigoid, Epidermolysis bullosa acquisita.
  • Due to linear deposits of IgA at DEJ: Linear IgA dermatosis

2. Focal granular deposits of IgA at papillary tips seen in Dermatitis herpetiformis

Related Pearl: Vesiculobullous Disorders

Disease Clinical Manifestations Histology Immuno-pathology Autoantigens
Pemphigus vulgaris       Flaccid blisters, denuded skin,oro-mucosal lesions Acantholytic blister formed in suprabasal layer of epidermis  Cell surface deposits of IgG on keratinocytes- fish net pattern Dsg3, Dsg1 in patients with skin involvement
Pemphigus foliaceus       Crusts and shallow erosions on the scalp, central face, upper chest, and back Acantholytic blister formed in superficial layer of epidermis  Cell surface deposits of IgG onkeratinocytes Dsg1
Bullous pemphigoid     Large tense blisters on flexor surfaces and trunk  Subepidermal blister with eosinophil-rich infiltrate Linear band of IgG and/or C3 in epidermal BMZ  BPAG1, BPAG2
Dermatitis herpetiformis      Extremely pruritic small papules and vesicles on elbows, knees, buttocks, and posterior neck Subepidermal blister with neutrophils in dermal papillae  Granular deposits of IgA at the tips of dermal papillae Epidermal trans-glutaminase
Linear IgA disease     Pruritic small papules on extensor surfaces; occasionally larger, arciform blisters  Subepidermal blister with neutrophil-rich infiltrate  Linear band of IgA in epidermalBMZ BPAG2
Epidermo-lysis bullosa acquisita Tense bullae and erosions  Subepidermal blister  IgG and C3 DEJ – Continous and linear  Type VII collagen

 The images below shows clinical pictures of pemphigus patients.

  • Image A - oral erosions in a patient with pemphigus vulgaris
  • Image B - heavily clotted and crusted lesions around the mouth in a patient with paraneoplastic pemphigus
  • Image C - skin lesions found on the trunk in a patient with pemphigus vulgaris
  • Image D - skin lesions on the trunk in a patient with pemphigus foliaceus

questions.text: Pale yellow fluorescence in Wood’s lamp examination is suggestive of:
questions.solution:
Pale yellow fluorescence in Wood’s lamp examination is suggestive of tinea versicolor or pityriasis versicolor.

  • Pityriasis Versicolor is characterized by asymptomatic hypopigmented or hyperpigmented macules and patches and produces fine scales (branny/furfuraceous).
  • Tinea versicolor is usually caused by the lipophilic fungi Malassezia globosa and possibly Malassezia sympodialis and Malassezia furfur.
  • Mechanism of hypopigmentation in P. Versicolor: Azelaic acid produced by Malassezia species.
  • The characteristic appearance on KOH mount and microscopy has been likened to ‘spaghetti and meatballs’ or ‘bananas and grapes’.
  • Besnier's sign (coup d'ongle sign, scratch sign, stroke of the nail): When the fine scales are not visible, an important diagnostic clue may be the loosening of barely perceptible scale with a fingernail, which is called as the scratch sign.
  • Patients are treated with Topical azoles.

Related Pearl: Wood's lamp examination

Wood's lamp examination is a diagnostic test wherein the skin or hair is examined under exposure to the black light emitted by the Wood lamp.

Blacklight is invisible to the naked eye because it is in the ultraviolet spectrum, with a wavelength just shorter than the color violet. The lamp glows violet in a dark environment because it also emits some light in the violet part of the electromagnetic spectrum.

A traditional Wood lamp is a low-output mercury arc covered by a Wood filter (barium silicate and 9% nickel oxide) and emits light at wavelength 320–450 nm (peak 365 nm).

Table: Various diseases and their color on Wood’s lamp examination

Disease

Colour on Wood’s Light

Tinea capitis

 

Microsporum species: brilliant green (M. canis, M. audouinii, M. ferrugineum, M. distortum)

Trichophyton schoenleinii: dull blue

Most Trichophyton species, with the exception of T. schoenleinii, are non-fluorescent

Erythrasma

Coral pink

Pityriasis versicolor

Faint yellow

Pseudomonas

Green

Scabies

Fluorescein solution fills the burrows and fluoresces on Wood’s light.

Porphyria

Urine, feces, blister fluid fluoresce red or pink

Vitiligo

Ivory or milky white

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of the given condition?
questions.solution:
The above image is a case of ichthyosis.

It is a family of genetic disorders characterized by the presence of excessive amounts of dry thickened scaly skin. The commonest form ichthyosis vulgaris is due to genetic defect in the gene FLG coding for Filaggrin protein.

It is regarded as a disorder of keratinization or cornification, and it is due to abnormal epidermal differentiation or metabolism. 

Other options:

  • Harlequin ichthyosis is the most devastating type of Autosomal Recessive Congenital Icthyosis.It is due to mutations of the ABCA12 genes.
  • Recessive X-linked ichthyosis is the second most common ichthyosis after ichthyosis vulgaris. It is caused by deletions or mutations in the STS gene encoding the steroid sulfatase enzyme.
  • Hodgkin lymphoma is the most common malignancy associated with acquired ichthyosis

Note: The presentation of acquired ichthyosis is similar to the inherited condition ichthyosis vulgaris, with prominent fish-like, relatively large scales adherent to the skin; however, the scaling in acquired disease may also be present on the palms and soles and in skin flexures.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man sustained a sudden head injury as a result of which the bridging dural veins were injured. Which of the following appearance is likely to be seen in the CT Brain of this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of an acute subdural hematoma, and the classical appearance likely to be seen in this patient is a crescent-shaped hyperdense lesion.

Subdural hematoma (SDH) refers to the hemorrhage between the dura and arachnoid mater, and most commonly, it results from injury to the bridging dural veins. The causes of SDH include trauma, anticoagulants, antiplatelets, alcohol abuse, and battered baby syndrome.

Acute subdural hematomas are crescent-shaped. They can cross suture lines, but they do not cross the tentorium or falx. In a non-contrast CT Brain, the acute lesions are hyperdense; subacute lesions are isodense; and chronic lesions are hypodense.

During the subacute phase with isodense lesions, the findings that are suggestive of subdural hematoma are gyral effacement and ventricular compression on the affected side and midline shift away from the affected side.

The below image shows acute subdural hematoma with a hyperdense crescentic lesion in the right posterior parietal region between the brain and the skull and a midline shift to left.

Other options:

Lentiform-shaped hyperdense lesion is seen in acute extradural hematoma. Lentiform-shaped hypodense lesion is seen in a chronic extradural hematoma. The crescent-shaped hypodense lesion is seen in chronic subdural hematoma.

Related Pearl: Types of Intracranial Hemorrhage

1. Extradural hemorrhage/epidural hematoma (EDH)

  • Source: Arterial - middle meningeal artery (m/c)
  • Cause: Trauma - fracture of the squamous part of the temporal bone
  • Lens or lentiform shaped opacity
  • Presence of a characteristic lucid interval
  • Treatment: Surgical evacuation of large/rapidly evolving EDH

 

2. Acute subdural hemorrhage (SDH)

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Trauma
  • Common in old age, alcoholics, patients on anticoagulants, shaken baby syndrome (a form of child abuse seen in infants and toddlers)
  • Clinical features: Acute SDH may be associated with a lucid interval; chronic SDH is associated with drowsiness, headache
  • CT findings: Crescent opacity
  • Treatment: May resolve spontaneously or require surgical drainage

 

3. Acute on chronic SDH

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Usually, trivial trauma in old age or patients on anticoagulants
  • Crescent clots
  • Presence of a history of headache, confusion, and being prone to falls

 

4. Subarachnoid hemorrhage

  • Source: Arterial
  • Causes: Trauma (most common), berry aneurysm (2nd most common)
  • M/c sites: Terminal ICA, MCA bifurcation, top of basilar artery
  • Clinical features: Characteristic thunderclap headache
  • CSF: Xanthochromia
  • Hyperdensity in the subarachnoid space
  • Treatment:  Triple H therapy (hypertension, hypervolemia, and hemodilution) to prevent vasospasm, Clipping/coiling of berry aneurysm

 

5. Intra-parenchymal hemorrhage

  • Most common type of intracranial hemorrhage
  • Cause: Hypertension (most common cause)
  • Hyperdensity within the brain parenchyma
  • Site: Putamen of the basal ganglia (most common)
  • Treatment: Correction of any identified coagulopathy by infusing prothrombin complex concentrates, FFP, or fresh platelets as required; surgical evacuation for cerebellar hematoma >3 cm in size

questions.text: Identify the structure marked as "A" in the CT scan shown below:
questions.solution: The structure marked as "A" in the CT Thorax is the Azygos vein.

questions.text: According to Weigert Meyer rule of duplication of ureter, the lower pole ureter in urinary bladder is:

choices.text: Lateral and cephalad to the upper pole ureter
Lateral and caudal to the upper pole ureter
Medial and cephalad to the upper pole ureter
Medial and caudal to the upper pole ureter

questions.solution:
The lower pole ureter is lateral and cephalad to the upper pole ureter

According to Weigart Meyer rule of congenital complete duplication of ureter,

  • The ureter draining the upper segment of the kidney inserts in the bladder inferior and medial to the ureter draining the lower segment of the kidney (Weigert–Meyer rule). The lower moiety of the completely duplicated system is generally normal. 
  • The upper ureter is considered ectopic and the lower ureter is considered orthotopic.
  • Ectopic ureters are more prone for Obstruction.
  • Orthotopic ureter are more prone for Reflux due to perpendicular entry into bladder musculature rather than oblique entry.

questions.text: Which among the following is the least affected ocular structure during radiotherapy?
questions.solution:
Ganglion cell layer is the least affected ocular structure during radiotherapy.

The most radiosensitive:

  • Tissue - bone marrow
  • Blood Cell - Lymphocyte
  • Stage of cell - G2-M interphase
  • Cell type - Rapidly dividing cells
  • Ocular structure - Lens
  • Retinal structure - Rods>Cones

Least Radiosensitive:

  • Tissue - nervous tissue
  • Blood Cell - platelet
  • Stage of cell -  S phase
  • Cell type - Quiescent cells
  • Ocular structure - Sclera
  • Retinal Layer - Ganglion cell layer

Interestingly, sebaceous gland function does not recover after radiotherapy.

questions.text: Identify the type of MRI image given below.
questions.solution:
The MRI image given above is T1 weighted.

In T1 images CSF is dark/hypointense and white matter is white whereas In T2 images CSF is bright/hyperintense and white matter is dark.

FLAIR: Fluid-attenuated inversion recovery is an inversion recovery technique that nulls fluid from T2. So, CSF is dark, white matter is dark, and grey matter is white. The image is given below.

Short-tau inversion recovery (STIR) is an inversion-recovery technique that nulls fat. So, fat is black. It is done to detect bone marrow edema. The image is shown below.
