questions.text: Best radiological investigation in a suspected malignant stricture at the confluence of right and left hepatic ducts in a jaundiced patient is:
questions.solution:
If a malignant stricture at the level of the confluence of the right and left hepatic ducts or higher is suspected in a jaundiced patient (Proximal bile duct), Percutaneous transhepatic cholangiogram (PTC) is preferred to ERCP because successful drainage is more likely.

Percutaneous Transhepatic Cholangiography:

  • It is a percutaneous technique of cannulating the bile ducts directly under radiological guidance.
  • Stent can be placed and can help in drainage of bile also in strictures and malignancy.
  • Proximal duct visualization is done easily by-passing water – soluble contrast.
  • Multiple images can be taken which demonstrate areas of strictures or obstruction.
  • Also enables placement of catheter to provide external biliary drainage or insertion of indwelling stents.
  • PTC is usually preferred to ERCP, when a malignant stricture is at the level of confluence of right and left hepatic ducts or higher in a jaundiced patient.

Radiological investigation of the biliary tree:

  • Plain radiograph: calcification, air within biliary system
  • Ultrasound: stones and biliary dilatation
  • MRCP: anatomy and stones
  • CT scan: anatomy, liver, gallbladder and pancreatic cancer
  • Radioisotope scanning (HIDA scan): function
  • ERCP: anatomy, stones and biliary strictures
  • PTC: anatomy and biliary strictures
  • EUS: anatomy, stones

questions.text: Nottingham prognostic Index is used for which of the following malignancies?
questions.solution:
Nottingham prognostic Index (NPI) is used for Cancer breast.

The NPI takes into account:

  • Size of the tumour,
  • Lymph nodes involvement
  • Histological grade of tumour

NPI is used to predict five-year survival.

questions.text: Gastric conduit created after oesophageal resection done for oesophageal cancer is primarily based upon?
questions.solution:
Gastric conduit created after oesophageal resection is primarily based upon right Gastroepiploic artery.

The viability of the transposed stomach mainly depends on the right gastroepiploic and, to a lesser extent, the right gastric vessels. It should be noted that venous drainage is as important as arterial supply, and it is essential to perform an accurate anatomical dissection that preserves the right gastroepiploic vein as well as the artery.

questions.text: Hereditary pheochromocytomas are commonly associated with all of the following except?
questions.solution:
Hereditary pheochromocytomas are not associated with Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia type-1.

Hereditary pheochromocytomas occur in several tumour syndromes:

  • Multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2 (MEN 2): an autosomal dominant inherited disorder that is caused by activating germline mutations of the RET proto-oncogene.
  • Familial paraganglioma (PG) syndrome: glomus tumours of the carotid body and extra-adrenal paraganglioma are characteristic in this hereditary tumour syndrome, which is caused by germline mutations within the succinate dehydrogenase complex subunit B (SDHB) SDHD and SDHC genes.
  • von Hippel–Lindau (VHL) syndrome: those affected can develop early-onset bilateral kidney tumours, pheochromocytomas, cerebellar and spinal hemangioblastomas and pancreatic tumours. Patients have a germline mutation in the VHL gene.
  • Neurofibromatosis (NF) type 1: pheochromocytomas in combination with fibromas on the skin and mucosae (‘café-au-lait’ skin spots) are indicative of a germline mutation in the NF1 gene.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents with bleeding per rectum. He gives a history of lumps that appear at the anal orifice during defaecation and return spontaneously thereafter. The degree of hemorrhoids would be:
questions.solution:
Lumps that appear at the anal orifice during defaecation and which return spontaneously afterwards indicate second degree haemorrhoids.

Four degrees of haemorrhoids:

First degree – bleed only, no prolapse

Second degree – prolapse but reduce spontaneously

Third degree – prolapse and have to be manually reduced

Fourth degree – permanently prolapsed

questions.text: Principles of management of enterocutaneous fistulae include all except:
questions.solution:
Management of enterocutaneous fistulae includes definite planned surgery because surgery can be extremely technically demanding, and an anastomosis should not be fashioned in the presence of continuing intra-abdominal sepsis or hypoalbuminemia.

The management of fistulas is based on well-established principles known as SNAP which includes:

  • S-Sepsis elimination and skin protection
  • N- Nutrition – a period of parenteral nutrition may well be required
  • A- Anatomical assessment
  • P- definitive Planned surgery

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman presents with recurrent attacks of dizziness and abdominal pain. Fasting blood glucose was 40 mg%, and insulin levels were elevated. CT abdomen showed a 3cm well-defined lesion in the body of the pancreas in proximity to the pancreatic duct. How will you manage this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of recurrent hypoglycemic symptoms (dizziness) and low blood glucose with elevated insulin is suggestive of a diagnosis of insulinoma. As the lesion is in proximity to the pancreatic duct, distal pancreatectomy is done in this patient.

Insulinoma is the most common neuroendocrine tumor of the pancreas.

Whipple’s triad describes the clinical symptoms of insulinoma.

  • Symptoms of hypoglycemia after fasting or exercise
  • Plasma glucose levels <2.8 mmol/L or 50 mg/dL.
  • Relief of symptoms after intravenous administration of glucose

The investigation of choice for insulinoma is the determination of 72-hour fasting glucose and serum insulin levels.

Insulinomas of <2 cm in diameter without signs of vascular invasion or metastases are considered benign. Tumour enucleation is the technique of choice for benign insulinomas.

Distal pancreatectomy is advised for the following:

  • Tumors deep in the pancreatic body or tail
  • Tumors of size >2 cm
  • Tumors within 2 mm of the main pancreatic duct

Medical management to treat hyperinsulinism includes frequent intake of carbohydrate-rich meals, octreotide, or diazoxide.

Related Pearl: Whipple's Triad

Whipple’s triad describes the clinical symptoms of insulinoma.

  • Symptoms of hypoglycemia after fasting or exercise
  • Plasma glucose levels <2.8 mmol/L or 50 mg/dL.
  • Relief of symptoms after intravenous administration of glucose.

questions.text: An obese patient was brought to the casualty following a road traffic accident.  He was diagnosed with tension pneumothorax. An immediate needle thoracotomy was performed in spite of which the vitals did not improve. What will be your next best step in managing this patient?

choices.text: Refer the patient immediately to tertiary care centre
Perform an eFAST to confirm the diagnosis

questions.solution:
The next best step for this patient would be to perform a finger thoracostomy.

According to ATLS, due to the variable thickness of the chest wall (here the patient is obese), kinking of the catheter, and other technical or anatomic complications, needle decompression may not be successful always. In this case, finger thoracostomy is an alternative approach and is recommended as the next best step.

Advantages of finger thoracostomy over needle thoracostomy:

  • Not limited by needle length
  • Observable signs confirming pleural access
    • Puncture sensation of parietal pleura with Kelly/finger
    • Palpation of parietal pleura with finger
    • Palpation of lung parenchyma with finger
  • If there is no pneumothorax, this will not puncture lung parenchyma and create a new pneumothorax
  • No risk of catheter "kinking"

Advantages of finger thoracostomy over tube thoracostomy:

  • Simpler, quicker, easier, and requires less equipment
  • No foreign body hence decreased risk of infection

However, it is mandatory to perform a Tube thoracostomy after a successful needle or finger decompression of the chest.

The RECENT UPDATE (Acc. to ATLS 10th edition):

  • In adults, the needle thoracotomy location changed to the 5th ICS mid-axillary line from the 2nd ICS midclavicular line.
  • In the pediatric age group, the thoracotomy location remains at the 2nd ICS midclavicular line.

questions.text: What is the size of the given blade used for minor surgical procedures?
questions.solution:
The blade shown in the image is of size 15 and is used for minor surgical procedures.

The 11-blade is used for skin incisions (eg. incision and drainage) and arteriotomy.

The 22-blade is often used for abdominal incisions.

questions.text: A patient is brought with bleeding from a deep penetrating wound in his right thigh. His pulse is weak and 100/min, BP is 90/60 mmHg. The skin on his extremities is cold and clammy. Which of the following is the best method of restoring adequate cardiac output and tissue oxygenation in this patient?
questions.solution:
The above clinical picture points towards a diagnosis of hemorrhagic shock.

In the case of hemorrhagic shock, the most effective method of restoring adequate cardiac output, end-organ perfusion, and tissue oxygenation is to restore venous return to normal by locating and stopping the source of bleeding.

Volume repletion will allow recovery from the shock state only when the bleeding has stopped. The first-line agents are crystalloids.

Since the patient already has cutaneous vasoconstriction, vasopressors are not administered without prior adequate fluid resuscitation to avoid further vasoconstriction and gangrene formation.

Nearly 70% of the body’s total blood volume is estimated to be located in the venous circuit. Compliance of the venous system involves a relationship between venous volume and venous pressure. This pressure gradient drives venous flow and therefore the volume of venous return to the heart. Blood loss depletes this component of venous volume and reduces the pressure gradient; consequently, venous return is reduced.

Related Pearl: Classification of hemorrhagic shock

Parameters Class I Class II Class III Class IV
Blood loss in % <15 15–30 30–40 >40
Pulse rate <100 100–120 120–140 >140
Blood pressure Normal Normal Decreased Greatly decreased
Pulse pressure Normal or increased Decreased Decreased Decreased
Respiratory rate 14–20 20–30 30–40 >35
Mental status Slightly anxious Mildly anxious Anxious, confused Confused, lethargic
Urine output (mL/hr) >30 20–30 5–15 Minimal

questions.text: Which of the following reduces the chance of incisional hernia if you are attempting to suture a wound of midline laparotomy?

choices.text: Place sutures 1 cm apart and 1cm deep
Place intra-abdominal drain through a separate incision

questions.solution:
Intra-abdominal drains should be brought out through separate incisions and not through the main incision, as this might lead to hernia formation.

There is no evidence that interrupted sutures are better than continuous if the suturing procedure is done appropriately.

Optimal ratio of suture length to wound length is 4:1 (Jenkin’s rule).

Recent research has also shown that smaller and closer bites taken during suturing leads to reduced incidence of incisional hernia and infection rates.

questions.text: In a patient with a head injury who presents with fixed dilated pupils and rapidly deteriorating neurological signs, where is the burr hole made?

choices.text: Temporal region contralateral to the side of pupillary dilatation
Midline as it is not known which side of pupil dilated first
Left temporal region if no localising sign found
Right temporal region if no localising sign found

questions.solution:
In the given situation, the best choice would be to do a burr hole in the left temporal region since no localizing sign was found and it is not known which pupil dilated first.

When making the initial burr hole, the temporal region is entered first. The side chosen for this initial temporal burr hole depends on the following:

  • In > 85% of cases starting ipsilateral to a dilated pupil will be the correct side 
  • If both pupils are dilated, use the side of the first dilating pupil, if known
  • If pupils are equal, or it is not known which side dilated first, place the burr hole on the side of obvious external trauma
  • If there are no localization clues, hole is placed on the left side – to evaluate and decompress the dominant hemisphere.

questions.text: Identify the following surgical position:
questions.solution:
The given image shows Kraske Position which is also known as Jack-knife position.

The patient's abdomen lies flat upon the bed which is scissored so the hip is lifted and the legs and head are low.

Pilonidal Sinus /Jeep Disease is operated upon in the Jack-knife position.

The sacrococcygeal region is best exposed in the prone jack-knife position with the buttocks taped apart. A paramedian longitudinal incision is made over the abscess cavity that is large enough to allow for adequate drainage and removal of all debris and hair.

Other options:

Fowler and Semi-fowler position:

Fowler's position is a standard patient position in which the patient is seated in a semi-sitting position (45-60 degrees) and may have knees either bent or straight. 

Semi-Fowler, 30 to 45 degrees; and low Fowler, where the head is slightly elevated.

Sims position:

It is used for rectal examination, treatments, and enemas. It is performed by having a patient lie on their left side, left hip and lower extremity straight, and right hip and knee bent. It is also called lateral recumbent position.

questions.text: Which of the following is the ideal time for repair of cleft palate?
questions.solution:
The ideal time for repair of cleft palate is between 6 and 18 months. Hence 9-12 months is the best one to choose among the given options.

The Delaire technique and sequence is one of the regimes currently practised for cleft palate surgery.

Cleft lip repair is commonly performed between 3 and 6 months of age, whereas cleft palate repair is frequently performed between 6 and 18 months.

questions.text: Hot spot on Tc-99 scan is seen in which of the following parotid tumours?
questions.solution:
The only neoplasms of salivary glands known to consistently concentrate 99mTc pertechnetate (hot spot) are Oncocytoma and Warthin's tumour (adenolymphoma).

Warthin tumour, or papillary cystadenoma lymphomatosum, is the second most common benign parotid tumour and occurs most often in older white men. Because of the high mitochondrial content within oncocytes, the oncocyte-rich Warthin tumour and oncocytomas incorporate technetium-99m and appear as hot spots on radionuclide scans.

Related Pearl: Important points regarding salivary gland tumors

  • Most common neoplasm of the salivary gland: Pleomorphic adenoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common benign tumor of the salivary gland in children: Hemangioma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland in children: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the minor salivary glands: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Most common gland affected by pleomorphic adenomas: Parotid gland
  • Tumor of the salivary gland with perineural invasion: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Tumor that shows a hot spot in 99mTc scan: Warthin’s tumor

questions.text: Which of the following rectal polyp is not a premalignant lesion:
questions.solution:
Among the given options, Juvenile polyp is the only benign lesion.

Rest all are premalignant lesions.

Juvenile polyp is a bright red, glistening pedunculated sphere (‘cherry tumour’), which is found in infants and children. A solitary juvenile polyp has virtually no tendency to malignant change, but should be treated if it is causing symptoms.

The autosomal dominant inherited syndrome juvenile polyposis does carry an increased risk of malignancy. It is characterised by multiple polyps and a positive family history.

Other options:

  • Villous adenomas have a characteristic frond-like appearance. They may be very large, occupying much of the circumference of the rectum. These tumours have an increased tendency to become malignant.
  • Familial adenomatous polyposis is due to mutation in the adenomatous polyposis coli (APC) gene. It is characterised by the development of multiple rectal and colonic adenomas around puberty. It is a premalignant condition.

questions.text: A patient presents with discrete thyroid swelling and FNAC reports is Thy 2. What would you infer from the report?
questions.solution:
Thy 2 in FNAC corresponds to Non neoplastic lesion.

Classification of fine- needle aspiration cytology reports

Type Meaning
Thy 1 Non diagnostic
Thy 1c Non diagnostic cystic
Thy 2 Non neoplastic
Thy 3 Follicular
Thy 4 Suspicious of malignancy
Thy 5 Malignancy

This classification of thyroid FNAC reports has been described according to the 27th edition of Bailey and Love.

questions.text: Which one of the following is not a feature of absorbable meshes?

choices.text: They are used in temporary abdominal wall closure
They are used to buttress sutured repair

questions.solution:
Collagen deposition is maximum when non-absorbable meshes are used, not with absorbable meshes.

Absorbable meshes:

Made of polygalactin or polyglycolic acid fibre.

It elicits a chronic foreign body reaction and promotes fibroblast activity. After complete absorption (30 days for polygalactin 910; 90 days for polyglycolic acid), the prosthetic material is replaced by a collagen-rich connective tissue.

Absorbable materials are less likely to become infected than nonabsorbable materials and are less harmful to viscera.

One disadvantage to absorbable implants is that the resultant scar tissue weakens after the material is absorbed and therefore may not provide the necessary long-term repair strength.

Nonabsorbable prosthetic materials (e.g., polypropylene):

Are associated with more connective tissue reaction than absorbable materials. Thus, repair strength is increased due to the continuing presence of the implant and greater scar formation.

questions.text: A middle-aged man suffering from chronic constipation presents with swelling in the inguinal region. On further evaluation, the swelling was confirmed to be due to direct inguinal hernia. Identify the following surgical landmark (denoted in green) from where this type of hernia arises.
questions.solution:
The surgical landmark (shown in green) from where a direct inguinal hernia arises is the Hesselbach triangle.

Boundaries of Hesselbach’s triangle:

  • Laterally by inferior epigastric artery 
  • Medially by the lateral border of rectus abdominis
  • Inferiorly by inguinal ligament

The floor of the Hesselbach triangle is formed by the transversalis fascia.

A hernia refers to the protrusion of part of the contents of the abdominal cavity through a weakness in the abdominal wall. Inguinal hernias may be direct or indirect. Direct inguinal hernias occur within Hesselbach triangle, while indirect inguinal hernias occur lateral to the triangle.

Patients present with an abdominal lump that is usually painless, but sometimes with an aching or heavy feeling. Cough impulse is usually present, and it is usually reducible. Treatment is urgent in irreducible hernias. Diagnosis is usually clinical.

Other options:

Option A: The boundaries of the triangle of pain are the iliopubic tract, testicular vessels, and the peritoneal fold. The lateral femoral cutaneous nerve, the femoral branch of the genitofemoral nerve, and the femoral nerve are located here.

Option C: The boundaries of the triangle of doom are the vas deferens, testicular vessels, and the peritoneal fold. The external iliac artery and vein are found in this triangle.

Option D: Corona mortis is an anastomosis between the obturator and the external iliac or inferior epigastric arteries or veins, which can lead to life-threatening hemorrhage if accidentally cut.

Related Pearl: Boundaries of Hesselbach’s triangle

  • Lateral - inferior epigastric artery
  • Medial - lateral border of rectus abdominis
  • Inferior - inguinal ligament

Direct inguinal hernia emerges through Hesselbach’s triangle (Hence situated medial to inferior epigastric artery)

Indirect inguinal hernia enters deep inguinal ring (Hence it is lateral to inferior epigastric artery)

questions.text: The initial focus of Damage control surgery (DCS) is:
questions.solution:
The initial focus of Damage control surgery (DCS) is Haemorrhage control.

Damage control is a staged process. The initial focus is haemorrhage control, followed by control and limitation of contamination.

The stages of damage control surgery:

Stage I: Patient selection

Stage II: Control of haemorrhage and control of contamination

Stage III: Resuscitation continued in the intensive care unit

Stage IV: Definitive surgery

Stage V: Abdominal closure

questions.text: Which of the following parameters is/are increased in abdominal compartment syndrome?
questions.solution:
Central venous pressure is increased in Abdominal compartment syndrome (ACS).

Cardiac output and visceral blood flow are decreased ACS.

Abdominal compartment syndrome is defined as a sustained IAP >20 mm Hg associated with organ dysfunction/failure. A urinary bladder catheter is the gold standard indirect method used to measure IAP.

Grade III ACS is associated with hypoxia and ARDS and serious complications.

Related Pearl: Physiological Consequences of Increased Intra-abdominal Pressure

Decreased :

  • Cardiac output
  • Venous return
  • Visceral blood ﬂow
  • Renal blood ﬂow
  • Glomerular filtration

Increased :

  • Cardiac rate
  • Pulmonary capillary wedge pressure
  • Peak inspiratory pressure
  • Central venous pressure
  • Intrapleural pressure
  • Systemic vascular resistance

questions.text: Which of the following genetic disorders does not predispose patients to develop berry aneurysm?
questions.solution:
Berry’s aneurysm is not associated with Neurofibromatosis Type II.

The various genetic disorders predisposing patients to develop Berry aneurysm are given below:

Frequent:

Autosomal Dominant Polycystic Kidney Disease

Infrequent:

Vascular Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome

Marfan Syndrome

Neurofibromatosis Type I

Rare:

Pseudoxanthoma Elasticum

Hereditary Haemorrhagic Telangiectasia

Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia Type I

Loeys-Dietz Syndrome

questions.text: A baby assessed at 5 minutes after birth, had irregular gasping respiration and blue extremities. Heart rate was 40/min and there was grimace with some flexion of extremities. What is the APGAR score for this newborn?
questions.solution:
APGAR score in this newborn is 5. 

In this baby:

  • Color: Blue extremities - score 1 
  • HR < 100/min - score 1 
  • Grimace - score 1 
  • Some flexion of extremities - score 1 
  • Irregular respiration - score 1 

Thus, total score is 5. At 1 minute and 5 minutes after birth of the infant, the 5 objective signs listed here are evaluated and each is given a score of 0, 1, or 2. A total score of 10 indicates an infant in the best possible condition. An infant with a score of 0-3 requires immediate resuscitation. 

Related Pearl: APGAR score

questions.text: A patient is brought to the casualty with circumferential full-thickness burns to the limbs. An emergency escharotomy is planned by the attending surgeon. Which of the following incision would be made by the surgeon?

choices.text: Depends upon the limb in involved

questions.solution:
Circumferential full-thickness burns to the limbs require emergency escharotomy.

The tourniquet effect of this injury is easily treated by incising the whole length of full-thickness burns. This should be done in the mid-axial line, avoiding major nerves.

Key features of escharotomy placement in limbs:

Upper limb: Mid-axial, anterior to the elbow medially to avoid the ulnar nerve

Hand: Midline in the digits. Release muscle compartments if tight. Best done in theatre and with an experienced surgeon

Lower limb: Mid-axial. Posterior to the ankle medially to avoid the saphenous vein.

questions.text: Which of the following can a 2-year-old perform?
questions.solution:
A two-year-old can walk upstairs and downstairs.

Hopping on 1 foot
5 years Can skip without falling to either side

questions.text: The clinical classification under CEAP (Clinical-Etiology-Anatomy-Pathophysiology) guidelines in a patient with the following feature would be:
questions.solution:
The given image is characteristic of atrophie blanche which is classified as C4b under CEAP guidelines.

Atrophie blanche is a localized white atrophic skin frequently surrounded by dilated capillaries and pigmentation, usually seen around the ankle. This is a sign of severe chronic venous disease.

CEAP (Clinical-Etiology-Anatomy-Pathophysiology) classification system is used to classify chronic lower extremity venous disease.

The clinical class of C4 under CEAP includes changes in skin and subcutaneous tissue secondary to chronic venous disease. It is further classified as,

  • C4a-Pigmentation or eczema
  • C4b-Lipodermatosclerosis or atrophie blanche
  • C4c-Corona phlebectatica

Related Pearl: CEAP Classification of Chronic Lower Extremity Venous Disease

CEAP (Clinical-Etiology-Anatomy-Pathophysiology)

Clinical classification (C)*

C0

No visible or palpable signs of venous disease

C1

Telangiectases or reticular veins

C2

C2r

Varicose veins

Recurrent varicose veins

C3

Edema

C4

Changes in skin and subcutaneous tissue secondary

to chronic venous disease

C4a-Pigmentation or eczema

C4b-Lipodermatosclerosis or atrophie blanche

C4c-Corona phlebectatica

C5

Healed ulcer

C6

C6r

Active ulcer

Recurrent active venous ulcer

S

With symptoms attributable to venous disease

A

Absence of symptoms attributable to venous disease

Etiological classification (E)

Congenital (Klippel-Trenaunay syndrome)

Ep

Primary

Secondary (postthrombotic syndrome, trauma)

Esi

Secondary (intravenous)

Secondary (extravenous)

Ec

Anatomic classification (A)

Superficial

Reflux

Pr,o

Note:

  • The descriptor A (asymptomatic) or S (symptomatic) is placed after the C clinical class.
  • Telengiactesia refers to tiny intradermal venules <1 mm in diameter.
  • Reticular veins refer to small dilated subdermal blue veins of 1 to 2.9 mm
  • Varicose veins refer to dilated tortuous veins >3 mm in diameter

questions.text: Which of the following is a feature of cephalohematoma?

choices.text: Swelling appears few weeks after birth
Swelling of soft tissues of the scalp

questions.solution:
Cephalohematoma does not cross the suture lines. 

Cephalohematoma:

  • It is a subperiosteal hemorrhage, 
  • It is always limited to the surface of 1 cranial bone and does not cross suture lines. 
  • Swelling appears only several hours after birth. 
  • Most cephalohematomas are resorbed within 2 weeks to 3 months, depending on their size. 
  • Cephalohematomas require no treatment, although phototherapy may be necessary to treat hyperbilirubinemia. 

Caput succedaneum:

  • It is a diffuse, sometimes ecchymotic, edematous collection of serosanguinous fluid in the subcutaneous layer of the scalp. 
  • It involves the area presenting during vertex delivery. 
  •  May extend across the midline and across suture lines. 

Related Pearl: Caput succedaneum and Cephalohematoma

Indicators Caput Succedaneum Cephalhematoma
Location Presenting part of the head The periosteum of skull bone and bone
Time of appearance  Immediately after birth Several hours after birth
Cause Prolonged labor, causing venous stasis and edema  Instrumental delivery, causes rupture of emissary veins in skull
Extent of movement Both hemispheres; crosses the suture line Individual bones; do not cross the suture lines
Period of absorption 2-4 days 2 weeks to 3 months
Treatment None

Supportive.

It can cause neonatal jaundice

questions.text: Which of the following should be the initial investigation in a patient with high probability of pulmonary embolism?
questions.solution:
CT pulmonary angiography is the initial investigation done in a patient with a high probability of pulmonary embolism (PE).

In a patient with a low probability of PE, the initial investigation should be the measurement of D-dimer levels.

Doppler USG is done in a patient whose V/Q scan is non-diagnostic.

The following algorithm guides in the diagnosis of pulmonary embolism in a patient with a probability of PE.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child was brought with complaints of bedwetting at night. There is no history of bedwetting during day time. The findings of urine examination were normal. The specific gravity was 1.020. What would be your advice?
questions.solution:
According to the given history, the child has nocturnal enuresis with normal findings on urine examination; hence, consulting a child psychologist should be advised.

Nocturnal enuresis: 

At 5 years, volitional control of micturition is expected. When there is an occurrence of involuntary voiding at night after 5 years, it is referred to as nocturnal enuresis.

A careful history should be obtained if the patient presents with involuntary voiding. Fluid intake at night and the pattern of nocturnal enuresis should be evaluated. Children with diabetes insipidus, diabetes mellitus, and chronic renal disease can present with this condition as they have a high obligatory urinary output and compensatory polydipsia.

If physical and urine examinations are normal and no daytime symptoms are seen, then further evaluation for urinary tract pathology is not warranted. An ultrasound is needed in an older child, usually >7 years with enuresis or in those who have not responded to therapy. 

Active treatment should be avoided in children younger than 6 years of age. The initial measure is a psychological therapy that helps the child to deal with enuresis psychologically and motivates the child to void at night if he wakes up with a full bladder. Therapy includes:

  • Motivational therapy (star charts for dry nights),
  • Conditioning therapy (auditory or vibratory alarms),
  • Self-hypnosis.

Pharmacological therapy (imipramine and desmopressin) is intended to treat the symptoms of enuresis and thus is regarded as second-line therapy and is not curative. Desmopressin tablets with a dosage of 0.2-0.6 mg at bedtime can be given.

questions.text: Type 4 respiratory failure best relates to which of the following?
questions.solution:
Type 4 respiratory failure is caused due to hypoperfusion of respiratory muscles in patients with shock.

Type IV respiratory failure:

  • Patients in cardiogenic shock → Pulmonary edema → respiratory distress → increased requirement of oxygen delivery (Increases from < 5% to 40 % of cardiac output)
  • The inadequate perfusion of respiratory muscles causes type IV respiratory failure
  • Intubation and mechanical ventilation can allow redistribution of the cardiac output away from the respiratory muscles and back to vital organs while the shock is treated.

questions.text: Which of the following predominantly involves the lower lobe of the lung?
questions.solution:
Asbestosis predominantly involves the lower lobe of the lung.

Most connective tissue diseases predominantly involve the lower lobes of the lung (RA, scleroderma, SLE), except ankylosing spondylitis.

Also, most pneumoconioses involve the upper lobes of the lung ( CWP. silicosis, berylliosis), except asbestosis.

Related Pearl: Lobes involved in various lung diseases

Mnemonic to easily remember the lobe of lung involved in CTD is:

Upper Lobe - CHARTS

  • Coal workers pneumoconiosis (CWP), silicosis, berylliosis
  • Histiocytosis X (LCH)
  • Ankylosing spondylitis, ABPA
  • Radiation
  • Tuberculosis
  • Sarcoidosis

Lower lobes - RAIDS

  • Rheumatoid arthritis
  • Asbestosis
  • Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) and non-specific interstitial pneumonia (NSIP)
  • Drugs: bleomycin, busulfan, amiodarone, methotrexate, nitrofurantoin
  • Scleroderma

questions.text: False statement regarding Down’s syndrome is?

choices.text: Most common cardiovascular lesion is endocardial cushion defect
It is the most common genetic cause of intellectual disability
Most common cause of intestinal obstruction is intussusception
AML is more common during first 3 years of life

questions.solution:
Most common cause of intestinal obstruction in Down’s syndrome is duodenal atresia. 

Clinical features of Down’s syndrome: (Mnemonic: I C A PROBLEM Somewhere) 

  • Intellectual disability/Incurved or short fifth finger with clinodactyly 
  • Congenital heart disease 
  • Acute megakaryoblastic leukemia/Alzheimer's disease/Atlantoaxial instability/Atresia of the duodenum 
  • Protruding tongue 
  • Round face
  • Occiput flat/Open wide fontanelle/Open mouth 
  • Brachycephalic/Brushfield's spots 
  • Low (depressed) nasal bridge 
  • Epicanthal fold/Ears low set and dysplastic 
  • Mongoloid slant (oblique palpebral fissure) 
  • Simian palmar crease and wider gap between first and second toes 

Note: 

  • Down’s syndrome is the most common genetic cause of intellectual disability. 
  • Most common cause of intestinal obstruction in Down syndrome is duodenal atresia (double-bubble sign). 
  • Children with Down's syndrome have an increased risk of developing leukemias, including acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) and acute myeloid leukemia (AML).  
  • AML is more common during the first 3 years of life. 
  • Most common AML associated with Down Syndrome is acute megakaryoblastic leukemia (AML).  
  • Most common hematological manifestation in Downs syndrome is transient abnormal myelopoiesis (TAM). 
  • Brushfield's spots are whitish speckling on iris seen in light-skinned people.

questions.text: Which of the following is observed in a patient with chronic renal failure ?
questions.solution:
Hypocalcemia, hyperkalemia and hyperphosphatemia are seen in a patient with chronic renal failure.

  • Typical electrolyte abnormalities in chronic renal failure:
    • Hypocalcemia
    • Hyperphosphatemia
    • Hyperkalemia
    • Hyperuricemia
    • Hypermagnesemia
  • Hyponatremia and hypokalemia although not commonly seen in CKD patients can occur occasionally.

Hypokalemia usually reflects markedly reduced dietary potassium intake, especially in association with excessive diuretic therapy or concurrent GI loss.

questions.text: What would be the clinical sign to identify a cyanotic spell?
questions.solution:
The absence of murmur can be considered as a sure sign of cyanotic spell. 

There is a characteristic temporary decrease or absence of systolic murmur during a cyanotic spell because of decreased flow across the right ventricular outflow tract. 

Treatment of cyanotic spell involves the use of the knee-chest position (or squatting), oxygen, morphine, sodium bicarbonate, beta-blockers (propranolol), and alpha-agonists (phenylephrine). 

Because metabolic acidosis develops when arterial Po2 is < 40 mmHg, rapid correction (within several minutes) with intravenous (IV) sodium bicarbonate is necessary if the spell is unusually severe and the child shows a lack of response to the foregoing therapy. 

Drugs that increase systemic vascular resistance (SVR), such as IV phenylephrine (alpha-1 agonist) or propranolol (non-selective beta-antagonist/beta-2 block), can improve right ventricular outflow, decrease the right-to-left shunt, and improve the symptoms. This is the same principle as squatting.

questions.text: What is the most common mutation seen in cystic fibrosis?
questions.solution:
The most common mutation in cystic fibrosis is Phe508del. 

Cystic fibrosis or mucoviscidosis is an autosomal recessive disorder with a mutation in the cystic fibrosis transmembrane regulator (CFTR) gene on chromosome 7q. The most common CFTR mutation is F508 deletion.

CFTR gene encodes for ATP-gated chloride channels in the apical membranes of epithelial cells. It regulates the flow of ions across epithelial membranes of sweat glands, respiratory airways, pancreatic ducts, etc. The defect leads to high salt concentrations in sweat and viscous luminal secretions in the respiratory and gastrointestinal tracts.

Clinical manifestations/ complications of cystic fibrosis include:
  • Sinusitis and nasal polyps
  • Respiratory - copious hyper-viscous and adherent pulmonary secretions with abnormal mucociliary clearance obstruct small and medium-sized airways leading to respiratory compromise. The disease can be further complicated by bronchiectasis and allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA).
  • Gastrointestinal - 
    • Thick and adherent exocrine secretions obstruct pancreatic ducts and impair the production and flow of digestive enzymes
    • Tissue destruction of the exocrine pancreas, with fibrotic scarring, cyst proliferation, and loss of acinar tissue - fat malabsorption, steatorrhea, fat-soluble vitamin deficiencies
    • Obstruction of intrahepatic bile ducts and parenchymal fibrosis leading to hepatic insufficiency and focal biliary cirrhosis
    • Distal intestinal obstructive syndrome in adults and meconium ileus in neonates
  • Reproductive - males have infertility due to the congenital absence of bilateral vas deferens and defective sperm transport, resulting in obstructive azoospermia. Females have infertility due to abnormalities of the reproductive tract secretions.

 The diagnosis is confirmed if both of the following criteria are met:

  • Presence of
    • Clinical symptoms affecting at least one organ system (respiratory, gastrointestinal, or genitourinary) or
    • Positive newborn screening or
    • A sibling with cystic fibrosis
  • Evidence of dysfunction of the CFTR gene by
    • Two positive sweat chloride test results were obtained on separate days or
    • Identification of two CFTR mutations by genetic testing or
    • An abnormal measurement of nasal potential difference

Cystic fibrosis requires a multidisciplinary approach to management. The correction of the defect can be via:

  • Lumacaftor, an FDA-approved drug that corrects the misfolding and reverts the Phe508del mutation defect
  • Ivacaftor potentiates CFTR channel opening and stimulates ion transport

End-stage pulmonary failure requires lung transplantation.

questions.text: The amount of total body water in a term neonate weighing 4 kg is?
questions.solution: The amount of total body water (TBW) in a term neonate is approximately 75% of the birth weight. So in this case, 75% of 4kgs is 3L.

questions.text: Most common extra-renal manifestation seen in autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease is?
questions.solution:
Most common extra-renal manifestation seen in autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease is heptic cysts.

Most common extrarenal manifestation is hepatic cysts which are derived from the biliary epithelium. Pancreatic and splenic cysts are less frequent.

Cysts can be found in the arachnoid membrane and they do not cause symptoms, but may increase the risk of developing a subdural hematoma.

Extrarenal cysts in ADPKD:

  • Hepatic cysts
  • Pancreatic cysts
  • Seminal vesicle cysts
  • Arachnoid membrane cysts

In autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease(ADPKD), cysts are least likely to be present in the lungs.

Note: Polycystic liver disease associated with ADPKD is different from autosomal dominant polycystic liver disease(ADPLD) which does not progress to renal failure.

There is a 3 fold increase in the incidence of bronchiectasis in ADPKD patients.

Related Pearl: Cystic Diseases of the Kidney

Features  Adult PKD Childhood PKD
Mode of inheritance Autosomal dominant Autosomal recessive
Mutation in genes PKD1, PKD2 PKHD1
Proteins produced Polycystin 1, polycystin 2 Fibrocystin
Chromosomes involved 16p, 4q 6p
Extrarenal manifestations 

Multiple cysts in the liver (most common), pancreas, spleen

Berry aneurysms in the circle of Willis - SAH

Colonic diverticuli

Mitral valve prolapse

 Congenital hepatic fibrosis

Other cystic diseases:

Medullary sponge kidney - 

  • Sporadic in origin
  • Characterized by medullary cysts
  • Associated with hematuria, recurrent renal stones, and normal renal function

Multicystic renal dysplasia - 

  • Characterized by irregular, enlarged, multicystic kidneys
  • Associated with ureteropelvic obstruction, ureteral agenesis, or atresia 
  • Bilateral multicystic renal dysplasia  is associated with renal failure

Simple renal cysts - 

  • Characterized by single or multiple cysts with normal-sized kidney
  • Associated with microscopic hematuria

questions.text: Mallory bodies are seen in?
questions.solution:
Mallory bodies are seen in alcoholic hepatitis.

Mallory bodies:

  • They are intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies due to aggregation of cytoskeletal intermediate filament.
  • Appear as clumped,amorphous,eosinophilic material within ballooned hepatocytes.

Councilman bodies:

A councilman body, also known as Councilman hyaline body or apoptotic body, is an acidophilic(eosinophilic) globule of cells that represents a dying hepatocyte often surrounded by normal parenchyma.

Related Pearl: Mallory Bodies vs. Councilman Bodies

Intra-cytoplasmic inclusions  Acidophilic apoptotic bodies
Due to aggregation of cytoskeletal intermediate filament  Due to hepatocyte apoptosis  

Appears as clumped, amorphous, eosinophilic material within ballooned hepatocytes.

 Entire hepatocyte shrinks and appears as intense eosinophilic stained bodies

Seen in

  • Alcoholic hepatitis
  • Primary biliary cholangitis 
  • Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency
  • Indian childhood cirrhosis
  • Hepatocellular carcinoma 

Seen in  

  • Acute viral hepatitis
  • Yellow fever

Mallory bodies seen as clumped, amorphous eosinophilic material within ballooned hepatocytes

Councilman bodies where the entire cell is shrunken into intense eosinophilic apoptotic body

questions.text: According to the WHO guidelines, indications for hospital admission in pneumonia in an HIV-negative child are all of the following except?
questions.solution:
The revised 2014 WHO guidelines state that it is safe to treat chest indrawing pneumonia at home. A child who is HIV positive and has chest indrawing will need to be referred for inpatient treatment. Only those children who have general danger signs are classified as having “severe pneumonia” and need to be referred to a higher level (hospital admission). Danger signs: 

  • Not able to drink 
  • persistent vomiting 
  • convulsions lethargic or unconscious 
  • stridor in a calm child 
  • severe malnutrition

questions.text: A nurse is found to be seropositive for both HBsAg and HBeAg. These findings denote which of the following?

choices.text: Concurrent hepatitis B and hepatitis E infection

questions.solution:
Seropositivity for both HBsAg and HBeAg indicates an acute hepatitis B infection.

Hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg) is an objective marker of active HBV infection and is present for about 3-4 weeks. It may be present in a chronic carrier state (when it persists for longer than 6 months). Antibody to HBsAg (Anti-HBs) is detected 3-6 months after recovery from the initial infection or vaccination and confers immunity.

Hepatitis B e antigen (HBeAg) is a marker of active viral replication in the liver. The persistence of HBeAg is an indicator of chronic hepatitis B with active viral replication. Anti-HBeAg antibodies are produced against these antigens.

In high infectivity chronic HBV, both HBsAg and HBeAg will be present but in low infectivity chronic HBV only HBsAg will be present.

Serological Patterns of Hepatitis B Infection:

Acute HBV +   - +  -  IgM
Window period  - -   - - IgM
Chronic HBV (high infectivity) +  -  +   -  IgG
Chronic HBV (low infectivity) + -  -  +  IgG
Immunized (Vaccination)* -  + -  -   
Immunized (Natural infection) -  +  - -  IgG
Remote past infection -  -  -  -  IgG

questions.text: Drug of choice in the treatment of congenital adrenal hyperplasia in children is?
questions.solution:
The drug used in the treatment of congenital adrenal hyperplasia in a child is hydrocortisone, 15-20 mg/m²/24 h, orally, in 3 divided doses continued lifelong. Double or triple doses are indicated during periods of stress, such as infection or surgery. 

  • Mineralocorticoid replacement with fludrocortisone is used for patients with the salt-wasting disease. 
  • The daily dose of fludrocortisone in infants is higher than that in older children. 
  • Significantly virilized females can undergo surgery between 2 and 6 months of age.

questions.text: Where does the primary tendinosis occur in tennis elbow?
questions.solution:
In tennis elbow, primary tendinosis occurs at 1-2 cm distal to the attachment of extensor carpi radialis brevis muscle to the lateral epicondyle. 

 

Tennis elbow is also known as lateral epicondylitis. This is the most common tendinopathy. It is caused by repetitive contraction of extensor muscles at lateral epicondyle in activities that require repetitive forceful wrist extension and supination. 

It is common in individuals who play tennis, squash, and badminton. The pain improves on rest.

Conservative management with physiotherapy will speed up the recovery. Steroid injections can be used for short-term pain relief. Arthroscopic surgery technique can be used, but it has a higher risk of nerve injury.

Related Pearl: Medial and lateral epicondylitis

Tennis elbow or Lateral epicondylitis

  • Pain is felt over or below the lateral epicondyle of the humerus
  • Pain is aggravated by lifting movements
  • It is common among tennis players and in those who perform repetitive wrist extension
  • Extensor carpi radialis brevis tendon is commonly involved

Tests:

  • Cozen's test: The patient is asked to pronate the forearm and make a tight fist.  Wrist extension against resistance causes pain at the lateral epicondyle
  • Mills sign: Pain at the lateral condyle when the elbow is extended in pronation with a flexed wrist
  • Wringing test: The patient is asked to wring a towel. Pain is felt at the lateral epicondyle in the tennis elbow
  • Maudsley's test: Resisted extension of the middle finger produces pain at the lateral epicondyle

Treatment: 

  • Conservative treatment: Activity modification and usage of a tennis elbow clasp are sufficient in most cases. Corticosteroid and local anesthetic injections into the tender area may reduce the pain, but is not curative
  • Operative treatment: Detachment of the common extensor muscle from the lateral epicondyle

 

Golfer's elbow or Medial epicondylitis

  • Pain is felt over the medial epicondyle of the humerus where pronators have their origin
  • Associated with ulnar nerve neuropathy
  • Less common than tennis elbow

Tests:

  • Reverse Cozen: The elbow is kept in slight flexion with the hand and wrist in supination. The examiner attempts to extend the elbow, while the patient is asked to resist this movement with active flexion. If pain is elicited at the medial epicondyle, it suggests golfer’s elbow

Treatment: 

  • Conservative treatment: Activity modification and pain killers is sufficient in most cases
  • Operative treatment:  Excision of the abnormal tendons at the flexor-pronator origin

Related Pearl: Important conditions of the elbow:

Tennis elbow

Golfer's elbow

Baseball pitcher's elbow

Damage to the bones or soft tissue attached around the elbow due to repeated vigorous throwing activities. Hypertrophy of the lower humerus and incongruity of the joint, or loose body formation and osteoarthritis

questions.text: Which of the following paraneoplastic conditions is matched incorrectly with the malignancy?
questions.solution:
Sign of Leser-Trelat is associated with gastrointestinal adenocarcinoma.

It is characterized by the sudden appearance or rapid increase in number and size of seborrheic keratoses, which are benign skin lesions. 

Necrolytic migratory erythema is a red, blistering and eroding skin lesions that form painful and itchy plaques. These are often associated with glucagonoma, a rare pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor that secretes excessive amounts of glucagon.

Pityriasis rotunda is commonly associated with hepatocellular carcinoma. It is characterized by discrete, round, scaly, pigmented patches.

Erythema gyratum repens is most frequently associated with lung cancer. It is characterized by figurate erythema commonly with concentric erythematous bands forming a wood-grain appearance.

questions.text: All of the following are true about trigeminal neuralgia except ?

choices.text: No objective signs of sensory loss

questions.solution:
Trigeminal neuralgia is associated with superficial pain.

Trigeminal neuralgia:

  • More common in females over 50 years
  • Characterized by unilateral lancinating facial pain, most commonly involving the second and/or third divisions of the trigeminal nerve territory
  • Bilateral or early onset is associated with multiple sclerosis
  • Unilateral trigeminal nerve compresion can be due to superior cerebellar artey.
  • Pain is repetitive, severe, and very brief.
  • Triggered by touch, a cold wind or eating.
  • Physical signs are usually absent, although the spasms may make the patient wince and sit silently (tic douloureux).
  • No objective signs of sensory loss.
  • Drug of choice-carbamazepine

questions.text: Which of the following peripheral neuropathies has asymmetrical sensory loss?
questions.solution:
Vitamin B6 toxicity has asymmetrical sensory loss.

Related Pearl: Sensory Loss In peripheral Neuropathies

Symmetrical Sensory Loss

  • Cryptogenic or idiopathic sensory polyneuropathy (CSPN)
  • Diabetes mellitus and other metabolic disorders
  • Drugs and toxins
  • Familial (HSAN), CMT, amyloidosis
  • Inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy (GBS and CIDP) 

Asymmetrical Sensory Loss

  • Cancer (paraneoplastic)
  • Sjögren’s syndrome
  • Idiopathic sensory neuronopathy (possible GBS variant)
  • Cisplatin and other chemotherapeutic agents
  • Vitamin B6 toxicity
  • Multifocal CIDP, vasculitis, cryoglobulinemia, amyloidosis, sarcoid, infectious (leprosy, Lyme, hepatitis B, C, or E, HIV, CMV), tumor infiltration 
  • Compressive mononeuropathy, plexopathy, or radiculopathy
  • Polyradiculopathy or plexopathy due to diabetes mellitus
  • Cryptogenic or idiopathic sensory polyneuropathy (CSPN)

questions.text: Type of sensation lost on same side in Brown Sequard syndrome is?
questions.solution:
Proprioception is lost on same side in Brown Sequard syndrome.

Hemi section of the spinal cord causes damage to ascending sensory (dorsal column pathway, ventrolateral spinothalamic tract) and descending motor (corticospinal tract) pathways, which is called the Brown- Séquard syndrome.

The lesion to fasciculus gracilus or fasciculus cuneatus leads to ipsilateral loss of discriminative touch, vibration, and proprioception below the level of the lesion.(fibers from the sacral cord are positioned most medially and those from the cervical cord are positioned most laterally.

The loss of the spinothalamic tract leads to contra­lateral loss of pain and temperature sensation beginning one or two segments below the lesion.

Damage to the cor­ticospinal tract produces weakness and spasticity in certain muscle groups on the same side of the body.

Related Pearl: Brown Sequard syndrome (Hemisection of spinal cord)

questions.text: A male patient presents with a history of back pain. He gives a history of pulling a muscle while lifting heavy weights. On examination, there is exaggerated lumbar lordosis and you perform the test as shown in the image below. Name the test performed.
questions.solution:
Thomas test is being performed in the given image above. 

Thomas test is used to detect fixed flexion deformity of the hip. Here, the affected hip is extended while the contralateral hip is held flexed, flattening and immobilizing the lumbar spine.

Flexion deformity is seen in the initial stages of the disease. The patient keeps the hip in flexion as this is the position of ease and maximum joint capacity. Soft tissue contractures convert this into a fixed flexion deformity, making locomotion impossible.

In an effort to bring the limb on the ground and to make locomotion possible, the lumbar spine undergoes exaggerated lordosis and thus conceals the fixed flexion deformity. This is revealed by the Thomas test. The easy passage of the examiner's hand between the bed and the back of the patient is considered a positive test as normally this is not possible. 

Other options:

Option A: Trendelenburg test is used to assess the weakness or paralysis of the gluteus medius muscle. 

Option C: Ober's test is used in physical examination to identify the tightness of the iliotibial band. 

Option D: Allen's test is mainly used to test the adequacy of ulnar collateral blood flow to the hand, which is usually done prior to radial artery cannulation.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Lambert Eaton Myasthenic syndrome is false?

choices.text: It can be associated with small cell lung cancer
No incremental response with repetitive nerve stimulation
Antibodies are present against pre synaptic calcium channels

questions.solution:
In Lamber Eaton Myasthenic syndrome there is incremental response in high frequency repetitive nerve stimulation test.

Decremental response in low frequency repetitive nerve stimulation test.

Lambert-Eaton Myasthenic Syndrome (LEMS):

  • LEMS is a neuromuscular junction disorder associated with the reduced acetylcholine (Ach) release from the presynaptic nerve terminals, despite normal ACh vesicle numbers, ACh presynaptic concentration, and postsynaptic ACh receptors.
  • Antibodies directed against the P/Q voltage-gated calcium channel (VGCC) interfere with the normal calcium flux required for the release of acetylcholine. Approximately 50% of LEMS cases are associated with malignancy, mainly small cell lung cancer (SCLC).
  • Most patients with LEMS present with symptoms as slowly progressive proximal muscle weakness, and this feature is common to almost all patients at some point in the illness.
  • An increase in the compound muscle action potential (CAMP) amplitude >100% after exercise or with high-frequency repetitive nerve stimulation (RNS) is considered to be of diagnostic significance.

questions.text: Which of the following statement is true about Maturity-onset diabetes of the young (MODY)?

choices.text: Autosomal recessive form of type 2 diabetes mellitus
MODY type 3 is most common form

questions.solution:
The true statement about MODY from the given options is that type 3 is the most common form.

Maturity-onset diabetes of the young (MODY):

It is an autosomal-dominant form of type 2 diabetes mellitus affecting the younger population with a strong positive family history. It is a monogenic diabetes i.e only one gene mutation is present. Clinical features include glucose intolerance, along with association with renal cysts. There is insulinopenia with no antibodies and no insulin resistance. The patient does not have obesity, hypertension, or hyperlipidemia and responds to sulfonylureas.

There are 5 types of MODY:

  • Types 1,3,5: HNF Mutation – Hepatocyte nuclear transcription factor. Type 3 MODY is the most common form.
  • Type 2: Glucokinase mutation
  • Type 4: Insulin Promotor Factor-1 (PDX 1) mutation.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presented with a mid-tibial swelling, with complaints of severe pain at night which reduces after taking aspirin. What is the best investigation to diagnose the condition?
questions.solution:
A child in 2nd decade which severe night pain and relieved by aspirin (NSAIDs) best explains the condition of osteoid osteoma. 

The nidus of osteoid osteoma is present in the cortex and hence CT scan will be the best investigation to diagnose osteoid osteoma. 

Osteoid osteoma:

  • It is a benign neoplasm most often seen in young men. 
  • The typical patient with an osteoid osteoma has pain that is worse at night and is relieved by aspirin or other nonsteroidal antiinﬂammatory medications. 
  • The nidus of osteoid osteoma is present in the cortex and hence CT scan will be the best investigation to diagnose osteoid osteoma. 
  • It is the most common true benign tumor of the bone. 

Treatment: 

  • NSAIDs 
  • Radiofrequency ablation 
  • Surgical Resection by curettage and en bloc resection (has lower recurrence rate) 
  • MR-guided focused USG (Magnetic resonance-guided focused ultrasound (MRgFUS) ablation is a new technique in which ultrasound waves are focused on the osteoid osteoma. When high-intensity waves are focused on a single point, considerable heat is generated.) 

MRI is used for both localization of the tumor and temperature monitoring. Note: In Osteoblastoma-Pain similar in character as osteoid osteoma(worse at night and relieved by NSAIDs).

questions.text: Lab investigations of a patient show low TSH, low T3, and low T4. Which of the following is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
The thyroid hormones (T3, T4) and TSH are low in this patient. The most likely cause for this secondary hypothyroidism. 

If the thyroid gland is not producing enough T3 and T4, ideally the thyrotrophs in the anterior pituitary should produce more TSH to cause more downstream stimulation of the thyroid gland. Since this is not happening in this case and TSH is low despite T3 and T4 being low, the problem is likely to be in the central axis involving the pituitary gland or the hypothalamus. This is referred to as secondary hypothyroidism. 

Related Pearl: Causes of Hypothyroidism

 

Primary

(Low T3, T4 → Raised TSH levels)

Secondary

(Low TSH levels → Low T3, T4)

Tertiary

(Low TRH → Low TSH → Low T3,T4)

Hashimoto’s thyroiditis

RAI therapy for Grave’s disease

Post thyroidectomy

Excessive iodine intake - Wolff Chiakoff effect

Subacute thyroiditis

Medications: Antithyroid drugs, lithium

Iodine deficiency, dyshormonogenesis

Pituitary tumour

Pituitary resection or ablation

Hypothalamic insufficiency

Resistance to thyroid hormone

questions.text: Bouchard’s nodes are seen in?

choices.text: Both proximal and distal interphalangeal joints

questions.solution:
Bouchard’s nodes are seen in the proximal interphalangeal joint. 

Heberden nodes are the knobby appearance of DIP. They are formed due to the formation of osteophytes and tissue swelling. 

They are the signs of osteoarthritis in hands. 

Osteoarthritis is the most common cause of chronic knee pain in individuals of age >45 years. In the early phases, there is episodic joint pain following overactive use of the diseased joint. As the disease progresses, there is continuous pain and may be associated with stiffness of the affected joint. Morning stiffness if present, is usually brief for around 30 minutes.

The joints involved in osteoarthritis are: 

  • Distal and proximal interphalangeal joints (DIP, PIP)
  • First carpometacarpal joint (base of the thumb)
  • Hip and knee joints
  • First metatarsophalangeal joint (MTP)
  • Cervical and lumbosacral spine

On examination, there is tenderness in the joint. A crepitus is felt on joint movement and the range of movements is painfully restricted. Bouchard's and Heberden's nodes may be palpated in PIP and DIP respectively.

Characteristic features of osteoarthritis seen on plain X-ray are:

  • Marginal osteophyte formation
  • Localized joint space narrowing
  • Sclerosis of the underlying bone
  • Subchondral bone cysts

questions.text: Which of the following is true about ulnar nerve palsy?

choices.text: Positive Egawa’s test is due to weakness of palmar interossei
Froment’s sign is due to weakness of adductor pollicis
Wartenberg’s sign is due to weakness of dorsal interossei

questions.solution:
Froment’s sign is due to the weakness of adductor pollicis muscle. 

Ulnar nerve palsy:

  • Positive book test or Froment's sign is due to substituting thumb inter-phalangeal joint flexion for thumb adduction due to weakness of adductor pollicis muscle supplied by the deep branch of ulnar nerve. So, the patient holds the book between thumb and index finger by the help of flexor pollicis longus muscle.  This produces flexion at the inter-phalangeal joint while holding the book. 
  • Positive Egawa's test is due to the weakness of dorsal interossei, therefore side to side movements of the middle finger is weak. 
  • Wartenberg's sign is involuntary abduction of the little finger caused due to weakness of the palmar interossei muscles.

questions.text: Pituitary adenoma with mucocutaneous myxomas and pigmentary nevi are features of?
questions.solution:
Pituitary adenoma with mucocutaneous myxomas and pigmentary nevi are features of Carney complex.

Carney complex (CNC) is an autosomal dominant disorder characterized by:

  • Skin lesions are the most common Carney complex manifestation. Spotty skin pigmentation (usually of the face, labia, and conjunctiva)
  • Myxomas (usually of the eyelids and heart, but also the tongue, palate, breast, and skin),
  • Psammomatous melanotic schwannomas (usually of the sympathetic nerve chain and upper gastrointestinal tract)
  • Endocrine tumors that involve the adrenals, Sertoli cells, somatotropes, thyroid, and ovary.
  • Null mutations in PRKAR1A, encoding a regulatory subunit of a cyclic-AMP-dependent protein kinase which results in Carney complex.
  • The most common type of endocrine tumors in Carney complex is the primary pigmented nodular adrenocortical disease (PPNAD) (present in two-thirds of the patients), a form of bilateral adrenal hyperplasia that leads to adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH)-independent Cushing syndrome.
  • NAME syndrome and LAMB syndrome are synonymous with Carney complex.
    • LAMB - Lentigines, Atrial myxoma, and Blue nevi.
    • NAME - Nevi, Atrial myxoma, Myxoid neurofibromas, and Ephelides.

Loeys-Dietz syndrome is a connective tissue disorder which is similar to Marfan's syndrome and most commonly presents with aortic aneurysms, bifid uvula (cleft palate) and hypertelorism. It is caused by mutations in the genes that encode TGF-β receptors 1 & 2.

Related Pearl: MEN 2 Syndrome Features

MEN 2A

  • Known as Sipple’s syndrome
  • Chromosome 10 / RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Parathyroid adenoma (10–25%)

MEN 2B

  • Known commonly as MEN 3
  • Chromosome 10/ RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (>90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Other associated abnormalities include: (40–50%)
      • Mucosal neuromas
      • Marfanoid habitus
      • Medullated corneal nerve fibers
      • Megacolon

Related Pearl: MEN 4 Syndrome Features

It is associated with CDKN1B gene on chromosome 12.

Associated conditions:

  • Parathyroid adenoma
  • Pituitary adenoma
  • Reproductive organ tumors like testicular cancer, neuroendocrine cervical carcinoma
  • Adrenal and renal tumors

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with inflammatory-monoarthritis affecting the right ankle joint. Which of the following is the first test to identify the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Based on the given clinical scenario synovial fluid aspiration is the first test done to identify the diagnosis.

The patient has inflammatory monoarthritis.The most common cause is trauma. In absence of a history of injury, septic arthritis and gout are the possible diagnosis. Both require mandatory analysis of synovial fluid before initiating treatment.Aspiration of the joint and blood cultures is the correct management.

questions.text: Most common cause of renal artery stenosis in young adults is?
questions.solution:
Fibromuscular dysplasia is the most common cause of renal artery stenosis in young adults.

Stenosis greater than 75 percent in both renal arteries, or 50 percent stenosis with post stenotic dilatation, suggests that the patient may have clinically significant bilateral renal artery stenosis.

There are two major causes of bilateral renal artery stenosis:

  • Atherosclerosis (most common)- Atherosclerosis primarily affects patients over the age of 45 years and usually involves the aortic orifice or the proximal main renal artery. This disorder is particularly common in patients with diffuse atherosclerosis but can occur as an isolated renal lesion.
  • Fibromuscular dysplasia – In contrast to atherosclerosis, fibromuscular dysplasia (FMD) most often affects women under the age of 50 years and typically involves the distal main renal artery or the intrarenal branches.
Unilateral renal artery stenosis Bilateral renal artery stenosis

U/L atherosclerosis

U/L fibromuscular dysplasia

Stenosis to only kidney

Systemic vasculitis

Atheroembolic diseases 
  • IOC for renal artery stenosis is renal angiography

questions.text: What Salter-Harris type of physeal injury does the diagram below denote?
questions.solution:
Type I – Slip (separated or straight across). Transverse fracture through the growth plate. 

Related Pearl: Types of Salter–Harris fractures- Mnemonic

There are nine types of Salter-Harris fractures. Among these, types I to V are more common.

The mnemonic "SALTER" can be used to help remember the first five types.

TYPE  MNEMONIC DESCRIPTION
Type I S = Slip/straight across Transverse fracture through the growth plate
Type II A = Away The fracture lies away from the joint. A fracture through the growth plate and the metaphysis, sparing the epiphysis
Type III L = Lower The fracture is below the physis in the epiphysis.
Type IV TE = Through Everything  A fracture through all three elements of the bone, the growth plate, metaphysis, and epiphysis
Type V R = Rammed (crushed)  A compression fracture of the growth plate

Rarer types VI to IX have been added subsequently.

  • Type VI - Injury to the perichondral structures
  • Type VII - Isolated injury to the epiphyseal plate
  • Type VIII - Isolated injury to the metaphysis, with a potential injury related to endochondral ossification
  • Type IX - Injury to the periosteum that may interfere with membranous growth

questions.text: Identify the given image below.
questions.solution:
This image shows Janeway's lesion, which is highly suggestive of infective endocarditis (IE). Janeway lesions are nontender erythematous macules on the palms and soles. They are more common in acute than subacute IE; histologically, they reflect microabscesses with neutrophil infiltration of capillaries.

Other lesions that are highly suggestive of IE are:

    • Osler nodes
    • Roth spots

Osler nodes are tender subcutaneous violaceous nodules mostly on the pads of the fingers and toes, which may also occur on the thenar and hypothenar eminences. Roth spots are exudative, edematous hemorrhagic lesions of the retina with pale centers.

Related Pearl: Modified Duke's criteria for diagnosis of infective endocarditis

Diagnosis of Infective endocarditis is by Duke's Criteria, which requires either:

  1. Pathologic criteria
  2. Clinical criteria

If clinical criteria are used, definitive endocarditis is defined by the presence of 2 major or 1 major + 3 minor or 5 minor criteria.

The presence of single pathological criteria is definitive of infective endocarditis.

Note: The diagnosis of endocarditis is rejected if an alternative diagnosis is established either when:

  • Symptoms resolve and do not recur with <4 days of antibiotic therapy OR
  • If surgery or autopsy yields no pathologic or macroscopic evidence of endocarditis in <4 days of antimicrobial therapy.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding Tako-tsubo cardiomyopathy?

choices.text: It is a type of ischemic dilated cardiomyopathy
It is associated with a poor prognosis
Myocardial stunning pattern does not match the ECG

questions.solution:
The prognosis is good in Tako-tsubo cardiomyopathy.

Tako-tsubo cardiomyopathy:

Ischemic dilated cardiomyopathy or tako tsubo cardiomyopathy is also called “broken heart syndrome”, because it is characterized by left ventricular contractile dysfunction following extreme psychological stress. It is a type of ischemic dilated cardiomyopathy caused due to elevated levels of catecholamines.

The affected myocardium becomes suddenly weakened or 'stunned' and may show multifocal contraction band necrosis. Left ventricular apex is most often affected leading to “apical ballooning” that resembles a “takotsubo,” Japanese for “fishing pot for trapping octopus” (hence, the name).

The ECG changes can mimic an acute infarction. However, the left ventricular dysfunction extends beyond the distribution of a specific coronary artery. Thus, the myocardial stunning pattern might not fully match the ECG. Coronary angiography maybe needed to rule out acute coronary occlusion.

Ventriculography shows a global ventricular dilation with basal contraction.

Treatment: No treatment has been proven beneficial. However, the following measure can be taken:

  • Nitrates for pulmonary edema
  • Intraaortic balloon pump for low output
  • Combined alpha+beta blockers if hemodynamically stable
  • Magnesium for arrhythmias related to QT prolongation

Due to the risk of ventricular rupture, anticoagulation is not undertaken.

The prognosis is good.

questions.text: Which of the following represents an aortic dissection originating from the descending aorta and extending below the diaphragm?

choices.text: Stanford type A + DeBakey III A
Stanford type A + DeBakey III B
Stanford type B + DeBakey III A
Stanford type B + DeBakey III B

questions.solution:
Aortic dissection originating from descending aorta and extending below the diaphragm is Stanford type B + DeBakey III B.

Classification of aortic dissections: 

  • Stanford Type A - proximal lesions, involving
    • both the ascending and descending aorta - DeBakey I
    • ascending aorta only - DeBakey II
  • Stanford Type B - distal lesions not involving the ascending part and usually beginning distal to the subclavian artery - DeBakey III.
    Debakey III is further subdivided into:
    • III A: involves descending thoracic aorta only
    • III B: extends below the diaphragm

questions.text: A patient in the postoperative ward was under opioid medication for pain relief. His respiratory rate was 7 cycles/min. Which of the following acid-base abnormality will be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of decreased respiratory rate in a patient receiving opioids is suggestive of opioid overdose. The acid-base abnormality seen in this condition is respiratory acidosis with metabolic compensation.

Opioid overdose causes respiratory depression and hypoventilation. Hypoventilation results in the accumulation of carbon dioxide, thereby increasing PaCO2 levels (hypercapnia). The increase in PaCO2, in turn, decreases the bicarbonate (HCO3–)/PaCO2 ratio, thereby decreasing the pH. This is called respiratory acidosis (low pH, high PaCO2).

Physiological compensation takes place to bring the pH back to normal. In acute respiratory acidosis, the body’s compensation occurs in 2 steps. The initial response is cellular buffering that takes place over minutes to hours. Cellular buffering causes a slight elevation in plasma bicarbonate values. The second step is renal compensation that occurs over 3-5 days. With renal compensation, renal excretion of carbonic acid is increased, and bicarbonate reabsorption is increased.

Respiratory changes (changes in PCO2) promote a corresponding change in metabolic response (changes in HCO3-) and vice versa as a compensatory mechanism. In general, PCO2 and HCO3- move in the same direction for compensation in metabolic and respiratory acid-base disorders, respectively. A change in the two parameters in opposite directions points to a mixed acid-base disturbance. 

Related Pearl: Causes of Acid-Base Disorders

Metabolic acidosis

Metabolic alkalosis

Respiratory acidosis

Respiratory alkalosis

Ketoacidosis

Chronic renal failure

Salicylate intoxication

Methanol/formaldehyde intoxication

High altitude

Psychogenic

Related Pearl: Expected compensation in acid-base disorders

Primary disorder Expected compensation
Metabolic acidosis

Expected PaCO2 = [1 .5 X HCO3-] + 8 ± 2; or

↓ PaCO2 = 1.25 x ΔHCO3
Metabolic alkalosis Increase in PaCO2 = 0.75 x ΔHCO3-

Respiratory acidosis

↓ pH = 0.008 x ΔPaCO2
Chronic

Increase in HCO3- = 0.4 x Δ PaCO2

↑ pH = 0.008 x ΔPaCO2

Chronic

Decrease in HCO3- = 0.4 x Δ PaCO2

Related Pearl: Interpretation of Acid-Base Disorders

pH<7.35 is acidosis

pH>7.45 is alkalosis

A primary change in HCO3- is termed metabolic

If the change in HCO3- is in keeping with the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and HCO3- is decreased) the problem is metabolic.

If the change in HCO3- is opposite with the pH (i.e. if there is acidosis and HCO3- is increased or normal) the problem is compensatory metabolic.

A primary change in CO2 is termed as respiratory

If the change in CO2 keeping in line with the pH (if in acidosis CO2 is raised) the problem is termed respiratory

If the change in CO2 is in the opposite direction of that of the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and CO2 is decreased or normal ) the problem is termed compensatory respiratory

questions.text: The JAK2 inhibitor used in the treatment of polycythemia vera is ?
questions.solution:
Ruxolitinib is the janus associated kinase (JAK2) inhibitor used in the treatment of polycythemia vera.

Note:

  • Dabrafenib: BRAF kinase inhibitor - treatment of melanoma
  • Nilotinib: Bcr-Abl (tyrosine kinase) inhibitor - treatment of chronic myeloid leukemia, increased potency and better tolerance than Imatinib
  • Eculizumab: anti-C5 complement inhibitor - treatment of paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria

questions.text: In GCS-P scoring system, what does P denote?
questions.solution:
In GCS-P ,P denotes pupillary response to light.

A new parameter, 'pupil reactivity score' has been added to GCS, and now it is being referred to as GCS - P.

Pupils Unreactive to light Score
Both pupils 2
One pupil 1 
Neither  0

The range of GCS-P is 1–15.

Related Pearl: Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS)

GCS Score

  • 13-15 represent mild injury
  • 9-12 represent moderate injury
  • Scores ≤8 represent severe injury 

Head Injury Severity: Clinical classification 

Eyes Opening

 Score
Spontaneously 4
To verbal command 3
To painful stimulus 2
Do not open 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Verbal response Score
Normal-oriented conversation 5
Confused 4
Inappropriate words only 3
Sounds only 2
No sounds 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Motor Response Score
Obeys commands 6

Withdrawal response to pain 4
Abnormal flexion/ Decorticate posturing  3
Abnormal extension/ Decerebrate posturing  2
No motor response 1

Non-testable

 NT

Minimum value: 3

Maximum value: 15

  • GCS, in particular, the motor score, is the best predictor of neurological outcome.
  • If an area cannot be assessed, no numerical score is given for that region, and it is considered “non-testable." (NT)
  • In case of endotracheal intubation or tracheostomy, the verbal component of the score is denoted as NT.
  • A score of  ‘1’ is not recorded in missing components, instead, NT is used
  • when a component is Not Testable, a total score is not recorded because the score will be low and this could be confusing to medical colleagues. This may also imply that the patient is more unwell than they actually are.

 

NOTE: 

A new parameter, "pupil reactivity score" has been added to GCS, and now, it is referred to as GCS-P.

P stands for "Pupils unreactive to light"

Pupils unreactive to light Score
Both pupils 2
One pupil 1 
Neither  0

The pupillary score is subtracted from the GCS score to give the final value. Therefore, the range of GCS-P is 1–15.

Note: The minimum frequency of observations for patients with GCS equal to 15 should be as follows, starting after the initial assessment in the emergency department:

  • Half-hourly for 2 hours,
  • Then 1-hourly for 4 hours,
  • 2-hourly thereafter.

Should the patient with GCS equal to 15 deteriorate at any time after the initial 2-hour period, observations should revert to half-hourly and follow the original frequency schedule.

questions.text: A HIV positive female has Hb of 7.5gm/dl. Which of the following drugs must be avoided in her?
questions.solution:
Zidovudine should be avoided.

The primary toxicity of Zidovudine is bone marrow suppression leading to anemia and neutropenia, which may require transfusions. This 54-year-old woman with a Hb of 7.5g/dl is anemic and hence Zidovudine should be avoided.

Emtricitabine is contraindicated in pregnancy and young children.

questions.text: What are Charcot-Leyden crystals derived from?
questions.solution:
Charcot-Leyden crystals are derived from eosinophils. They are seen in patients with asthma.

Characteristics finding in sputum or bronchoalveolar lavage specimen of an asthma patient is Curschmann spirals, which may result from extrusion of mucus plugs from subepithelial mucous gland ducts or bronchioles. Also present are eosinophils and eosinophil protein galectin-10 forms Charcot-Leyden crystals.

Other characteristic histologic findings of asthma, collectively called airway remodeling include

  • Thickening of airway wall
  • Subbasement membrane fibrosis (due to deposition of collagen I and III)
  • Increased vascularity
  • An increase in the size of the submucosal glands and number of airway goblet cells.
  • Hypertrophy or hyperplasia of bronchial wall muscle.

Airway remodeling also adds an irreversible component to the obstructive disease.

questions.text: The most common vessel involved in lateral medullary syndrome is ______.
questions.solution:
The most common vessel involved in lateral meduallry syndrome is the vertebral artery.

Lateral medullary syndrome: occlusion of vertebral, posterior inferior cerebellar, superior, middle, or inferior lateral medullary arteries.

On side of lesion:

  • Fifth nerve nucleus and descending tract: Pain, numbness, impaired sensation over face
  • Cerebellar fibers, spinocerebellar tract: Ataxia
  • Vestibular nucleus: Nystagmus, diplopia, oscillopsia, vertigo, nausea, vomiting
  • Descending sympathetic tract: Horner’s syndrome (miosis, ptosis, decreased sweating)
  • Ninth and Tenth nerve fibers: Dysphagia, hoarseness, paralysis of palate, paralysis of vocal cord, diminished gag reflex:

On the contralateral side:

  • Spinothalamic tract: Impaired pain and thermal sense over half the body, sometimes face

Related Pearl: Medullary syndromes and Weber syndrome

  • I/L tongue paralysis

  • I/L loss of pain/temperature on face
