questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of revised trauma score (RTS)?
questions.solution:
Pulse rate is NOT a part of revised trauma score.

The Revised Trauma Score is made up of three categories: Glasgow Coma Scale, systolic blood pressure, and respiratory rate.

The score range is 0–12.

A patient with an RTS score of 12 is labeled delayed, 11 is urgent, and 3–10 is immediate. Those who have an RTS below 3 are declared dead.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman presented with neurological symptoms. The radiological image is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given MRI showing Dawson's fingers (white-colored areas perpendicular to the ventricular surface), points to a diagnosis of multiple sclerosis (MS).

Multiple sclerosis is an autoimmune disease in which there is chronic inflammation in the CNS, with demyelination and gliosis. Patients can present with a variety of symptoms:

  • Sensory symptoms such as paresthesias and pins and needles sensations
  • Optic neuritis, which presents as diminished visual acuity, decreased light perception, and periorbital pain which worsens with eye movement
  • Weakness of limbs, usually of the UMN type. Exercise-induced weakness is a characteristic of MS
  • Facial weakness 
  • Diplopia due to internuclear ophthalmoplegia
  • Trigeminal neuralgia, hemifacial spasm, and glossopharyngeal neuralgia
  • Bladder and bowel dysfunction

Patients with MS report worsening of their symptoms after being exposed to heat. For instance, the symptoms may worsen after a hot shower or during a fever. This phenomenon is termed Uhtoff's symptom. It probably occurs because of the transient conduction block when the body's core temperature is elevated. Another feature seen in MS is Lhermitte's symptom. It refers to an electric shock-like sensation that radiates down the back, into the legs. It is commonly induced by movements of the neck.

MRI is used for making the diagnosis of MS. The diagnosis of MS requires demonstrating that the lesions are disseminated in space (involving multiple areas of the brain) and in time (multiple episodes over a period of time). Dissemination in space is determined by evaluating the MS-typical lesions on MRI. Dissemination in time is determined by the coexistence of gadolinium-enhancing and non-enhancing lesions.

questions.text: Which of the following is a true statement about ulcerative colitis?

choices.text: Appendicectomy is not a protective factor.
Pyloric metaplasia is a clinical marker.

questions.solution:
Collar button ulcers are seen ulcerative colitis .

questions.text: Which of the following muscle groups is spared in inflammatory myopathies?
questions.solution:
Ocular muscles are spared in inflammatory myopathies.

Ocular muscles are spared, even in advanced, untreated cases of inflammatory myopathy.

In all forms of inflammatory myopathy, pharyngeal and neck-flexor muscles are often involved, causing dysphagia or difficulty in holding up the head (head drop). In advanced and rarely in acute cases, respiratory muscles may also be affected.

Patients usually report increasing difficulty with everyday tasks requiring the use of proximal muscles, such as getting up from a chair (quadrceps muscle), climbing steps, stepping onto a curb, lifting objects or combing hair.

questions.text: What does the transverse diameter extend between at the pelvic inlet?
questions.solution:
The transverse diameter at the pelvic inlet extends between the linea terminalis on either side. It is at right angles to the obstetrical conjugate and intersects it 5 cm in front of the sacral promontory. It is approximately 13 cm in length.

The interspinous diameter is measured at the level of mid-pelvis and extends between ischial spines. It is the smallest pelvic diameter and is around 10 cm in length.

The inter-tuberous diameter is measured at the pelvic outlet and extends between the inner borders of the ischial tuberosities. It is about 11 cm in length.

questions.text: What does a positive fern test indicate in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
A positive fern test in pregnancy indicates amniotic fluid leakage.

Ferning refers to the formation of a fern-like branching pattern seen when cervical mucus is smeared on a glass slide and viewed under a microscope. It is due to the sodium chloride present in the mucus. Increase in estrogen increases sodium chloride secretion whereas progesterone is inhibitory.

Ferning is maximal just before ovulation and disappears on the 22nd day of a normal ovulatory cycle.

Image - ferning of cervical mucus:

Ferning is absent in pregnancy due to the high progesterone content. The presence of ferning indicates contamination by amniotic fluid following membrane rupture.

A false-positive test is seen in contamination with fingerprints, blood, and urine. A false-negative test is seen if the amniotic fluid leak is minimal or if much time has passed after the leakage.

questions.text: Which of the following signs is not associated with fetal growth restriction?

choices.text: Increased end diastolic flow in the MCA
Absent diastolic notch in the uterine artery
S/D ratio > 95 percentile in umbilical artery

questions.solution:
Absence of uterine artery diastolic notch is not associated with fetal growth restriction. The notch is present in pregnancy and normally disappears with uterine artery remodeling in the 2nd trimester. Persistence of the notch beyond 24 weeks of gestation is associated with preeclampsia and IUGR. However, this finding is not used in clinical practice as it has a poor predictive value. 

Image: Uterine artery doppler, without and with early diastolic notch

Other doppler findings in fetal growth restriction include the following:

  • Umbilical artery: S/D ratio > 95 percentile for gestational age. In extreme growth restriction, end-diastolic flow is absent or reversed.
  • Middle cerebral artery: Increased end-diastolic flow due to brain sparing effect.
  • Ductus venosus: Decreased, absent or reversed flow corresponding to the a-wave/ atrial contraction.

Image: Doppler findings in the umbilical artery and middle cerebral artery

Image: Ductus venosus, normal waveform vs waveform in IUGR fetus

It is believed that changes appear first in the umbilical artery, followed by the middle cerebral artery and then the ductus venosus.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions does the uterus match the size expected for the gestational period?
questions.solution:
The uterine size corresponds to gestational age in threatened abortion.

Abortion Clinical picture Size of uterus  Internal os          USG
THREATENED Slight bleeding Corresponds Closed Live foetus, sub-chorionic haemorrhage
INEVITABLE Bleeding, pain, shock Equal or less Open with products felt Dead foetus
INCOMPLETE Bleeding Smaller Open Retained products
COMPLETE Bleeding stopped Smaller Closed Empty cavity
MISSED Absent/minimal bleeding Smaller Closed Dead foetus

questions.text: What is the most common karyotype seen in complete mole?
questions.solution:
46 XX is the most common karyotype seen in a complete mole.

It occurs when an ovum with absent or inactivated chromosomes is fertilized by a haploid sperm (23 X) which then duplicates its chromosomes (46 XX) after meiosis.

46 XY karyotype is less commonly seen in complete mole and occurs when an ovum with absent/inactivated chromosomes is fertilised by two sperms (23 X and 23 Y). This is called dispermy.

69 XXY and 69 XXX karyotypes are common in partial mole and are due to fertilization of a haploid ovum by two sperms. 69 XYY karyotype is less common.

Related Pearl: Complete vs. Partial Mole

Hydatidiform mole is a benign abnormal condition of the placenta characterized by partial degenerative or proliferative changes of the chorionic villi. Though benign, it has malignant potential. It is commonly seen in pregnancies of extreme reproductive age groups - teenage and women above 35 years of age. A previous history of molar pregnancy is also a strong risk factor for recurrence of this condition.

Molar pregnancy is of 2 types - complete mole and partial mole.

Feature Partial mole Complete mole
Karyotype 69 XYY or 69 XXY 46 XX or 46 XY
Diagnosis Missed abortion Molar gestation
Uterus size Small for date Large for date
Theca-lutein cysts Rare 25–30% of cases
Initial hCG levels <1 lakh mIU/ml >1 lakh mIU/ml
Medical complications Rare Uncommon
Rate of subsequent GTN 1–5% 15–20%
Embryo-fetus  Often present Absent
Amnion, fetal erythrocytes Often present Absent
Villous edema  Focal Widespread
Trophoblastic proliferation Focal, slight to moderate Slight to severe
Trophoblast atypia Mild Marked
p57KIP2 immunostaining Positive Negative

questions.text: In mediolateral episiotomy, at what angle is the incision made away from the midline?
questions.solution:
In mediolateral episiotomy, the incision is made at an angle of 60 degrees from the midline. Post-delivery of the fetus, this angle changes to 45 degrees as the stretched and distorted perineum becomes relaxed.

Related Pearl: Mediolateral Episiotomy

It begins within 3 mm of the midline in the posterior fourchette and is directed laterally at an angle of at least 60 degrees from the midline. This yields an incision of 45 degrees off the midline.

It is essentially an inflicted second-degree perineal tear.

Structures cut in mediolateral episiotomy:

  • Posterior vaginal wall
  • Superficial and deep transverse perineal muscles, bulbospongiosus and part of levator ani
  • Fascia covering those muscles
  • Transverse perineal branches of pudendal vessels and nerves
  • Subcutaneous tissue and skin

Advantage: Lesser risk of anal sphincter laceration, hence it is preferred over median episiotomy.

Disadvantage: Increased blood loss and causes more perineal pain and dyspareunia.

questions.text: In occiput anterior presentation, what is the most common position in which the fetal head enters the pelvis?
questions.solution:
In occiput anterior presentations, the most common position in which the foetal head enters the pelvis is the left occiput transverse (LOT) position. The mechanism of labor is similar in all positions. With internal rotation, the occiput is rotated anteriorly towards the pubic symphysis.

Note:

  • Most common presentation: Cephalic
  • Most common presenting part: vertex
  • Head enters the pelvis through: transverse diameter> oblique >AP diameter
  • Most common position of foetus is left occiput transverse> left occiput anterior
  • Internal rotation of foetal head occurs at the level of ischial spine.
  • In a vertex delivery, the baby's head is delivered by extension.
  • In a breech delivery, the baby's head is delivered by flexion.
  • The best time to give episiotomy is after crowning has occurred.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions does not show the finding seen in the image below?
questions.solution:
The cardiotocograph shows a sinusoidal fetal heart rate pattern and is not seen in fetal head compression which shows early deceleration. Fetal head compression typically shows early deceleration.

A sinusoidal pattern is seen in the following conditions:

  • Fetal intracranial hemorrhage
  • Severe fetal asphyxia
  • Severe fetal anemia - Due to anti-D alloimmunization, feto-maternal hemorrhage, bleeding from vasa previa, parvovirus infection, and twin-twin transfusion syndrome.
  • Administration of opioid analgesics - pethidine, morphine, alphaprodine, and butorphanol

The pattern is characterized by a stable baseline heart rate between 120-160 with regular sinusoidal oscillations. The amplitude of the oscillations is usually between 5-15 beats per minute and accelerations are absent.

Other cardiotocography patterns:

Early deceleration:

Uniform, repetitive periodic slowing of FHR and in most cases the onset of the uterine contraction and recovery of deceleration coincide with the beginning, peak, and ending of uterine contraction respectively. It is due to head compression (vagal nerve activation)

 Late deceleration:

Uniform, repetitive periodic slowing of FHR. It begins after the onset of the uterine contraction. Usually, the onset, nadir, and recovery of the deceleration occur after the start, peak, and end of the uterine contraction respectively. Nadir occurs 20 seconds after the peak of the contraction and FHR returns to normal after the contraction is over. It suggests uteroplacental insufficiency and fetal hypoxia.

Variable deceleration:

It is the intermittent periodic slowing (variable) of FHR with rapid onset and recovery. Decelerations are variable in all respect of size, shape, depth, duration, and timing to the uterine contractions. It is thought to indicate cord compression and may disappear with the change in position of the patient. Accelerations often precede and follow the deceleration.

questions.text: Identify the maneuver shown in the image below.
questions.solution:
Modified Prague’s maneuver is shown in the image. It is used in breech presentations to deliver the aftercoming head when the back of the fetus fails to rotate to the symphysis.

Technique:

  • Grasp the shoulders of the baby from below with two fingers of one hand.
  • Draw the feet up and over the maternal abdomen with the other hand.

Other options:

Lovset’s maneuver is used for the delivery of extended arms in case of a breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Hold the sacrum with the thumb and the hips and pelvis with other fingers.
  • Turn infant 90 degrees to bring shoulder under pubic symphysis and deliver the anterior shoulder.
  • Then counter-rotate 180 degrees to engage and deliver the posterior shoulder.

 

Burns-Marshall method is used for delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Allow the baby to hang by its own weight.
  • When the nape of neck is visible under the pubic arch, grasp the baby by the ankles with a finger in between the two.
  • Swing the baby in an arc in an upward and forward direction.

Pinard’s maneuver is used for the delivery of extended legs in case of breech delivery.

Technique:

  • Flex and abduct the popliteal fossa
  • Catch hold of the ankle
  • Pull down along with abduction

Related Pearl: Maneuvers for breech delivery

Pinard’s manoeuvre 

It is used for the delivery of extended legs in case of breech delivery.

Technique:

  • Flex and abduct the popliteal fossa
  • Catch hold of the ankle
  • Pull down along with abduction

 

Lovset’s manoeuvre

It is used for the delivery of extended arms in case of a breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Hold the sacrum with the thumb, and the hips and pelvis with other fingers.
  • Turn the infant 90 degrees to bring the shoulder under pubic symphysis and deliver the anterior shoulder.
  • Then counter-rotate 180 degrees to engage and deliver the posterior shoulder. 

 

Modified Prague’s manoeuvre

It is used in breech presentations to deliver the aftercoming head when the back of the fetus fails to rotate to the symphysis.

Technique:

  • Grasp the shoulders of the baby from below with two fingers of one hand.
  • Draw the feet up and over the maternal abdomen with the other hand.

 

Burns-Marshall method

It is used for delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Allow the baby to hang by its own weight.
  • When the nape of the neck is visible under the pubic arch, grasp the baby by the ankles with a finger in between the two.
  • Swing the baby in an arc in an upward and forward direction.

 

Mauriceau-Smellie-Veit technique

It is another method that can be used in the delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation. It is also called malar flexion and shoulder traction.

Technique:

  • Place the baby on the supinated left arm with limbs hanging on either side.
  • Place the index and middle fingers of the left hand on either side over the malar bones.
  • Place the ring and the little finger of the pronated right hand on the child’s right shoulder, index finger on the left shoulder and middle finger over the suboccipital region.
  • Traction is given in the downward and backward direction till the nape of the neck is visible.
  • Thereafter, the baby is carried in an upward and forward direction towards the mother’s abdomen.

 

Mnemonic:

  • Extend the arm to express Love(Lovset's)
  • Put the fingers in popliteal fossa for Pinard's(P for P)

questions.text: According to WHO guidelines on postpartum hemorrhage management, in which of the following conditions is controlled cord traction now considered optional?
questions.solution:
According to the WHO, controlled cord traction is now considered optional in vaginal deliveries conducted by skilled birth attendants.

Other options:

It is contraindicated in deliveries where skilled birth attendants are not available.

Controlled cord traction is recommended in cesarean sections and in deliveries where the third stage of labor lasts for more than 30 minutes.

Note: The WHO recommends controlled cord traction in vaginal deliveries only if a small reduction in blood loss and duration of labor is considered important by the physician and the mother.

questions.text:
Which among the following incisions is made during LSCS?

LSCS- Lower segment Cesarean section
questions.solution:
Pfannenstiel incision, represented by 4 in the image above is the most common incision made in lower section caesarean delivery.

It follows Langer lines of skin tension. A transverse and slightly curbvilinear incision is made in the skin and subcutaneous tissue 3 cm above the superior border of the pubic symphysis. This is stretched laterally for 12-15 cm to accommodate the delivery of the fetus. Following this, the rectus sheath is incised transversely and rectus muscles are separated in the middle to gain entry to the peritoneum.

The various incisions mentioned in the image are:

Incision '1' - Midline vertical incision is made in the middle extending from just below the umbilicus to just above the symphysis pubis. This is used less commonly compared to the transverse abdominal incision.

Incision '2' - The Maylard incision is a variation of the Pfannenstiel incision in which the rectus abdominis muscles are sectioned transversely to permit wider access to the pelvis. It is also known as the Mackenrodt incision.

Incision '3' - Joel Cohen is a straight incision higher than the Pfannenstiel incision. The fascia was incised transversely in the midline then extended laterally with blunt finger dissection; finger dissection was used to separate the rectus muscles vertically and laterally.

questions.text: The Ortho Evra transdermal patch releases ethinyl estradiol and ____________
questions.solution:
The Ortho Evra transdermal patch is a hormonal contraceptive that releases ethinyl estradiol and norelgestromin. It can be applied to the buttocks, upper outer arm, lower abdomen or upper torso, but not to the breasts.

A patch is worn at the beginning of the menstrual cycle and replaced every week for 3 weeks. It is then discontinued for one week to allow for withdrawal bleeding.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is magnesium sulphate not indicated?
questions.solution:
Magnesium sulfate is not indicated in chronic hypertension. It is used to treat eclampsia and also prevent it in the following conditions

  • Severe pre-eclampsia
  • Acute rise in blood pressure to a systolic BP > 160 mm Hg or a diastolic BP > 110 mm Hg or both

MgSO4 regimens:

 

Regimen Loading Dose Maintenance Dose
Intramuscular (Pritchard) 4 g (20% solution) IV over 3-5 minute
followed by 10 g (5O%), deep IM
(5 gm in each buttock)		 5 g (5O%) IM 4 hourly in the alternate buttock
Intravenous (Zuspan or Sibai) 4g IV slow over 15-20 minute 1-2 g/h IV infusion

questions.text: In a primigravida, there is uterine inversion after the foetus is delivered. The management of this condition involves all except ______________
questions.solution:
Management of uterine inversion does not include cord traction. The following steps are done simultaneously in uterine inversion.

  • Administration of IV crystalloids through large-bore IV cannulas to prevent/treat neurogenic and hemorrhagic shock. This is followed by blood transfusion to replace losses.
  • Tocolytics such as terbulatine, magnesium sulphate, and nitroglycerin can be used to relax the uterus for repositioning. An inhalational anesthetic agent can be used if relaxation is not sufficient with tocolytics.
  • Repositioning is tried after confirming that the inverted uterus is not firmly retracted or contracted. The palm and the fingers are used to push up the uterine fundus along the vaginal axis.
  • The placenta is manually removed after repositioning if it is still attached to the uterus. If repositioning fails, the placenta is peeled and repositioning is tried again.
  • Oxytocin infusion is started and tocolytics are stopped after repositioning.
  • The position of the uterus is maintained while applying bimanual compression.
  • Surgical intervention is needed if repositioning fails or can't be done.

questions.text: Which of the following is used to treat postpartum venous thrombosis?
questions.solution:
Postpartum venous thrombosis is treated simultaneously with warfarin and unfractionated heparin (UFH) or low molecular weight heparin (LMWH).

Warfarin is safe in the postpartum period as it does not accumulate in breast milk. It is started at a dose of 5-10 mg for 2 days and titrated to achieve an INR of 2-3.

UFH or LMWH is added until the therapeutic INR is reached and maintained for 2 days. This is done to avoid paradoxical thrombosis/skin necrosis seen initially in warfarin therapy due to its anti-protein C effect.

questions.text: In pregestational diabetes, which system is most commonly affected by congenital malformations?
questions.solution:
The incidence of congenital malformations is increased in pregestational diabetes and the cardiovascular system is most commonly involved. Increased risk of congenital malformations is thought to be due to poor glycemic control in the pre-conceptional period and in early pregnancy.

Adequacy of glycemic control can be assessed using HbA1c in the first trimester and the risk of malformations increases with increasing HbA1c levels.

questions.text: A young nulliparous female who desires pregnancy comes to you with complaints of heavy menstrual bleeding. On palpation, an abdominal mass corresponding to 14 weeks of gestation is felt. The mass is found to be a subserosal pedunculated fibroid on imaging. What is the treatment of choice?
questions.solution:
The treatment of choice in this nulliparous female with subserosal pedunculated fibroid is myomectomy. Myomectomy is indicated if the uterus size corresponds to more than 12 weeks of gestation and the patient desires pregnancy.

Myomectomy refers to the removal of fibroids and preserving the uterus. It is indicated in fibroids which present with the following 

  • Persistent uterine bleeding despite medical therapy
  • Excessive pain or pressure symptoms
  • Size > 12 weeks, patient desirous to have a baby
  • Unexplained infertility with distortion of the uterine cavity due to fibroid
  • Recurrent pregnancy wastage due to fibroid
  • Rapid growth during follow up
  • Subserous pedunculated fibroid

Myomectomy can be performed by laparoscopy, hysteroscopy, or laparotomy. It is contraindicated in patients with an infected fibroid, pelvic or endometrial tuberculosis, suspected malignancy, and growth in post-menopausal and multiparous women where hysterectomy can be the safe definitive management.

Fibroids are benign estrogen dependant tumors of the uterine smooth muscles and connective tissue. 

Management of uterine fibroids in asymptomatic patients includes observation with regular follow-up regardless of the size of the fibroid. Surgery is indicated in cornual fibroids if it causes infertility or pedunculated fibroids (due to the risk of torsion). 

In symptomatic patients, medical therapy is done to shrink the fibroid. It acts as a preoperative adjunct. Surgical methods such as myomectomy, laparoscopic myolysis, hysterectomy, and endometrial ablation are tried for patients with persistent symptoms despite conservative management. Hysterectomy is done in postmenopausal women and in multiparous women who have completed their families or are not desirous of childbirth.

Related Pearl: Myomectomy

Myomectomy

  • Retains uterus and hence preserves childbearing function.
  • Effective for heavy menstrual bleeding and pelvic pressure.
  • Disadvantage - formation of new clones of abnormal myocytes.
  • Hysteroscopic myomectomy is the procedure of choice for removing intracavitary myomas.
  • Vaginal myomectomy is performed in case, a fibroid prolapses through the cervix.

Related Pearl: Indications for treatment in an asymptomatic fibroid

  • Infertility caused by a cornual fibroid blocking the tube, or a submucous fibroid causing habitual abortions.
  • Any fibroid of more than 12 weeks size
  • A pedunculated fibroid which can undergo torsion
  • A fibroid causing pressure on the ureter/ bladder, leaving residual urine and causing a urinary infection.
  • Rapidly growing fibromyoma in a menopausal woman implying impending malignancy
  • When the nature of the tumor cannot be ascertained clinically (laparotomy is needed on this occasion).

questions.text: In which condition is the pessary test done to rule out surgery?
questions.solution:
The pessary test is done in uterine retroversion to rule out the need for surgical treatment. The retroverted uterus is held in the anteverted position by a Hodge-Smith pessary for 3 months. If symptoms such as dyspareunia, back pain, and pelvic pain disappear on placing the pessary and then reappear after removal, it is concluded that retroversion is the cause and surgical correction is done. Otherwise, surgical correction is not indicated.

Retroversion is surgically corrected by ventro-suspension of the uterus. In this procedure, the uterus is anteverted by plicating the round ligaments to the undersurface of the anterior rectus sheath.

Note: The pessary test is also done to diagnose occult stress incontinence associated with pelvic organ prolapse and determine if a prophylactic anti-incontinence procedure is needed in addition to prolapse repair.

questions.text: A 30-year-old asymptomatic woman undergoes a VIA VILI examination. A sharply demarcated acetowhite area extending upto the squamocolumnar junction is seen. The area does not stain brown with Lugol’s iodine. What will you do next?
questions.solution:
Abnormal areas on visual inspection with acetic acid and Lugol’s iodine are biopsied and subjected to histological examination. These include areas that appear white on the application of 3 or 5% acetic acid and do not stain mahogany brown with Lugol’s iodine.

Conization and endocervical curettage are indicated if the inner margin of the acetowhite area (transformation zone) is not visualized.

Further management is based on the biopsy findings.

Related Pearl: Management of CIN

questions.text: What is the most common cause of puberty menorrhagia?
questions.solution:
The most common cause of puberty menorrhagia is anovulatory cycles. The ovulation failure is due to an immature hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian (H-P-O) axis. This leads to unopposed estrogen action on the endometrium causing hyperplasia and prolonged heavy bleeding.

Other causes such as polycystic ovary syndrome, hypothyroidism, and clotting factor deficiency are less common.

Treatment:

Often, menstrual cycles become regular as the H-P-O axis matures.

  • Rest and correction of anemia are the only needed treatment in most cases.
  • In refractory bleeding, normal cycles are established using a progestogen such as medroxyprogesterone acetate or norethisterone, followed by combined oral contraceptives.
  • Conjugated equine estrogen is administered intravenously to stop bleeding in emergencies.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman complains of foul-smelling vaginal discharge. A giemsa-stained smear of the discharge is shown below. Which of the following is not seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The image shows Trichomonas vaginalis and infection causes a frothy, greenish-yellow discharge. Curdy white discharge is seen in vaginal candidiasis.

Trichomonas is a protozoan that’s slightly larger than a leucocyte with four anterior flagella and a single posterior flagellum. It exhibits jerky or twitching motility.

Infection of the female genital tract causes the following symptoms:

  • Foul-smelling, frothy, greenish-yellow discharge per vaginum
  • Itching around the vulva
  • Dysuria and frequent micturition

The vagina looks red and inflamed. The inflamed cervix looks like a strawberry with punctate hemorrhagic spots.

The condition is treated with a single 2 gm dose of metronidazole or tinidazole. The partner must also be treated simultaneously.

questions.text: A woman with a family history of breast cancer undergoes genetic screening and is found to be positive for BRCA1 mutation. Which of the following procedures should be suggested to this patient?
questions.solution:
Prophylactic bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy and mastectomy are offered in women with BRCA mutations as they have an increased risk of ovarian and breast cancers.

Salpingo-oophorectomy is ideally done between the ages of 35 to 40 for those with BRCA1 mutations but can be delayed up to 45 years for those with BRCA2 mutations. This procedure also reduces the risk of breast cancer in premenopausal women by decreasing hormonal stimulation of the breasts.

Bilateral mastectomy reduces the risk of breast cancer by 85-100%.

The risk can also be reduced with medical therapy. Combined oral contraceptives reduce the risk of ovarian cancer and tamoxifen or raloxifene reduces the risk of breast cancer.

questions.text: What is the most common complication associated with ovarian dermoid cyst?
questions.solution:
Torsion is the most common complication seen in dermoid cyst of the ovary.

Other options:

  • Cyst rupture is less common and is seen in only about 1% of dermoid cysts. It leads to granulomatous peritonitis.
  • Malignant transformation occurs in 1-2% of dermoid cysts.
  • Hyperthyroidism is a rare complication seen in dermoid cysts with thyroid tissue.

questions.text: A 26-year-old man with Kallmann syndrome and on testosterone therapy wishes to undergo treatment for infertility. Which of the following is used to treat infertility in this condition?
questions.solution:
Infertility in Kallmann’s syndrome is due to gonadotrophin-releasing hormone deficiency and is treated using gonadotrophin-releasing hormone (GnRH) or beta-human chorionic gonadotrophin (β-HCG).

In addition to infertility, the external genitalia and testes are also underdeveloped and secondary sexual characters are absent. Hence, testosterone therapy is given first to induce virilisation before treatment of infertility.

Hypogonadotrophic hypogonadism with anosmia is called Kallmann’s syndrome and it is caused by a failure of migration of olfactory and GnRH secreting neurons during development.

questions.text: Where is ectopic endometrial tissue seen in endometriosis interna?
questions.solution:
Endometriosis interna is an alternative term for adenomyosis and refers to the ingrowth of endometrium into the myometrium.

Adenomyosis (Endometriosis interna):

  • Etiology: Vigorous curettage, repeated child birth or excess of estrogen
  • Clinical features:
    • Multiparous females >40 years
    • Most common symptom: Menorrhagia > Dysmenorrhea
    • Pelvic discomfort, backache, dyspareunia
    • Per-Vaginal: Symmetrical enlargement of uterus (corresponding to <12-14 weeks of pregnancy)
    • Bimanual examination: Halban’s sign: Tender, softened uterus
  • Diagnosis:
    • It is mainly clinical
    • Diagnostic hysteroscopy with curettage
  • Management of adenomyosis
    • Total Hysterectomy (Treatment of choice)
    • Localized excision/ Levonorgestrel containing IUCD is tried in younger women.

questions.text: What is the treatment of choice for non-metastatic epithelioid trophoblastic tumour?
questions.solution: The treatment of choice for non-metaplastic epithelioid trophoblastic tumour is hysterectomy. It is a rare tumour that histologically resembles placental site trophoblastic tumour (PSTT) but forms nodules instead of infiltrative lesions.  It arises from chorionic-type intermediate trophoblast and often occurs long after a preceding pregnancy. The efficacy of chemotherapy is not yet clear as only a few cases have been reported so far.

questions.text: Serum level of which of the following is decreased in polycystic ovary syndrome?
questions.solution:
Serum progesterone levels are decreased in polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) due to anovulation.

Other options:

Serum Luteinizing hormone (LH) and LH-FSH ratio are increased due to changes in the pulsatile secretion of Gonadotrophin releasing hormone (GnRH).

Hyperandrogenism is a feature of polycystic ovary disease and serum levels of free testosterone, androstenedione, and dehydroepiandrosterone sulfate (DHEA-S) are elevated. It is due to increased ovarian secretion of androgens in response to luteinizing hormone and decreased serum levels of sex hormone-binding globulin (SHBG).

Insulin resistance in polycystic ovary syndrome leads to hyperinsulinemia.

 

Related Pearl: Endocrinological changes of PCOD

  1. Elevated Estrone/E1 levels.
  2. LH level is raised over 10 IU/mL. FSH level remains normal to low, but FSH/LH ratio falls.
  3. Testosterone and epi-androstenedione levels rise.
    • Testosterone elevated but < 200 ng/dL (normal range 20 -80 ng/dL)
    • Testosterone > 200 ng/dL suggests androgen-secreting ovarian tumor
    • DHEA-S values may be normal or slightly elevated
    • DHEA >700 ng/mL suggests adrenal tumour
  4. Serum SHBG is reduced.
  5. Triglyceride level >150 mg/dL-hyperlipidaemia HDL <50 mg/dL.
  6. Fasting blood glucose/fasting insulin <4.5 suggests insulin resistance
  7. Prolactin is mildly raised in 15% cases
  8. Fasting insulin is more than 10 mIU/L in PCOS in 50–70%cases
  9. Thyroid function tests may be abnormal (hypothyroidism)
  10. 17-a-hydroxyprogesterone in the follicular phase >300 ng/dL suggests adrenal hyperplasia due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency.
  11. Urinary cortisol <50 μg/24 h.

questions.text: Surgical staging in a woman with endometrial carcinoma reveals an invasion of less than 50% thickness of the myometrium. No other structures are involved. Histopathological examination shows grade 3 endometrial carcinoma. Which of the following is done after surgery?
questions.solution:
The patient has stage IA, grade 3 endometrial carcinoma as less than 50% of the myometrium is invaded. It should be managed with postoperative radiotherapy/brachytherapy. 

Post-operative pelvic radiotherapy is advocated for stages IA (grade 3), IA2, IB, and II. Radiotherapy along with chemotherapy provides a better result. A dose of 6000 cGy is used for a period of 6 weeks. Post-operative radiotherapy is given based on three factors: grade of the tumor, histology of the tumor, and depth of the tumor.

Radiotherapy as the main mode of treatment is used in stages III and IV when the tumors are inoperable. Chemotherapy is also given in stage III, while palliative radiotherapy is used in stage IV. 

Endometrial carcinoma - histopathological examination:

Grade Features
1 The glandular pattern is maintained with cellular atypia
2 Some glands show a papillary pattern and are solid
3 Glands are solid with a loss of architecture and stroma is scant

 

Related Pearl: Ca.Endometrium staging (Revised FIGO)

Related Pearl: Management of endometrial cancer

Surgery is done for staging of the cancer. The surgery done for this purpose is abdominal hysterectomy, bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy, omentectomy, and pelvic as well as para-aortic lymph node sampling.

Stage Treatment
IA noninvasive 
  • Surgery alone
IA
  • Surgery
  • Post-op radiotherapy
IB
  • Surgery
  • Post-op pelvic radiotherapy 4000-5000 cGy
  • Post-op vaginal vault radiotherapy
II
  • Surgery
  • Post-op brachytherapy
  • Post-op external beam radiotherapy
  • Wertheim's hysterectomy
III
  • Inoperable/ Cytoreduction
  • Chemotherapy with Doxorubicin+Cisplatin+Paclitaxel
  • Medroxyprogesterone adjuvant
IV
  • Inoperable/ Cytoreduction
  • Palliative radiotherapy/chemo/ progesterone therapy

*This pearl is in line with the FIGO 2010 guidelines. It will be updated according to the FIGO 2023 guidelines after an official treatment guideline is released.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a definitive criterion in the diagnosis of pelvic inflammatory disease?

choices.text: Tubal hyperemia on a doppler scan
Cervical infection with N. gonorrhoeae or C. trachomatis

questions.solution:
Laboratory confirmation of cervical infection with Neisseria gonorrhoeae or Chlamydia trachomatis is only an added criterion and not a definitive criterion in the diagnosis of pelvic inflammatory disease (PID). This is because less than 50% of the women diagnosed with acute PID test positive for these organisms.

The criteria used in the diagnosis of pelvic inflammatory disease include the following:

CDC 2006 criteria for the diagnosis of PID

  • Definitive criteria:
    • Histopathological evidence of endometritis on endometrial biopsy
    • Transvaginal sonography or MRI suggesting salpingitis or tubo-ovarian abscess
    • Doppler findings such as tubal hyperemia which suggest pelvic infection
    • Laparoscopic abnormalities consistent with PID
  •  Minimum criteria:
    • Lower abdominal tenderness
    • Adnexal tenderness
    • Cervical motion tenderness
  • Additional criteria:
    • Oral temperature >38.3° C (101° F)
    • Abnormal cervical or vaginal mucopurulent discharge
    • Abundant WBC on saline mount of vaginal secretions
    • Elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate
    • Elevated C-Reactive protein
    • Lab evidence of cervical infection with N.Gonorrhoeae or C.trachomatis

Presumptive treatment for PID should be started if even one minimum criterion is met in sexually active and at-risk women with pelvic or lower abdominal pain and no other identifiable cause.

The CDC recommends that all women diagnosed with acute PID should be tested for HIV, gonorrhea, and chlamydial infections using nucleic acid amplification test (NAAT).

questions.text: Which of the following procedures involves burying the proximal stump into the myometrium?
questions.solution:
Irving procedure involves ligating and excising the mid-portion of the tube followed by burial of the proximal stump into the myometrium. The distal stump is buried in the broad ligament.

Other options:

  • Uchida technique involves stripping the serosa from the muscular layer in the midsegment of the tube, followed by ligation and excision of the stripped portion. The proximal stump is buried in the broad ligament while the distal stump is left open to the peritoneal cavity.
  • Pomeroy technique involves forming a loop off the mid-portion of the tube followed by ligation at the base and excision. It is the most popular technique of tubal ligation.
  • Kroener procedure refers to fimbriectomy done by ligating the distal ampulla with two permanent sutures followed by division and removal of the infundibulum.
